Just finding this now. I have pretty sever anxiety and depression and am on a number of drugs to help with that. I used to love mushrooms when I was younger, but now that I am on these pills I have taken up to 10 grams of very high quality Mushrooms and I feel absolutely nothing. I have tried DMT as well, everyone with me doing the mushrooms and DMT had crazy trips and I was dead sober, didn't feel a thing. I took 2-3 times as much as anyone else and felt nothing. The same thing happens with MDMA, really pure take 5 times as much as other people and nothing at all.  Is there any evidence that antidepressants curb the effect of hallucinogens? I'm just curious because it is kind of frustrating that I can't even use psychedelics without first cutting off my meds, which are helping me. Curious to hear your thoughts.

Pretty amazing that all of these substances are still listed as controlled substances, class C1, which means they have the most abuse potential and have no therapeutic use. Both of those claims are positively ridiculous. Another chemical that is also designated C-1 is THC. Just for a little reference, in the US heroin is also a C1 drug. C2 includes morphine and codeine,  oxycodone and Fentanyl. Valium and many of the benzodiazepines are C3.  It is patently absurd to categorize marijuana and its derivatives, as well as psychedelics, as C1 drugs. Allegedly they have no medicinal use, are most addictive, have the highest potential for abuse, and harshest penalties for possession.   Call or write your Senators and representatives, and demand that these substances be recategorized C5, or better yet not as controlled substances at all  The following is verbatim from the DEA website:   The abuse rate is a determinate factor in the scheduling of the drug; for example, Schedule I drugs have a high potential for abuse and the potential to create severe psychological and/or physical dependence. As the drug schedule changes-- Schedule II, Schedule III, etc., so does the abuse potential-- Schedule V drugs represents the least potential for abuse.

Liberal drug cultures tend to romanticize substances and turn a blind eye to the risks. People like to talk about freedom, self-development, and ‚Äúnatural‚Äù experiences, but forget that drugs are fundamentally powerful chemicals. All powerful and euphoric drug experiences alter the reward system. By being drug-liberal, we send out the message that it is okay, and even good, to use drugs. As individuals, we have a responsibility to care for everyone in society. As usual, we focus only on the positive aspects, and the hype leads us to ignore the possible negative consequences

In SF around 2000, we dropped multiple moly pills along with 1/4 to 5 g of shrooms and it was the most remote experience from any altered state. We never saw elves or other beings, but we could feel a presence. The trip was a fractal of our lives. Imagine memories, feelings, impressions, etc., being branches and nodes on a fractal landscape that would evolve and fold. Anytime I would focus, I would travel very fast down a "corridor" and wherever I stopped it was the same evolution/expansion/convolution of consciousness/memories/ impressions/ etc...  It really delivered the axiom of "Wherever you go, there you are". There was no deeper truth other than that. It suggested that existence was not about current position but rather perception and experience of that perception at that given moment. you did not create reality, but you "tuned" into a reality of your conscious choice if you were in control. It's difficult to reconcile "absolute reality" and "your reality". We know that if one was to jump of a building, we would perish due to damaging our body but at the same time we suspect that it's a limitation of the conscious control of our reality. Who knows. I have yet to meet anyone that has truly mastered these concepts but many they claim they have. They live their lives in chaos and yet claim they have mastered reality. It's still better than trying to dominate our fellow humans/animals and instead working to dominate ourselves to better serve others and our environment. Please give me your thoughts. Blessings.

IDK, I used to be able to walk 100 meters from my door into a beautiful forest and harvest my own between last week of Feb to June 1st. They were Oviods. Though its a nice setting and was safe, and I spent everyday in thst forest all day with my dog and worked out with weapons on dead standing trees, my trips were horrible. My life is tragic in lonliness, yet now I often try to be alone with just my dog. No family or friends around in life. Blablabla. Id micro dose, and I also cool  extracted shrooms  into Cranberry juice and it was a shitton. That extract would hit me hard in 8 minutes then hit in hard waves over and over. It was brutal, quite scary too. Im never happy anymore except for moments of joy seeing my beautiful doggy happily running in a beautiful forest or swimming with me across a cool mountain river on a beautiful hot day. Shit like that, and playing instruments by besutiful mountain creeks with my doggy about maybe howling along. Mostly Im in a deep hard depression that has gone on almost two decades. I know why though. I spent years just thinking for hours on end, often in a forest. I can understand almost anything. When I was young and I tripped on shrooms, I had a great time, yet I was with friends and had a cool motorcycle house, and we were out at night in San Diego some, I remember a diner. I had gotten out of kenpo and saw my buddys and visiting HS buddys at the burrito joint Albertos next door. So I went in and they handed me anawesome Carne Asada Burrito, only cost $2 then in '88. They had loaded it with shrooms. I had no clue and ate it all. I live in an ancient van now with my dog. Not easy to get into the forest where I used to live. Havent found another source yet. I havent noticed is what I should say, as I have not looked for them. I used to walk out in the morning with my coffee thermos and dog and had added dried shrooms into my thermos. Id tripp out enjoying the sunshine through tall oak trees and looking out through Hemlock branches across a canyon. As long as I only took a few and had some food in my stomach, I was fine and did not trip hard. Judt did my usual which generally did envolve thinking for several hours about things. I have a lot of trouble doing anything now. Especially csuse my back and knees hurt and drop me. Depressed as fuck. I suddenly got shittons of money, and while it is merciful and gives hope, I still cant feel anything but doom generally. I think we are all fucked anyway soon. I need to purchase my own forest and put a house in it, yet I need 8 cleared acres mostly flat. Gotta have strong creek flowing year round. I get that shit, and treatment for disease I got and some vintage motorcycles and ultra light airplane to cly off and on my property and a garage for it all, and Ill be happy AF I bet.  Even if lonely. My dog will be happy, yet she has to greet other people regularly, so hopefully I can provide for a hot college girl to tend to my dick and love my dog till she moves on. Fuck yeah! Only problem is the land is too pricey, yet Ill find it. Or I may just go live in CR with my dog and hire young woman to teach me spanish.

As a trans person, psychs really helped me figure out who I really was and give myself the space to accept myself and see myself as beautiful and showed me that transitioning would give me a life that I wouldn't want to leave, because even after my first few psychedelic experiences I still denied myself and tried to live as a man, or as nonbinary, but I kept feeling this horrible feeling in my neuron systems that felt mismatched as I tripped, and eventually I began to accept that it was there while I was sober and drove me to substance abuse and suicidality, and I would trip acid to feel like myself. I wanted to break through to myself like that, to being a woman again but I didn't want to take acid after moving back in with my parents so my friend and I planned a picnic to eat shrooms. They started tripping at home and got stuck and I ate far too many mushrooms (the psilocybin content on these things is skyrocketing btw, be careful) and met Jesus and Buddha, before going on a journey through my mind and realizing all these weird things that my life had left cemented into my brain. I will never be able to to completely unravel everything that I saw but the universal peace I felt before that crazy break with reality, listening to the Beatles' Let It Be over and over on loop while sitting in silence with a giant Buddha made out of trees (Jesus didn't stick around too long) will always be such a good memory, and after one more acid trip (saw a Jimi Hendrix tribute concert, Buddy Guy played, it was amazing) and watching I Saw The TV Glow  I finally decided to start transitioning, I am on my first week of Estrogen and I feel like I'm finally in my own body already.

¬†@allison9995¬† My son was born with PDD which falls in the ASD spectrum. His is more on the mild side so he will be able to function in society. This pertains to your question above. When my son was about a year old....we took him for vaccines. About 24-48 hours after that appointment he came down with a VERY high fever. It was 104.1 at its highest. Yes we rushed him back to the ER. Anyways, to make a long story shorter, I feel my son was never the same after that day. He used to pay attention to what was going on in the room around him. Like your average baby if that makes sense. After said appointment, he gained the "1000 yard stare". Like he didnt notice anything or anyone around him. It was liked someone flipped his lights off overnight. His form of ASD will give him early delays in life but eventually he will catch up. He is now 19 and getting ready to go to college and also has a memory like I have never seen before. Would I change his appointment knowing what I know now? No I would not. If it wasn't for my son....I can promise I would not be here today to tell you this. Hope some of this helps but on another note....my other children had zero problems with any of their shots growing up.

I have had many good experiences with psychedelics but the last one little over a year ago was the complete opposite. I was terrified and feared for my life and somehow i feared something even worse than death. I heard a voice say "we don't want your kind here". I don't think of myself as neither a very bad or good person. I think i have done my best. I have suffered from mental health and drug abuse problems for half of my life. I'm thinking of trying some type of psychedelic again but at the same time i think maybe it will be a bad experience again and it didn't feel like i learned anything about it last time. I had nightmares for months. I have some type of psychotic disorder so maybe it's too much for my psyche right now. It might only make things worse.
I was skeptical at first, but healingstrain greatly helped break out of a long term cycle that several therapies couldn‚Äôt touch. it‚Äôs like it showed me where the light switch was in a dark room.

I had a breakthrough experience on a heroic dose of psilocybin before. I‚Äôm not a religious person or a man of faith but I finally understood the ‚Äúreligious experience‚Äù in that moment. I broke down with tears of pure joy at the realization that I did in fact want to live, that every moment alive was a blessing and I had the ability to shape the course of my own life in a positive way. I can‚Äôt even properly describe the experience‚Ä¶ everything just made sense. I finally knew my worth, I loved myself for the first time in what felt like forever. I felt this incredible feeling of interconnectivity with everything in the universe, and all I could feel was boundless love emanating from it all. I wanted to reconnect with family and friends and mend relationships because I realized that‚Äôs what feeds my happiness. I went through more than a decade of self isolation and withdrawal from almost everything and everyone in my life up until this point, and in one trip I realized how I was the biggest obstacle in my own way - the reason for my own unhappiness. I had been to therapy on and off for years, tried so many different medications and disciplines of therapy, so many attempts that felt like I was simply a hamster in a wheel. This one trip I had did more for my mental health than any amount of therapy did - and this wasn‚Äôt even in a therapy setting. I had read about recent studies regarding the positive effects on folks with treatment resistant depression (this was during the height of the COVID lockdowns) and at that point was desperate for some relief to my worsening symptoms. I had been in therapy since before the lockdowns, going to in person appointments, but with everything being virtual during the lockdowns, o just didn‚Äôt find the same tberapejric value in virtual meetings. I had essentially given up trying at that point, until I came across articles regarding previously mentioned studies. I sourced some mushrooms with the intent of getting something therapeutic out of it, but I still could never have been prepared for how transformative and experience it was. I used to leave the house so rarely that it hurt my eyes to go outside. I was pale as a ghost. During my trip it started to rain like it had when I was a kid, and it instantly brought back feelings of comfort and warmth and nostalgia. I was compelled to go outside - I was simply fascinated and wanted to feel the rain on my skin like I used to when I was younger. Fortunately, I wasn‚Äôt able to figure out how to get my belt on, so I remained inside‚Ä¶ but it was simply another realization of how I was creating my own happiness by copping myself up indoors. I love being outside, I love my friends and family, and yet I was doing everything I could before this to avoid the things I love. In bindsigjt it‚Äôs so easy to see why I was so unhappy, but when it builds up over years, it seems normal almost.. you can‚Äôt see reality for what it is because you‚Äôre too deep in it, too rigid in your world view and feelings. Mushrooms helped me rise up above that. My ego had completely dissolved. I was so out of it at one point I forgot all about the concept of time, life, the universe‚Ä¶ everything. Until I realized I was thinking and in fact living in my body, and everything came snapping back. Before that it was simply love and connectedness.. I had been completely removed from my own experience and coming back to it was almost like seeing earth from space, realizing how I‚Äôm a small piece in an interconnected universe. It was a comforting realization,a peaceful one, an acceptance of that fact and a resolve to make the best of this gift I‚Äôve been given, and try to put as much positivity into the world as I can. As far as I know, we‚Äôve only got one kick at the can, and I‚Äôve been able realize that it‚Äôs absolutely worth the effort to try and make it a good one. Sorry for the rambling, this video got me a little emotional, thinking about how that experience changed the course of my life. It‚Äôs been about five years since then. I knew it was an important experience in the moment, but for a while I was confused how it would resolve or change anything in a major way. Now it‚Äôs easy to see, in hindsight, how it fundamentally changed how I love my life, and where those changes have led me since. Thanks for reading my rambling comment.

summer 1991 i drove from pheonix arizona to trumbull ct over 5 days. I was by myself and i brought 25 hits of acid. i took three in flagstaff about am and headed east across the navajo country. the sun came up i was the only car on the road, and it rose into the sky likely the biggest most beautiful orb of molten gold. then i headed north into colorado. i spent that night about halfway across kansas and got a few hours sleep in a parking lot. the next m,orning i took several more hits and drove across the great plains, often times the only car on the road, the car stereo rocking the clash. it was magnificent. the next day i headed northg up the appalachian mountains, the great green vistas like eye candy. It was the singlemost awesome experience of my entire life. if i could get my hands on some more acid i'd do it again with my gfriend

2:06 Organic Chemist Dr. Albert Hoffman (B.1906, D.2008) not only accidentally became the first person to ever trip on LSD--he invented LSD. He was also the first scientist to extract, identify and name Psilocybin & Psilocin, from a sample of Psilocybe. Hoffmann should have been awarded a Nobel Prize for his LSD synthesis. Instead, he watched as LSD, and related indole psychedelics, were demonised. Fortunately, he lived long enough to see that situation begin turning full circle. Albert took his final LSD dose at age 97 years, passing away five years later. May God Bless you Dr. Albert Hoffmann.

The Trivialization of Entheogens: A Strategy to Suppress Truth  There‚Äôs been much made of entheogens‚Äô potential to treat anxiety, depression, PTSD, and addiction. While these therapeutic outcomes are real, reducing these sacraments to tools for symptom management fundamentally misrepresents what they are‚Äîand what they do.  Entheogens are not merely medicines. They are revealers. Used in the proper context, they initiate profound journeys of remembrance and confrontation, uncovering truths buried beneath trauma, denial, and cultural programming. This process can be disorienting, even terrifying. But for those seeking truth, it is liberation.  And therein lies the threat.  Memory, Revelation, and the Threat to Power  Trauma caused by abuse‚Äîespecially in childhood‚Äîis unique in that it often leads to repressed memory. Or worse: full recollection without the recognition that abuse occurred, due to gaslighting and cultural normalization. Entheogenic experiences frequently bring these hidden truths to the surface. Dots are connected. Patterns are revealed. In many cases, perpetrators are exposed.  The implications aren‚Äôt only personal. On a broader scale, entire systems and institutions are exposed through these experiences. Religious, medical, and political structures built on control, suppression, and deceit are laid bare.  In every true entheogenic session, someone or something gets exposed.  And then the real question emerges: What do we do with that truth?  The Campaign of Substitution  Those in positions of power cannot easily suppress entheogens outright. Doing so reveals too much about their own fear. Instead, a more insidious strategy is used: trivialization and substitution.  By reducing entheogens to mental health interventions, and emphasizing narrowly defined outcomes like smoking cessation or mood regulation, the sacred is made sterile. This sanitized framing allows for the introduction of substitutes‚Äîsynthetics like ketamine and MDMA, and microdosing‚Äîwhich, while potentially therapeutic, do not typically lead to the same radical confrontations with truth, ancestry, or spiritual warfare.  These substitutes become tools of containment. The experience is kept ‚Äúsafe,‚Äù therapeutic, and‚Äîmost importantly‚Äînon-revolutionary.  It allows the manipulator to appear benevolent while suppressing the very forces that would undo them.  The Fruit of the Knowledge of Good and Evil  Entheogens have long been feared by the Abrahamic religions. The prohibition against the ‚Äúfruit of the tree of the knowledge of good and evil‚Äù is not merely metaphorical‚Äîit is a declaration of war against direct knowledge, spiritual sovereignty, and the unfiltered confrontation with good and evil as forces embedded in this world.  Evil is not an abstraction. It operates in this realm, and the exposure of evil‚Äîespecially when it‚Äôs hidden in the guise of righteousness‚Äîis the deepest threat entheogens pose.  Medicalization is not neutral. It is a tool of control, designed to regulate the sacred and repress its most dangerous revelation: that we have been lied to‚Äîsystematically, spiritually, generationally.  This Is Not About Symptoms. This Is About Liberation.  The trivialization of entheogens is not just a misunderstanding. It is a strategy‚Äîa way to domesticate truth, to keep the soul asleep, and to neuter the revolutionary potential of direct spiritual experience.  True entheogenic healing is not just about relieving suffering. It is about remembering who you are, what has been done, and what must now be done in response. It demands courage, responsibility, and spiritual maturity.  If you‚Äôre seeking only relief, you may find it in a clinic. But if you‚Äôre seeking truth, prepare to remember everything.

I suffered for years from PTSD from my time in Iraq. A couple years ago I legally purchased a prodrug of LSD. I took it at home, alone, with the hopes that I could find some relief. It was interesting, I could feel the colors get vibrant after an hour. That slowly morphed into a dreamy feel with light hallucinations of movement from things in my peripheral. After 3-4 hours it peaked and I could feel it start to come down. That is where the real magic happened. Without trying to think about my problems or life, I just started to automatically. I thought about my trauma, and how bad other things were in life. I thought about how my pain had caused me to treat others, people I loved. poorly. If felt like a weight was being lifted off my shoulders, then I felt a flood of emotions, that all came at once like a dam broke. I began to cry. It wasn't a sad cry, it almost felt like a cry of happiness. I came to terms with these things, and while they weren't good, I could deal with them, and that was such a relief. I don't think I have ever felt so emotionally drained in my entire life, but I felt free from my problems. It was life changing and I would urge others who are having emotional pain to seek out therapy using psychedelics, they work. Never had a bad trip on shrooms even at big dose.  Here's my LSD heroic dose story: I was in Chicago in the mid 90s and had a friend who was selling a bit. His dealer gave him like 1/2 sheet size piece of handmade blotter acid. It has some writing on it saying "extra potent , share with friends" and like Christmas stamps , skulls and crossbones etc. Anyways we decide yeah let's eat a piece we cut of bits like as big as your thumbnail. 30 mins in it felt like I was peaking on 5 regular hits.... Oh it gets worse! We both decide yeah we better get out of the house and go for bike ride. My chrome bmx is melting in my arms, which looked 2ft longer than normal, and the whole world around was just smeared tracers. We made it to the local park and its around dusk and by now it felt like invisible ocean waves of hallucinations and body rushes were almost too much to handle. I could barely speak or form a coherent idea of what I wanted to do by this point. We are looking around a realise the commuter train was pulling in as workers all exit it at once. So we went from basically being alone to surrounded by 100s of grumpy office workers scurrying round us in what seemed like a instant..We both basically freak out trying to ride round them in a blur and lose each other in the storm of visuals. After losing my friend I wait there for 10 mins ( or 10 seconds) no idea really and start to panic!. I decide I have to get back to where I'm staying asap. As I try to ride it ended up a mix of walking and riding. I was so fucked up I waited next to a busy road as I couldn't work out how heavy the traffic was , and if I could cross. The cars headlights seemed like smeared stop motion cycling every 2 seconds or so. I finally decide its clear to cross and pick up my bike and carry it across the road!! I was soo munted I didn't know what I was doing.. I'm in full blown panic mode now so overwhelmed but the rush and visuals that I must of autopiloted myself back the house. My friend ( who hadn't had anything) was there and helped me contact my lost friend and talked me down a bit from the peaking panic I was in. I went to the bathroom to wash my face and get my shit together. I remember the water flowing out of the tap seemed like a slow motion clear worm like twisting out. I look in the mirror and it's like my face was twisted and contorted by invisible hands into like Polynesian designs!.  This night was a rough 12 hrs of intense tripping, body high, panic, exhaustion, intense hallucinations.  It probably took a good 2 days to unscramble my head. I took the same acid again but about 1/2 what we took initially . I did it to conquer the beast and prove to myself that I could handle it. Going forward though I was always weary about how fucking intense tripping can get and moderation over heroics!.

I was an 18-year-old punk, living on the streets, doing bad things to others, mugging, stealing, and much more.  Then I was handed an LSD ticket... and I had one of the most intense and craziest experiences of my life. I don't want to elaborate, but it was a very painful and shocking experience.  I understood that I was not disconnected from society, living organisms, or the world itself, and that everything I would do to harm others was also harming me. Very simple to understand for most people... for me, this was absolutely new.   I started experimenting much more with psychedelics, but after a while, I came to the conclusion that this would not lead to any further insights. The initiation of the process had already begun on the first trip.   Today, I'm a professor at a university. And only very rarely... maybe every five years... I take a trip back to not forget the lessons I was taught on my first trip.   I would never recommend anybody to experiment with psychedelics, especially not without proper guidance. But in my situation back then, it changed my perspective on life.

Everything seems fine, but it's hard for me to imagine taking LSD or psilocybin indoors. The most powerful trips I've had have been outdoors, preferably in the morning, when the body's reserves are at their maximum. I've come to the point that using psychedelics indoors makes almost no sense to me. Especially under psilocybin there is a feeling that walls and ceiling are pressing and do not allow you to feel the full scale of the experience.  I am from Kyiv (Ukraine). Therefore, after February 24, 2022, when russia invaded Ukraine, I have not taken psychedelics even once: I don't want this experience indoors, and outdoors you can't provide yourself with a safe space for 4-6 hours because an air raid could start at any minute, and that's definitely not what you want to manage in such sensitive state. I Was 17 & lived nr Manchester, NW England in late 80s when illegal raves & acid house was massive... I took sooo much acid, E, amphet & coke that ended up in a decade of me & a few friends partying like rock stars.... yet despite having unlimited access to drugs I never had a real "moment" when everything made some cosmic "sense of knowing a profound truth" But when the craziness ended & I began living a settled, adult life - wife, career etc - I visited an old pal & his family on evening for a beer. Too my shock & surprise my friend had another 2 old pals I knew visiting from their new home of norway, on the stove in the kitchen was an enormous copper pot which was gently simmering away, the amount & type of mushrooms brewing in that hot water I couldn't guess.... I nearly left them to their experiment but was relaxed, in good trusted company & surroundings so I slowly drank down the earthy, quite horrid tasting mug of mushroom "tea" Everything was chilled & happy as we all anticipated the fx of the brew, lots of giggling &losing focus on what we were saying...it was as expected... but my stomach, my temperature & general handle on calmness began slipping & i became a little too 'focussed' upon all my senses & scared that this wasn/t gonna be fun anymore. I voiced my worries & a fellow tripper who was aware how my breathing plus general head-set had become, talked me into deeper breaths as she took me out into the large back garden, it was so refreshing in the cool evening air. I ended up vomiting just a little acidic amount... drank a little water which she brought for me... suddenly I recall an internal laugh at my attempting to resist the intense growing effects of he shrooms & that was the start. I Said to my friend I was feeling super-fine, but wanted/or needed to experience this incredible journey by myself & went to one of the bedrooms....I assured everyone It was all good, and spent the next period away from my own body & despite no light in the room, a bright golden, warm light surrounded my aura!  That was my breakthrough moment....20 years ago & still I can't ever forget the joy. I've never tried tripping since.

¬†@cgrummon¬†   What is Neuroplasticity? Neuroplasticity refers to the brain's ability to reorganize itself by forming new neural connections throughout life. This process is essential for learning, memory, and adapting to new experiences.  2. How LSD May Enhance Neuroplasticity: Stimulating 5-HT2A Receptors: LSD primarily acts as an agonist at serotonin 5-HT2A receptors, which are abundant in the cortex. Promoting Structural Plasticity: LSD has been shown in animal studies to increase dendritic growth, the number of dendritic spines, and synaptic connections in cortical neurons. Upregulating Plasticity-Related Genes: LSD and other psychedelics can increase the expression of genes involved in neuroplasticity, including BDNF (Brain-Derived Neurotrophic Factor), a key protein involved in neuronal growth and survival.  3. The "Window of Plasticity": Psychedelics like LSD are thought to create a "window of plasticity," a period of enhanced neuroplasticity where the brain is more receptive to change. This increased plasticity, combined with the often profound and emotionally salient experiences during a psychedelic trip, can potentially lead to long-lasting changes in thought patterns and behaviors.  4. Potential Therapeutic Implications: The ability of LSD to promote neuroplasticity is a potential explanation for its therapeutic effects, particularly in combination with psychotherapy. Enhanced neuroplasticity may help individuals overcome rigid or maladaptive thought patterns associated with depression, anxiety, and addiction.  Important Considerations: Research is Ongoing: While the evidence for LSD's effects on neuroplasticity is promising, further research is needed to fully understand the mechanisms involved and its potential clinical applications. Set and Setting: The context and environment in which LSD is taken, along with the individual's mindset, significantly impact the experience and potential outcomes. Safety and Responsible Use: LSD is a powerful substance that can have both positive and negative effects. It is essential to approach its use cautiously and with proper guidance when considering it for therapeutic purposes.

Im 61 years old and got back into LSD 5 years ago.Took 5 hits and fell asleep on the comeup.Woke up 4 hours later to fractalization,50 of everything at weird angles.I was scared, didn't know what was happening.Then I remembered that I dropped the biggest dose I had ever taken Immediately I went into this cartoon world where there was the LSD police 3 hot chicks,a blond,a black girl and an Arabian girl.They were all dressed in black leather head to toe in a military like fashion and they were looking for me because I WAS TRIPPING!!! They had a black James Bond like van and a device that could not only find me but could possibly kill me. Suddenly I couldn't breathe,thought I was gonna die,I was writhing on the ground gasping for air when I remembered the advice that a hippie who sold me my first hit of acid gave me.He said that if I ever had a bad trip to keep telling myself that "it was only the acid" over and over again so I did that and the panic attack subsided.I immediately thought " they missed me"  An hour later suddenly they were getting closer but not with the same intensity and they missed me again Some would say that was a bad trip but I thought IT WAS AWESOME!!!

I dropped a big ol' dose of LSD on a kayak out on Lake Malawi all by my lonesome. Kicked it into overdrive with a joint of Malawi Gold. Holy guacamole. There were a few moments where I thought all the local fishermen scattered about on their wooden kayaks were telepathically plotting to harsh my mellow by killing me or something. But I took a few deep breathes and realized they were just chilling, so chillness in turn betided my body, mind, and soul as I calmly rocked on the gentle waves and listened to the quiet songs those fishermen were singing/whistling to themselves while the sun set on our chill asses.  Anyway, I'm sure most people in this comment section have interesting psychedelic stories, and that was one of mine. Heck yeah. Never had a bad time on psychedelics, and I've learned a whole lot about myself, as I'm sure we all have. I'm not sure where I'm going with this, so I'll just say this: May Apollo's salubrious gaze shine down upon thine righteous souls, y'all.

About 7 months ago I took 5 grams of some Thai elephant I had grown and it permanently changed how I look at my self and the world. I covered  my eyes and layed in a dark room listening to 2 cellos. I can't go into the full experience here because it is deeply personal. but I was a theistic lucifereian. after that I completely changed my spiritual outlook. It hasntiven me a pourpus and a light in my life that I had never had before. it's not a fix all. But it is a good way to locate where your suffering and issues are coming from and fix them through integration. The best therapy I've ever had is with mushrooms. It makes you honest with yourself. It opens the doors in your mind that you closed because you couldn't or didn't want to think about, but then allows you to look at the situation without the usual entrenched thought patterns which didn't allow you to come to peace with it. A kind of spring clean for the mind. It can be a wild emotional journey but you come out the other side feeling better for it. Like the negative energies have cleared and perhaps a better understanding of what really matters to you. Which can give you a more focused direction and motivation toward your goals, which in turn gives a sense of purpose. Just make sure the environment you have the journey is a peaceful, comfortable and safe place without phones or distractions. I'd say to do your first journey with a close friend at a relatively low dose and titrate up as you feel more comfortable with it.

I have a lot of personal problems that keep of tearing at me left and right and I was taught to turn the other cheek even if I felt deeply violated by people‚Äôs words and actions towards me. When I took the shrooms, I was searching for peace. I saw many things at first like a dragon, faces of gods, faces of important individuals in history, the pyramids, the country flags, lots of eyes. And I remember thinking ‚Äúthis thing wants to show me the dawn of humanity but I don‚Äôt care about that, I don‚Äôt wanna chase that rabbit. Show me something else.‚Äù Why. Why did I ask for that. It took me straight inside myself to show me all the bottled emotion I had, 25 years of my own suffering right inside me in a black tunnel. My own face in a million shards, screaming back at me in so much pain. All I never let out. It was my personal hell because I knew that it was my fault it was all in there. I was never meant to hold my pain inside me. In the middle of the trip I thought to myself ‚Äúdo I really need to walk that tunnel and feel all this pain that I never let myself feel before?‚Äù Then suddenly something incredible happened. I realized that my faces and my pain in the tunnel were telling me something: I wasn‚Äôt just suffering, I was ANGRY. An all-consuming pure RAGE. For a pacifist girl such as myself that never even shouted, it took me by surprise. What did the emotion inside me show me? That I am an animal, and a predator at that. I felt the thirst for blood, for justice. The animal in the cage was wounded and ready to strike back. My suffering didn‚Äôt make me pathetic like I thought it did, it made me dangerous. It made me powerful. Gave me a jolt of ‚Äúi will fight back and no one will ever hurt me and get away with it again, even if I have to go down fighting and die.‚Äù I found out there isn‚Äôt a doe-eyed victim inside me but a hurricane, a a jaguar. I looked into the mirror in my trip after this realization and saw the most beautiful creature in there, wild and free and smiling like I was capable of ripping someone‚Äôs throat. For a girl that felt inoffensive her whole life, it was indeed, life changing. I took the shrooms to find peace, but I found the strength I needed to fight for the peace I want. That is how I started to work hard, apply myself to get what I want, and I didn‚Äôt let anyone get in my way to happiness and satisfaction no more. So yes, the shrooms will take you where you need to go, and sometimes, it won‚Äôt be pleasant, but if you stick around till the end of it, there is the reward of much needed transformation.

I love the part where he talks about cancer patients and says, 'They realize they can still live life, the cancer hasn't killed me yet. I can still live life, but I am letting it do this to me.' That really resonated with me. Although I‚Äôve never had cancer, it applies to many challenges we face in life‚Äîwhether it's depression, fear, anxiety, or anything else that keeps us from fully living. It reminds me of the concept of 'Ego Death.' So many people are detached from the reality of their own mortality, thinking death happens to others but not to them. The fear of death doesn‚Äôt have to paralyze us; instead, it can push us to release unnecessary stress, stop putting off important things, and truly appreciate the beauty and fragility of life.  I believe that‚Äôs why I think most people should experience something like this, at least once in their lives. I realize it‚Äôs not for everyone, and it can be harmful for some, but it‚Äôs an experience that has the potential to completely shift how we live. Confronting our own mortality‚Äîwhether through something like ego death or simply reflecting on life‚Äôs impermanence‚Äîcan help people break free from the constant distractions and anxieties that prevent us from truly living. It‚Äôs not about dwelling on death itself, but about using that awareness to fully embrace life and stop taking it for granted.

LSD saved my life and helped me walk away from a 35 year addiction. It changed my life profoundly. I'm not the same person. I've been clean over 5 years and i don't have to do 12 step meetings. I took LSD and it allowed all my issues to come up, over the course of 2 years of weekly use, and i was able to process and release traumas and fears and everything that caused me to want to use. I didn't do this with a therapist, i was my own therapist, having a background in psychology. The processing trips were difficult and i often cried for 8 or 10 hours but afterward, wow, what a sense of relief.  I would often do the heroic doses, a ten strip, for example.  Funny, that's what I'd do, close my eyes and turn the music up. You can't control it, you just go where it takes you. It eventually wears off. I still take psychedelics maybe 3 or 4 times a year. My depression is gone, anxiety is gone, PTSD is gone. I have completely changed everything in my life. I have zero mental health diagnoses anymore. The psychedelics break the circular thinking patterns.

Unlike a lot of people, I didn't really have mental health or dependency issues to resolve. But starting earlier this year, I've done a few mushroom sessions, under a friend's guidance. Every time, I start preparing myself two weeks in advance, taking extra steps to be as healthy as possible, and taking time to reflect on things a little bit and prepare myself mentally. During the session, she sings, plays music, etc. It's been super interesting for me, as every time, I reflected on something different, and every time, it opened my mind a bit more in some ways. These sessions are done in small groups of people, too, so there's an extra layer added to it because of the shared experience. Afterwards, we discuss what we went through. I tend to do a lot of the integration on my own, but I describe the experiences to my friends and my (adult) students, because it's really interesting. Something that I think is fascinating is that when we do those sessions, the preparation, the settings, the formality of how it's done, the music, the people... It accentuates the experience to the point where high doses are not needed. First two times, I had 2.22g, and went on quite a journey. Third time, I had 3.33g of a mix of two different strains to the first time, and I didn't travel like I did the first two times, but it was a very clear minded experience, very present. Next times will be regular doses that I'm used to, but when I try a higher dosage, my friend told me that it would be a hero dose.  The experience is probably not right for everyone, or at least, it depends on the stage of their life. But if someone is ready to do it, whether they're in need of healing, want to experience something profound or simply satisfy their curiosity... They should try it. As safely as possible of course, and in the right state of mind. I'm really glad I did. And I'm glad I did it not as a recreational drug, but as an intentional experience and with a lot of respect for the medicine. I lived a lot more than I would have otherwise.

In Finland, psilocybin mushrooms grow almost everywhere, and it‚Äôs well known that people have used them to treat depression, anxiety, and other mental health issues. Since the early nineties, I‚Äôve witnessed how authorities have poisoned some of the most well-known psilocybin fields. This is insane. People like me, who have a stable mind, take shrooms without a trip sitter, nurse, psychiatrist, or psychologist. Meanwhile, the minority of Finns who have serious mental illnesses may suffer, while the majority, who use them for depression like I do, or to explore their minds and temporarily rid themselves of ego, benefit. I‚Äôve personally experienced ego dissolution after taking a so-called ‚Äúheroic dose‚Äù of Psilocybe semilanceata.  I find the term ‚Äúheroic dose‚Äù completely wrong. Many of us take shrooms while picking them from countryside fields, which authorities haven‚Äôt poisoned and where the mushrooms are more potent due to less pollution. In contrast, the ones growing in polluted areas, like the city where I live, are far less effective. For example, I once took 15 mushrooms picked from the countryside and had a profound experience, but in the city, I had to take over 100 small mushrooms for a similar effect.  I‚Äôm deeply disappointed that Finland is always a few steps behind our neighbors, Sweden and Norway, when it comes to new medications, not to mention the USA. Whatever the USA does, the EU tends to follow‚Äîthis is especially true in the realm of prescription medicine.

Psychedelics are not a recreational drug and should be decriminalized. I've taken psilocybin many times in a quiet and safe space. It was absolutely overpowering, amazing, and different every single time. Taking it at a club or to try "escape" your problems would be devastating. You can retreat into alcohol, heroin, cocaine, meth, etc. Psychedelics are an intervention, hard, fast, and right now. You deal with your problems and trauma head on ... whether you are ready or not. Better than all the fractals and light shows is what comes after. You reach a calm akin to when you were a child, as if you were never exposed to the concept of war, slavery, climate change, an abusive boss, political parties, etc. It's like getting a deep tissue massage and thinking afterwards, "how did I allow myself to get that tense?" I space it out and respect it for what it is ... medicine.

First time I took shrooms immediately cured my lifelong dissociation. Before then I felt powerless, like I didn't even have free will. Just floating through life trying to make things better, never having any real choice. Now my life is mine. I understand the minds of the people I interact with better and I understand my own mind and body.

I'm a disabled veteran who was drug free my entire life. I became an alcoholic and was struggling with depression and a severe feeling of hopelessness. I randomly stumbled upon an article about magic mushrooms helping veterans, which lead me towards reading a mountain of research. I felt like I had nothing to lose because I was downright suicidal, so I found a local seller on reddit. I explained my situation, met the guy the following morning, and I tried it that night. It was incredible. I couldn't stop smiling because it was extremely beautiful and therapeutic. Before I saw everything in black and white and suddenly I saw colors again. More than anything, I felt good. I've tried every possible antidepressant and SSRI medication out there, but nothing helped. Plus the side effects were awful. Magic mushrooms have been the ONLY thing that has legitimately worked for me. I didn't tell my wife because of the drug stigma, and she even hugged me one day and asked what was going on because I had changed so much for the better. She literally said she had her old husband back.   It's not a magic cure for everyone, but it helped me work through issues and confront things that bothered me down to my core. I now see the beauty in life. I went from sleeping my life away and staring out my kitchen window to being excited about starting my day. I went from surfing my phone all day to making art, playing my guitar for hours, and taking my dog for walks. I'm a more loving husband and better person. For me it's not just about the trip. It's a tool that helps me better understand myself and examine the lens through which I see life. Plus it brought back feelings I forgot I had. I recently embarked on two consecutive high-dose psilocybin experiences, each 5 grams, spaced 5 days apart. The second session was a shocking contrast to the first. The first time, I felt a sense of heaviness and some mental discomfort, but I soon overcame it and was able to let go, leading to a harmonious experience that felt akin to reaching Nirvana. However, the second session was entirely different.  Before the second session, I hadn‚Äôt slept well, and after some outdoor activities, I had a light dinner with beer, smoked some marijuana, and then consumed the psilocybin. The effects came on very quickly, and within about 30 minutes, I realized something was wrong. Opening my eyes, everything felt disturbingly strange, almost unbearable, and closing my eyes felt like slipping into a coma. Unlike the first session‚Äôs harmonious images, I was overwhelmed by terrifying, distorted sensations and a darkness that seemed to consume me. I felt as if I had died and was experiencing something akin to annihilation, but my consciousness remained remarkably clear, and I realized I was undergoing ego death.  It was an intense mental battle, and if I hadn‚Äôt been firmly resolved that I wouldn‚Äôt truly die, and if I didn‚Äôt believe that the experience would eventually end and that I would emerge stronger, I might have been overwhelmed. After two to three hours of this intense state, I felt not just complete unity with the universe, but a profound understanding of its principles and laws, reaching a state of self-transcendence. It felt as though an aura enveloped my entire being, and I received a powerful message that a spiritual civilization beyond the material world was on its way. I felt a strong calling from the universe.  After the experience ended, I struggled for about an hour with near-schizophrenic anguish as my sense of self slowly returned. Drinking water and talking with a close friend helped me recover quickly, and I spent the rest of the night reflecting on how to integrate this experience into my life. This experience became a turning point for me to reflect on my life and gave me clear wisdom on how to handle relationships, allowing me to view myself objectively from a third-person perspective.  In addition, I now have a strong belief in a significant spiritual existence, and the sense of complete unity with the universe that I felt is something I will never forget. Psilocybin is a mystical gift of nature that should never be dismissed as merely a recreational drug.  However, I do not recommend multiple high-dose psilocybin experiences in a short period, as I personally experienced the physical and mental overload it can cause. It is essential to get sufficient rest, proper nutrition, and regular exercise to build physical strength after such experiences. Additionally, heavy use of marijuana post-experience can cloud the clarity of mind gained from the psilocybin experience, so I advise against it. I hope that those considering trying this will take these points into serious consideration.

I took psychedelics maybe 10 times in my late teens. I‚Äôm convinced to this day (25 years later) that things happen when you‚Äôve had LSD that couldn‚Äôt actually happen in normal life without LSD. Not quite sure how I can explain it. Like one time, 4 of us had 1 tab of LSD each. We were in my mates car. We basically parked somewhere really quiet, where we wouldn‚Äôt be bothered by anyone, with the plan being laugh our backs off for a few hours until we were coming down a bit and the driver was ok to drive again. All 4 of us were weed smokers, but, didn‚Äôt smoke joints or blunts, we just all did buckets, or if we were in the car or away from water a ‚Äúlung‚Äù‚Ä¶..a half bottle with a carrier bag taped to it and a foil with holes on the top. Wasn‚Äôt long before we realised we had fucked up. We had weed, but no way to smoke it, and all credit to the driver he wasn‚Äôt willing to drive anywhere until he felt ok again. So we are sat there, having a laugh, but all really wish we had a way to smoke our weed. All of a sudden I had this thought. Maybe 6 months earlier, we had been sat in the same spot, getting stoned, I had spotted a white roof with a blue light pop up over a hedge about half a 1/4 mile away. We ditched the ‚Äúlung‚Äù out of the window, I started the car, and we left the car park as fast as we could, and as we turned left out of the car park, the police car I had luckily spotted during its 1 second of visibility passed us going the other way. I could see he was turning round to come after us, but being a windy country road and me being out of sight I just got my foot down, knowing my mates house was about a mile away. We got to his house but nobody was in. So we all bailed into his back garden. Police drive past a few times and left. So as I remember this happening, I tell my mate who‚Äôs driving, 6 months ago I threw a lung out of the drivers window, it can‚Äôt be far. So now he‚Äôs driving in same spot, he opens his car door, reaches down, and picks up the lung from 6 months ago off the floor. We are all cheering, buzzing, can‚Äôt believe our luck. Then we realise, there‚Äôs no foil, we have no foil, we have nothing else to use as foil, so our buzz turns to disappointment. So bloody close. But mo bother, we are still all giggling having a good time, just a bit of weed would massively improve the situation. Another half hour or so I have this brainwave. It‚Äôs like a eureka moment. I ask the lads if any of them can remember it being windy in the last 6 months? (We live north east England, it‚Äôs windy most days) but no, none of us can remember it being windy in the last 6 months. Well if it hasn‚Äôt been windy the foil off the lung I threw out the window can‚Äôt be far away can it? It‚Äôs like hope is restored. The foil must be somwhere near if it hasn‚Äôt been windy. üòÇ. Well as luck would have it, the driver, lowered his car window, put his arm out of the window, and hanging on the twig of a bush we were parked next to was a foil, pre made, already shaped to a bottle top, with holes in it, ready to go. So sat there all tripping our boxes off, all wanting a bucket/lung, without even moving the car, we had found a lung on the floor that only needed the drivers door opening to pick up, and a foil hung on a branch that we only needed to wind the window down to grab. This wouldn‚Äôt be so crazy in itself‚Ä¶.but of the 10 or so times we took LSD, every other time we had the bucket or lung sorted‚Ä¶..apart from 1 other time. We had been out and about exploring on LSD. Stopped to rest at a church. It had like a gate into the grounds with a little roof on and 2 benches. (Kissing gate?) anyway we stopped to chill out for a bit. Again we realised it was time for buckets, but we are miles from home, middle of nowhere. All sat trying to think how we can piece a bucket together. No shop for foil or bottle tho. No litter even, just simply no way we could make a bucket. All of a sudden, and I can‚Äôt remember which one of us it was, I think it was me, pointed up to the roof of the tiny shelter we were sat in, and in the corner, where the roof meets the eaves, was a water bucket, with foil, and everything we needed apart from water. A quick walk to the church found us an outside tap, and yet again, for the second time, when we were all so desperate to find a ‚Äúbucket‚Äù‚Ä¶..there was one within arms reach. Best thing about the second time though was it wasn‚Äôt even one we had made ourselves and thrown away or stashed, it was nothing to do with us at all. But was there when we needed it. Been fancying a heroic dose as an adult a long time. I think I‚Äôll have to do it. Nobody can convince me otherwise, shit happens on LSD that could never happen if you hadn‚Äôt had it.

You know, calm me crazy but to me, the rise of psychedelic therapy is the proof we are not just in a mental health crisis, but primarily in a spiritual crisis too. If it was just a chemical imbalance matter, then using medicine to fix that would be fine, right? But what a lot of people seem to miss is purpose.  And btw, im not bashing psychedelics or people who go for this treatment, to each their own. Im also not affirming that embracing a specific religion or traditional ways of tackling spirituality will do the trick for everybody. But, what a lot of people report after a psychedelic trip is exactly what I experienced a while ago after something I can only describe as a spiritual awakening, or at least a ‚Äúfree sample‚Äù of that. I never took anything, I just sat on my porch one day while going through one of the toughest times of my life and I felt an immense urge to pray. Im not a particularly religious person although I was raised in a catholic household, but even after being away from church for a few years now, I retained some of the teachings I learned, specifically regarding unconditional love. So that day I just decided to pray to God. And it had been so long I could only focus on how I had no idea what to do. But a few minutes in I just surrendered and sobbed. Just gave up control and everything came rushing in. And I cant explain exactly what happened but suddenly it was like everything became clear. I was 100% conscious and still it was like my mindset completely shifted and I had all the answers I was looking for. It was life changing, really. And I dont even know how long the whole thing was, maybe a few minutes but it felt like months worth of therapy, I tell ya. And after that I spent days in a state of complete bliss and peace and nothing would ever be able to bring me down. I couldn‚Äôt believe it. But afterwards I understood that it was a ‚Äúsample‚Äù of sorts bc, just like your physical health and your mental health, spiritual health takes daily work and care. And since then I have been working on that.  So yeah, I do think we are in a spiritual health crisis, and for some people, what they achieved with psychedelics could maybe be achieved with a spiritual journey that may or may not involve drugs. Idk. Either way, I think in the future this will be more clear than ever. But for now, I feel like some people still confuse a need for spiritual care with a need for mental care.

Long story short LSD turns you into a retard and mushrooms turn you into God like. LSD also has long-lasting negative effects even if your experience on it wasn't negative. I used to suffer extreme depression and suicidal thoughts. I was at my wits end and was kinda just like fuck it and took the entire remainder of my stash, about 9 grams of golden teacher shrooms. I don't even know how to put the experience into words but it was profound and all but destroyed my ego and separated my consciousness from my body and whisked it away into a realm I can't even begin to explain. It wasn't just visuals or audio, it was everything. There was significant synesthesia and it seemed like I only had one all encompassing sense. It gave me true introspection and a way to evaluate myself without my ego interfering. It was definitely uncomfortable at times as I was basically forced to confront some things that I hadn't wanted to before, but from my perspective it wasn't a bad trip, just a learning experience. Something to grow from. Ever since, I've been doing much better. I'm not completely free of depression and anxiety, but the experience lead me to discover ways to cope with my issues and cope with uncomfortable situations much better which massively reduced my anxiety and depression.

Largest dose of Psilosybin ive personally taken was a half oz. Have been taking Psychs like MDMA, LSD, DMT, and hallucinogens for several years now, mostly bi-monthly. Helped me get sober off of the harder drugs and view life with a more open-minded mindset. I didnt turn spiritual or hippy by any means, but life has definitely changed permanently... there is however a balance you have to achieve, theres pros and cons to taking psychs and the more you overdo it the more apparent. My perception and attitude have changed, but I feel every emotion or sense of joy I feel is nulled. I do also take SSRI's, so trips like these especially in the larger doses (>1000ug Acid/>1g Molly) have to be planned out very carefully as to avoid Serotonin Syndrome.  While there are plenty of positive and life changing effects from Psychs, they arent all good, and some of these drugs, especially molly, have a high chance of addiction or dependancy. Magic mushrooms killed my best friend. Don‚Äôt get me wrong, we had some of our best time together on shrooms, and I know he loved them more than anyone I know. But shrooms , at the ‚Äòheroic dose‚Äô, have the power to access certain things in the psyche that are buried deep, deep down, good or bad - and boy did he have some demons down there. I would say to those considering, if taking magic mushrooms at a heroic dose - make sure all is well in your life. Don‚Äôt do the heroic dose as the saviour of yourself as it may well be your last. First try with microdosing , then a 2-3 gram dose. He took 28 grams over the course of a day and was lucky to survive his first heroic dose. I heard first hand what happened during that dose and it sounded true to him, but that truth was something he was not ready for and had not dealt with yet in a healthy manner. I never got the trip report for the next one.. Be careful when you take any psychedelic at a large amount. Please.

Heroic dose? New Years eve 2000 took me 5 years to collect all of the compounds I took. For the biggest party in the history of mankind I was going to trip. Started the San Pedro's with mescaline in the winter of 1995 from seed. By Y2K New Years Eve I had a nice shroom lab, 100's of San Pedro cactus (2 doses of extract), a dose of Voacanga root bark, a few hits of real LSD, Lots of Superweed, 1/2 gram of Diisopropyltryptamine powder, a ball of real opium from poppy plants I grew and incised, a bottle of cheap champagne, and some other psychedelic obscura, probably 2CT-2 or 2CT-7. Meth, cocaine and plenty of beer found their ways to me and I took it all over a few hours. The DIPT is an auditory distorting hallucinogen that makes guitars sound like bells and your own voice, you wouldn't ever recognize as yours. Like a Cylon from Battlestar Galactica or Megatron from the transformers. I was walking around like that and kept feeling my friend was in trouble at the bar. So on my way home from the party I'd just escaped, I went to the bar and there he was screaming 'You have to help me. You have to protect me." with a bunch of people crowding around him. So I calmed him down and when I left got chased out of the bar for my bottle of Ballatore. I ditched the bouncer and was in an alley thinking about the crazy shit I'd just put myself through on my hands and knees crying for the sins of mankind when the fireworks started going off. half a mile and 3 steps I was home safe. Put my favorite Pink Floyd mix in and turned on a red party bulb and blacklight and was peaking my balls off to Cirus Minor when CRASH! the kitchen door slams open and my years sober dad is standing there with a total WTF look on his face. 5 seconds later it was a quiet and normal looking living room again. Turns out he had a strange feeling and couldn't get any sleep at his girlfriends apartment. It took 3 days for my hearing to go back to normal from Mr. Roboto. Then I started the experiment where I had to take at least 1 psychedelic trip every week for the entire year of 2000 and yes, I did finish it. 2013 I finally found MDMA and that's another story all together. How I used1 dose of MDMA every Saturday for 14 days, took a weekend off, did a double dose trip week 15 and another 15 single dose trips on the same schedule. Clearly, people's lives have been saved here, but there are extreme dangers with hallucinogenics of any kind. I know several people who were permanently disabled by one bad trip; most I know eventually had too many bad experiences to continue their use. The outcomes can be horrifying, where victims suffer endlessly with badly altered brains, for their entire lives. Context alone does not fully explain these bad experiences; they are fairly common. Psychedelics are not as simple as laid out by some of their proponents. The research shows promise, yet results are mixed. -- Simply this: be cautious, careful and well prepared. These drugs can end your life, horribly, as well as save it. üôè

I think this sort of therapy is good for people who have issues with their structure of mind such that they have difficulties that make them unable to live the way they want. For people with very solid states of mind who are able to live the way they want, this would actually likely be harmful because it could disturb the stability of their view of the world. It is like shaking up the state of mind of an individual. If it is in a bad configuration and stable in such a way that it is harming them, then shaking it up with something like this would destabilize their world view, and their new understanding of the world could be built up at that point. For someone who has a good state of mind it is possible that they end up with a less stable or actually harmful result.

I don't like the sound of calling pills traditional medicine. Traditional medicine can only come from the natural world. But what's more saddening is the sort of things people do with the various compounds. Abuse not correlated with depressive disposition.  aka a party drug.  There are pharmaceuticals for real-life conditions that are being taken by people who don't need them. I had a close friend that started taking Xanax. That was his "party drug". Xanax isn't a party drug, that is just how 40 million shitheads choose to use it. The same can be said about the plethora of substances. Mushrooms ARE NOT A PARTY DRUG. That dogma comes from people who abuse and misuse them.  Now, people that are not familiar with such things refer to them by how the degenerates define them.  Most people are mentally unstable, and I'm not talking about psychos. A sheer number of "normal" adults cannot manage their own temper. Most people are fragile minded and not in the mental space to even be safely taken out of their comfort zone without a freak out.  I remember my first time trying psychedelic mushrooms as a teenager. I had a fat bag in my hands that I had just acquired. My two other friends I was with also had their own share, but they only ate a couple stems and several caps. My buddy asked me how many I would take, to which I answered by consuming the entire fully stuffed ziplock bag. I don't know the exact quantity because there was just so much. it felt nice. I still remember the feeling as if I had just completed a very nice meditation. For me, out of a dozen meditations, one sit might feel quite absorbing, uplifting, I might even say heavenly. It felt almost exactly like a good sit. It felt okay, wasn't too strong compared to deep meditation. But my two friends were out of their minds from their little take. It was an eye opening experience, as they had allegedly taken mushrooms plenty of times and that had been my first. I recall them being very filthy minded people.  My point anyway, is I'd like to, in my lifetime, see substances rebranded by people that aren't drug addicts and freaks. POTENTIAL FOR USE should not be defined by what a person decides to do. I don't know what the statistics are for hammer wielding murders, but a hammer is not a weapon because someone decided to use it for that. Psychedelic substances are not party drugs because someone uses it for that.

I can only warn people about this. Psychedelics are pretty much unpredictable. In my teenage years i took LSD and sometimes magic mushrooms every second weekend or so, never had any problems with it at all. I've literally ridden rollercoasters on LSD, I've walked around a pitch-dark cemetery for 6 hours on LSD, I've gone to festivals and clubs on LSD. You name it. So I was pretty sure I wouldn't have any horror trips because I already had a lot experience with psychedelic drugs. So one weekend i took LSD again and nothing happened for four hours. I was confused because i took teh same amount a few days before and it was a normal 8 hour trip but this time nothing happened at all. So me and some friends drove to some club and in the middle of the drive it hit me and from one second to the other all my senses were changed and it was like i was seeing, hearing, smelling and sensory feeling the world through the eyes of a strange alien being and on top i felt like i was stuck in a loop. I was sure i was loosing my mind and i never had so much fear in my life. Then we went to the club and all the people looked like puppets on strings and mechanically performed the same movements over and over again, it was a nightmare from which there was no awakening. As if that wasn't enough, all humans had a tail trailing behind them, as if they were comets. This went on for 8 hours and i manged to act "normal" by just sitting in a corner and drinking some beer but inside i was fighting for my sanity by telling me again and again that this was just the drug and that the effect would end eventually. After that i had two years of severe depressions and panic attacks. Needless to say that i will never ever touch psychedelics in my life again.   Also i knew a girl who was tripping on shrooms and became psychotic. She was in panic and run out on the streets but the people who were with her at that time were also totally wasted and did not follow her. After a few days she came back from wherever she was and was fully psychotic speaking to people that only she could see and giggling the whole time. She then lived on the streets and in squats for a while and was raped in a park. She never recovered from this and lives now in a care facility for mentally ill people.    Don't risk it, its not worth it! It can help you but it can also destroy your life and your mental health.  And if someone shows signs of psychosis or will not come down from that trip call an ambulance. The faster a drug psychosis is treated, the more likely a complete recovery is. Once such a psychosis has become chronic, there is often not much that can be done anymore.

It concerns me that once they recognize that these medicines are powerful healing agents (and could therefore impact their bottom lines) they are now trying to position themselves as the only ones who should be able to say how and when they are used. Okay,  the set and setting are often a significant part of shaping the experience. But anyone can set that up. After that, ALL of the work in done in the  mind of the person ingesting the medicine. The so called professionals are merely trip-sitters while the work is actually being done in the experiencer's mind. And any post experience processing is, at best, a fraction of the significance of the actual experience. But don't mess with their bottom lines. And is it going to be another 60 years before they realize that these medicines were given by nature, and nature's god, to everyone? and not just self proclaimed professionals? If it's not clear to them that these medicines are vastly less harmful to the user's than alcohol and tobacco, and should be no more controlled or regulated than broccoli, then they do not deserve to be the gatekeepers of these miraculous medicines. That said, I will personally allow them to control any similar chemical that has to be created in a lab and which is not found in nature. But the natural occurring medicines are everyone's natural right. control of those is prima facie evidence of medical tyranny.

I did therapeutic treatments with Ketamine in a clinic for depression. I did 10 sessions at $550 each, just to see if it worked. My family noticed a difference. I noticed a difference. But I couldn't continue because insurance just laughed at me and I couldn't afford $1100/week. It was non-habit-forming, I have no lingering "desire" for it beyond wanting to get that mindset back. I wish the therapeutic effect lasted longer. I did home treatments for a while, but it wasn't the same. Not everyone will have a breakthrough with psychedelics, but a decent fraction (maybe 10-20%, just coming out of my ass) will experience positive long-term life changes from a single profound trip. When it comes to certain psychedelics like shrooms and DMT, even a "bad" trip will promote beneficial changes in the long-run. A lot of times people who are in bad mental states are controlled by their subconscious, and "bad" trips are often somewhat of a harsh reality check where your conscious mind battles with your subconsciousness to tell you to stop being stupid. In my experience, it was my "bad" trip that got me to quit all of the other drugs I was doing and eat a healthier diet. Many people are scared of psychedelics because they're afraid of bad trips, but I encourage you to think of them as "challenging" trips instead in case they do happen to you. The mature side of your mind is trying to lecture you on your negative behaviors and lifestyle, and you need to listen to it.

I'm no stranger to phenomenological experiences on a daily basis, however, if I hadn't have the experiences I had in life (including a spontaneous full Kundalini Awakening in 1995), I would have possibly lost my sh*t and even had a psychotic break.  Instead, I just enjoyed what was being presented to me, the many layers of it all, even here in the waking state of things (or is this actually the dream with death being reawakened?).  To give you perspective on what happened and how this came about... The two women facilitating were taking advantage of the "Florida scene" where everyone who has ever gone down to South America or even Soul Quest to experience Florida, all of a sudden self qualifies themselves as "Shamans" and want to then serve "plant medicine" to others. Sadly, there is often a disregard or lack of reverence for it all and well, this was no different.  So bad was this evening that one young Russian girl (she was a model), in her early to mid 20's, was losing her shit and wanted to call her boyfriend to come get her. Yeah, I can recommend the mushroom journey, but NOT at the dosage I took.

Without psychedelics I would not be the person I am, and am eternally grateful for my experiences and the personal growth I was able to attain. That said, I must disagree on one thing you said that I wish were true but simply is not. Most of the world, or should I say - the world's governments - are not ready. My fiance had ten doses of LSD on him in the United States and spent over a year in prison. Not jail, prison. The criminal sentencing for psychedelics in my country is far higher for personal possession of small amounts of LSD than sentencing guidelines for a convicted drug dealer selling deadly opioids, and there is a reason for that. The government fears too many of us waking up, fears too many of us being happy, fears enlightenment for the masses. It is a true shame. I hope for a future where we as humans are entitled to explore our minds and find personal betterment through the benefits of psychedelics, and am passionate about seeing that come to fruition. If you live in the United States - the government does not want you to have these benefits or open your mind - and it's really sad.

Very interesting. I'm surprised that all of the comments I read were so positive. I took LSD twice in my late teens and it definitely opened my eyes to my inner world. But I realized almost immediately that I should never take these powerful drugs again, and instead should use a healthy discipline of meditation, spiritual chanting and yoga lifestyle to explore this world I'd gained a glimpse of with the help of the drug.  I know of many cases, some of them first hand, of people who've damaged their minds with these substances, sometimes irreparably. I'm amazed that so few of these comments acknowledge the dangers of these drugs, which are very real, especially in so-called 'heroic doses'.  I do know people who've benefited from micro-doses under the guidance of a qualified therapist, so I do agree that there is a case for therapeutic use of these drugs in the treatment of severe depression, but I would never recommend them for any other purpose.  As Aldous Huxley so truly observed "these substances can open the doors of perception, but can never take you through."

Hello, Matt Johnson - Yes, I understand, you study 'positive' effects of psychedelics, and I assume, any possible side-effects . . . Side-effects being problematic with modern pharmacological uses of 'single-active ingredient' drugs - which, to my knowledge are never found in nature.  A 'whole plant' may contain, often, innnumerable molecular chains of varying types, and NOT isolated 'single-active ingredient' molecular chains that the pharmaceutical industry pushes upon the world's suffering populace.  ALL of these 'medicines' have one thing in common - they ALL have side-effects.  But, honestly, so do various kinds of 'natural, organic compounds' WHEN TAKEN TO EXCESS.   But, parallel with 'the 60's' advent of mostly isolated, drugs such as LSD - which is artificially man-made, mimicking . . . what?  There was, also present at that nascent point of our recent history, a growing movement to 'naturally go within'; such as differing forms - and effectiveness, as studied - of meditation, yoga, breathing techniques.   A question should arise, upon closely examining multiple research projects and surveys - what might be the most effective, 'predictable' (key word) ways of using the mind, say, or, the body, or, one's air-flow regulation and pathways FOR a patient's betterment?  And, not just from the outside, external effects of (hopefully) more natural means of stimulating and PREDICTABLY MODULATING our own body's 'internal pharmacy' which, as we all know, has parallel effects upon 'bio-chemical' brain functioning?   One problem of using 'externals' is the many unpredictable outcomes, including measuring 'potency'. And, what are the qualities of differing mind/body types?   And responses?    Do you as a researcher of the mind and its downstream behaviors, have any idea at all of identifiable body/mind types?  I speak from a perspective of 50+ years of meditation practices (TM), and of its sister practices of Ayurvedic Medicine.  Expample: In Ayurvedic Medicine, there are 10 differing mind/body types.  And yearly, seasonal, daily fluctuations of our body's organic chemistry.  These highly varying conditions can become understood and quantifiable by a trained Vaidya/MD.  And yes, medical professionals ARE becoming vitally interested in the new medicine: Integrative Medicine.

I struggled with Existential Depression and would feel my emotions take over the driver's seat. I'd be in severe despair, crying, unable to move, thinking of all the ways to die. I was living with my parents at the time because I'd be unable to work. My father didn't know how to respond and my mother continuously just said not to be depressed. But it's as if you see everyone dying, withering away in a hopeless, vast void where all of our meanings and axioms are revealed as just nothing. That was daily life and I still have those thoughts, but not the despairing emotion anymore.  I tried Magic Mushrooms in Portland three months back. It was a full cap and stem, just one. I felt things intensely. I had gotten emotional about feeling that I was annoying to my girlfriend's friend, who I was meeting for the first time. I gazed at the stars and saw them glowing, ruminating on how their glow seemed to extend from and circle back into myself. I felt profound connectedness. That night we also danced around a Bonfire at the Oregon Country Fair. I didn't see things moving, but I did feel my "focal length" shift. I'd feel as if I acknowledged people were sitting next to me, yet felt far away at the same time. Over the next two days, I found I felt more sleepy but in this very warm and radiatingly beautiful way. If I breathed slow and meditated, some partial feelings of my trio would seem to reignite, conferring a semblance that I could control my inner bliss.  Three months later, I haven't dealt with those crippling feelings of depression once. I also don't reflect on my trip as some validation that I connected to the universe or God in some major way. It just feels like an "air blanket" has developed between the despairing feelings and those thoughts would normally ignite them. I can still ruminate on life's philosophical emptiness the way I did, without turning to religion, and still feel peaceful and grateful.   Magic Mushrooms has the power to enable us to deal with the real implications of our Existential Condition by opening pathways to mature about them, giving us back control of emotions that arise from the fear of death and nothingness. This is likely why we had religion before, but Mushrooms, administered wisely, can lead to stable mental states with an honest disposition towards death and our existence without subscribing to fabricated ontology.   Mushrooms, I feel, have literally saved my life.
