This is the most based and reasonable comment I‚Äôve seen here.   We‚Äôre not a species designed to be between concrete walls staring at screens all day to get enough magic numbers to go home and buy processed food.   We are bombarded with more information on our phones in one hour than an early human would have gotten in an entire year.   We have destroyed our dopamine receptors because we could get a quick fix on sites like tiktok to the point these generations including myself are so addicted to the next dopamine high that we scroll all day and get addicted to social media, drinking, sex and recreational drugs to escape the feeling that there‚Äôs something deeply wrong with how we‚Äôre living. I‚Äôve done it too.  We are naturally tribal, family and empathy based and meant to travel for miles a day for our food and water.  I‚Äôm not saying go back to the Stone Age, but there‚Äôs a deep deep problem with how we run society that is going against everything in our natural being. And either we need to genetically alter and change our entire species to thrive in these capitalist conditions, or change the actual conditions themselves. The latter is the far more logical option. We weren‚Äôt meant to be unfeeling machines.  Mark my words, the problem with suicide and depression will only get worse. And you‚Äôre seeing it with people my age having less and less children, less relationships. This is not sustainable.

In 1981, when I was 24, I took my first dose thinking it would be a fun thing to do on a Saturday night. After 15 minutes, I began to feel really uncomfortable. I couldn't hold back this tide of discomfort, and I soon realized all the unpleasant things I had been stuffing down to avoid facing were now being thrust up, and I could no longer avoid them. My feelings of being an imposter (I was a BMW salesman who had dropped out of high school), of guilt and sadness over my mom's death 5 years earlier, the loss of connection with my family, and the self-loathing I experienced as the result of years of childhood trauma and abuse flooded me. I writhed in agony on my bed as these 'demons' came for me. Then a voice began to speak to me, telling me it was all ok, that it was normal to have these feelings - of course I was sad about my mom, of course I missed caring for my mom and younger brother, of course I didn't know or understand a lot because I had missed a lot of learning and guidance, and of course I would feel bad about myself when most of what I was told about myself was negative. Then I felt this tremendous sense of relief, like nothing I'd ever experienced. This experience changed me, made me softer, more vulnerable, and more empathetic to others. I'm 66 now, and my world has again "shrunk", and I'm stuck. I tried microdosing, but it had limited impact. I need another heroic dose.  I was afraid to try it again, but now I'm ready.

I took a pretty high dose and it's hard to describe everything in a comment. I felt in contact with something that is always there but that I normally can't communicate with directly. This thing was overjoyed that I was perceiving it but was urgently trying to tell me things in the limited time we had. It communicated in symbols. I felt my brain being temporarily rewired and saw hallucinatory representations of that. I saw a being sitting at the foot of my bed which communicated with me telepathically. I felt the perceived seat of my consciousness shift. I passed through a tunnel into a place where my constant inner narrative stopped. I finally realized why bands like Tool use so many staring disembodied eyeballs in their album art. As I came down, I kept seeing a brilliant light coming unexpectedly from different sources, and this faded into a kind of afterglow that lasted for a day or two. I came away from this with the realization that this had been not only the greatest spiritual experience of my life but perhaps the only one.

I was being a piece of garbage person who was headed down a road that would only lead to a sad death. Now I'm inspired with the things I do and I try to do my best like I used to. I think the world is constantly bombarding people with dopaminergic activities left and right and we get overstimulated and burned out. It's why I think meditation and practicing mindfulness as well as rigorous exercise is the key to a stable mindset. It's all within your control no matter how bad you feel it is. I was genuinely wondering if I had deep psychological issues due to me constantly sabotaging my life and having no emotional control but I realized when tripping that your mood can change in an instant so why not apply it to real life. When I said I wasn't depressed i felt something like a lightbulb moment that changed the course of my life forever.

It was more cognitive for me, this entity (possibly myself) explained to me that, the world is full of pain and fear, to the point where it is overwhelming at times. But, lets take the opposite, what if it was true that, there was just so much joy, that it was overwhelming, nothing required effort, you could literally have anything, it could be stuff you didn't even know was possible, and it just gets served to you without any effort required.... We'll that is just as equally disturbing, you would have no reason to even be conscious, everything would be provided, you could literally not be aware of anything, and feel super amazing all the time, but then you would be unconscious, and super bored. You might even be bored to the point where you start to crave difficulty, and then you make a place where nothing in life is free, and everything is super difficult to get, and there is a constant looming fear that everything that you know of could end at any moment. It would be exciting, overwhelming at times, but at least you wouldn't be bored in to unconsciousness. And that is the cycle that we are in right now, but I think we are at the point where we are getting tired of everything taking a lot of effort, and we are starting to swing in the direction of not needing to use so much energy to obtain goals. For the record; in the proper set & setting, with informed intention, and the support of like minded peers I (as a neorodivergent twenty something) was initiated into used of "Threshold" doses per the McKenna family protocol. (5 dried grams in a dark quiet safe space). The use of "Heroic" as a descriptor for this level of dosage has the tinge of party culture nomenclature that I prefer to avoid.  These are plant medicines & many  require proper initiation before use. Again; education is key.   I digress; I would like to point out that high doses of psychedelics used in the proper circumstance utterly changed my quality of life for the better; & I have no fear in advocating Their proper use in therapy, self care, and as a means of harm reduction.  They also have a place for the curious in our society while providing an alternative to both legal & illicit drug cultures that endanger people daily.  Are we not ready for this? As a species, ask yourself - really ask and do research. I am only one, but I am here to tell you that there is an entirely different approach to how we could live; if you're willing to open a Third Eye.   Personally, I'm done asking. So, how about we give this a genuine shot as a species? Please? It would mean a great deal to myself & those like me who have to live in the shadow of misinformed stigmatization. I was grief stricken a year ago. Unable to function after my fianc√© died traumatically I could only find relief in plotting how to make my death not look  like suicide. I took a micro dose of mushrooms he‚Äôd left behind and went to bed expecting nothing to happen. 90 minutes later I was in my kitchen doing the dishes. Then I walked the dog and felt sun on my face. Then I ate dinner for the first time in weeks, drank water and went to bed.  My grief was still there - painful, raw and vivid but somehow I understood that I would make it and that life was going to show me the way and let joy in again.  Edit; I didn‚Äôt want my death to look like suicide - I wanted to find a way to have an ‚Äúaccident‚Äù that didn‚Äôt put anyone else at risk.  Edir 2: it‚Äôs 2 years and 3 months later. I'm confused by his terminology. He refers to 30 milligrams of psilocybin as a heroic dose.  That is a very small amount. We would often eat several grams of psilocybin for recreational doses.  Is he referring to some isolated and refined extract?   One of the things that gets left to the side is the abuse of these things.   People will reflexively try to negate any kind of statement about this.  Trying to defend their hallowed psychedelic experience.  But if you go back and read your Terrence McKenna he talked about this.  There is the initial epiphany which can be such a profound experience that we desire to get back there.  We waste a lot of time trying to get back there using the same means. Even formalizing the approach to this experience.  Which McKenna thought was the foundation of religion. Once, many years ago, I found myself with about three days off, and I did an ounce of 'shrooms over my weekend.  Started with about 3g on Friday and just went nuts after that until there weren't anymore.  Watched some excellent movies (Blade Runner, 3 Rooms, Alien, etc.).  Two of the best were Baraka (a very expansive experience) and Das Boot (quite the opposite - WWII from the perspective of a German U boat crew).  THE BEST was Apocalypse Now, pretty much a mix of the two.  I also have Apocalypse Now on a double CD.  It's amazing to listen to the movie with the lights out.  Be in a good place, though.         Yeah.  Friends of mine have ended up in the fetal position in the corner listening to that while tripping.  Me, thankfully, I never forget I'm tripping and have never had a bad trip - only enduring others who have.  Other people I know - holy shit.  They think they're never coming back.  Haven't tripped in decades, but still value the experiences.

Respect mushrooms, and remember your state of mind, environment and many other factors contribute to how it will go. Sitting in a dark apartment in a bad mood on your computer = bad trip. Taking after a family or relationship loss = bad trip. Taking in a good mood and comfortable environment = good trip. Set yourself up for a good trip, and if you are taking anything over 3 grams assure you are being safe and maybe have a trip sitter and trip killer on hand. Remember it's not like weed, you can't just do it recreationally all the time. It should be used sparingly in large doses and or micro dosed. Mushrooms aren't something you just do daily with the bros.

I have recently been delving into this, and have read that the "in between dose" of micro dosing and heroic dosing can be the worst area, having bad trips.  Micro dosing is a mood elevator, creativity enhancer and produces little to none hallucinations.  While the heroic dose, (5-7grams), is supposed to break through, disconnecting you from reality, and cause ego death, introspection, and dissolve the stress and bad negative habits and thoughts we learn as we go.    That being said, Mushrooms are not a pharmaceutical drug with a consistent dose.  It varies from plant to plant, in the species.  Its possible to take the proper dose and under dose.  However, some researchers use Psilocyben molecules, which are an exact controlled dose.  If you do have a need for further therapy in the future, dont take it off the table :)  Best luck

¬†@icecube8496¬†   I really hope you read this, because I really do care about you - even though I don‚Äôt know you. I may say things you think you‚Äôve heard before, but read to the end - because this is much deeper than becoming ‚Äúenlightened‚Äù or discovering truths about reality‚Ä¶  I was chasing after Glory, through my extensive use of hallucinogens. I wanted to know the core of reality. However, like I said, no matter what combination I used, no matter how hard I tripped and no matter how many Ego Deaths I had or grand experiences, I never reached where I actually was trying to get to. I was on a spiritual treadmill, trying to go deeper and never getting where I wanted - sometimes with grave consequences (like diving headfirst out of a moving vehicle on 24 grams of shrooms because I listened to entities which told me to sacrifice myself to save everyone‚Ä¶. that‚Äôs a longer story)‚Ä¶.  My life has been radically transformed and I have found deeper, lasting satisfaction, peace, joy, and EVERYTHING I was looking for in hallucinogens (but not getting a hold of) - However, it wasn‚Äôt my intellect or power, or intentionality that transformed me. I didn‚Äôt do it - I just stopped running away‚Ä¶ What I discovered was that the Source, God, the Creator of All, did not expect me or want me to try to manifest spiritual realities in the physical, by my own will through ingesting substances. He wanted to have a personal relationship with me, and I didn‚Äôt need to chase wind to get it‚Ä¶ He offered a way and He made himself known, when I sought Him with my whole heart desperately - not trying to do it my own way‚Ä¶ but through submitting to HIS way‚Ä¶.   I was 18 when God made himself known to me and opened my eyes. He gave me a new heart and mind; true ego death - and I was born again - not through my own effort (with drugs or substances) but by HIS spirit and will, My only participation was HUMILITY and FAITH.  I was on the edge of suicide, going through withdrawals (for bath salts) and ready to die. I was desperate and so tired of trying my own way‚Ä¶. when I was calling out to God, telling him I was ready to die and couldn‚Äôt do it anymore - I remembered something my mom had said about Jesus and God‚Äôs unfailing power‚Ä¶. I had rejected Gods ways and chosen my own path, but in my desperation I leaned into the Creator who I rejected and it dawned on me that He HAD made a way for us to know Him, through the death and resurrection of Christ. He revealed himself to me and transformed my heart from the inside out. I realized I had never truly been alive, I was always ‚Äúspiritually dead‚Äù and He gave me a new life. The blinders were removed.  I know you‚Äôve heard about Jesus, but let me break it down simply: We ALL have sinned and fallen short of God‚Äôs glory - no human is perfect. We‚Äôve all hated God and rebelled against our Creator, and we deserve the penalty for spiritual treason against God - which is death.. our physical death is the punishment for our sins. Our sin and rebellion has seperated us from a pure and holy and perfect God, who is beyond anything we can comprehend - and the debt we owed him for our treason is much too great for anyone to ‚Äúpay back‚Äù through ‚Äúgood works‚Äù or ‚Äúreligious duties.‚Äù  No amount of human effort could reconcile or reunite us to God - but in his love and grace He made a way - He inserted himself into the reality he created, to live a perfect life and die a brutal death to take the judgement of our sins. He reunited Himself to us by making a way that we could be forgiven, by himself taking our punishment - which we can only have by BELIEVING he did it and turning to Him and away from our rebellion.    When we surrender and trust in Jesus‚Äôs work on the cross to restore us to God, He gives us a new spirit and we are born again - like I was, all alone in my parents basement, without any substances or moral ‚Äúself righteousness.‚Äù  I knew I needed saving, I was desperate. Some people still rely on their ‚Äúgood works‚Äù which amount to nothing in God‚Äôs eyes‚Ä¶ You cannot tell a judge the good things you did to avoid punishment for treason‚Ä¶ So He made a way, in pure love and grace, sending himself in human form to die on the cross and bear our sins‚Ä¶ You‚Äôve heard it before, but I pray today that your eyes are opened and you recognize your separation and sin, and see that you deserve to pay the penalty, but rejoice in the good love of God that He made a way, by HIS work - not yours. He LOVEs you so much, and I pray that you come to know the depths of his love and personality. It is not about ‚Äúreligion.‚Äù It is about trusting in Jesus, who He is, what He did, and allowing Him to become Lord over your life. He will make you knew, and it is better than ANYTHING i‚Äôve ever experienced‚Ä¶ plus it lasts for Eternity‚Ä¶ However it isn‚Äôt easy to be a Christian. People hate you for telling them they need to be saved. However, it‚Äôs worth it, because I have a real relationship with God.

As psilocybin mushrooms are capable of being harvested in nature, there is a major risk in misidentifying mushroom species and accidentally consuming poisonous, if not lethal varieties. This can be avoided by educating oneself in advance on how to properly identify the correct species of mushroom and the potential look-alike mushrooms found within one's local area. It is recommended to not learn to do this by oneself, but instead, have someone experienced in mushroom-picking as a mentor.

This is incredibly dangerous. There are numerous cases of individuals who were negatively impacted for life after a bad trip. Increases in depression anxiety suicidal ideation and lack of motivation are all reported. Long term. The risk is almost never worth the reward folks. Please, please do not resort to any psychedelics without researching all sides of the results. Most importantly, those with mental health issues should never use this treatment, unless thorough research has been conducted and the process is administered and controlled by a trained professional who accepts all legal liability for negative consequences. No one wants to be depressed or anxious, but being in and out of mental wards, losing relationships, being unable to hold a job and suicide are not acceptable risks. God bless and keep those looking for relief and salvation.

What do you mean by integration ?

¬†@sha-sha7665¬† Here is a well written explanation: "The term ‚Äúpsychedelic integration‚Äù can have many meanings depending on the context in which the term is used.  In a general sense, it refers to the work of self-reflection that a person engages in, in the days and weeks following a psychedelic experience.  Self-reflection allows for the insights gained during the psychedelic experience to be better retained in memory.  It also allows an individual to ‚Äúmake sense‚Äù of the material that arose during a psychedelic experience by relating it to their life‚Äôs journey and life experiences, or current life challenges they are working through.  Psychedelic integration can be done alone, with a peer support group, or with a therapist or guide."  The point is to make your journey stick. Getting high is easy, but turning your experience into lessons that you learn from and integrate into your being takes practice. Integration also has an aspect of emotional support because sometimes the post-trip experience can be challenging to deal with.

I had the most wonderful experience and the next day I woke up like I was brand new. I wasn't 100% cured for certain, but this was the catalyst for my healing journey.  All my friends and family instantly recognised a complete personality change.  I explained why and some were resistant to the concept, others just accepted.  Over the next year I experimented more and found I was able to work through each of my issues with the help of mushrooms.  its now been over 12 years since that night and I still explore my mind when the opportunity presents its self.  I give my gratitude to that first experience and the wonders of the Psilocybin mushroom,  if not for that night I wouldn't be here to share this story.

Psychedelic expert here. I've taken psychedelics hundreds of times. Here is some advice. Give yourself one or two years to prepare. Take your time. Make the first time special. But don't think about it too much. Purify your set. Practice Yama and Niyama. Practice Dharana and Dhyana. Study and practice the eight limbs of yoga. Try not to get too caught up in either Hatha yoga or Raja yoga. What is Bhakti yoga? Ask yourself this question. All our feelings of guilt or prestige all the hoops society pushes us through, are all about feelings. Find "the Beloved".  Open your heart. Find a beautiful setting wherein you are at peace. Take the journey with a friend, at least someone who is willing to be with you until you come down and fall asleep, and who will also be there for you the following day. Forgive everyone for everything. With sufficient preparation psychedelics reveal the "wish-fulfilling gem". This is a non-religious spiritual journey. Be Here Now. I Love You. Yes, you are right. Use these simple mantras, they bring peace. Heroic dose? For LSD? 400 micrograms. For Psilocybin? Two grams. These are the only two sacraments I would recommend for the novice. Know yourself well first, and then be prepared to let go of all you know. Behind what you think you are, is the truth of what you are. Good luck. All the best to you.

Since then I have been removing the wall that went up just so i can return to my development.   I was just all in all happier, more easily and readily able to deal with the world and the problems it presented and solve the problems i was plagued with.   Prior i struggled just to get every day tasks done but with this, I was able to put my mind on a hyper focus.  I lost weight safely, and properly dropped 100  lbs from my overweight status and im now at a healthy weight and maintained it, I was a better and WAY more open person, nothing really bothered me any more. Directly or indirectly i was okay with whatever happened, even when bad things happened i shrugged my shoulders and continued on with my day,  These days i struggle a little bit but i am finally getting back to where i can safely say, im ready again and will return to a status where whether im sober or under the influence that i can be happy.     some may consider this rose colored glasses but when you deal with some of the stuff we deal with in society today and take those things overly personal it makes that stuff worse.   Honestly i wish the entire world would "trip" because we all need to learn to just let go and stop to look at ourselves and where we are. AA use to treat members with MDMA to help fix their addictions and had huge success until the government and religion kicked in and destroyed it and turned it into more of a cult for a religion indoctrination. I've done a lot of psychedelics and I'm just grateful it didn't completely reshape who I am. I have really bad anxiety and moments of severe confusion and disorientation occasionally, symptoms I didn't have before my encounters with LSD and psilocybin.  I wouldn't be disparaging towards the drug if it didn't have real consequences. Psychedelics are one of the most dangerous, they can permanently reshape your reality to make it something happy and cheerful and full of candy (for neurotypicals) or it can make it a demented, anxiety-ridden, depressive and destructive nightmare (if you have mental health conditions, like 95% of people do)

I took a heroic dose with a group of friends. 3.5g dry fine cut fresh picked along with a full mid-size glass of potent tea. I experienced a strong period of nausea to which I looked for comfort down stairs, then back upstairs on the couch. I had cold sweats for a bit but I fought through it until I was suddenly thrust into extreme comfort on cloud 9, instantly. I was suddenly viewing the open living room of my friends place and it was floating in black space. At one point I went to the balcony and gazed upon the moon and could feel how my consideration towards ideas in how we exist in space was open and understanding at the most profound levels. I could tell we exist in an open space, no borders, anything could traverse here, that was slightly unsettling to fully consider.   Later, I was looking at a picture on the wall and somehow, I could see the picture and an evolving fractal edge of which I related to the train of cellular reproduction on earth. At least that is what my head told me or how I interpreted it. Following the fractal bit I came to a point where I could see myself from a distance like standing somewhere or leaning on a wall, but I could see what I looked like without having the ego of oneself. I could also notice how it creates an effect in your vision like looking at a 3D movie without the glasses on. At the peak I experienced conscious time dilation where you seemingly know time should be passing soon, but you know not when that moment might come, nor do you know how much time has elapsed so you don't know when the next minute will turn. It is the strangest sensation because just prior you knew roughly how much time has passed.   At the end I tried to use the clarity of mind and the group to present some questions, but I wasn't around anyone who gave a hoot enough to try and really answer them or try to "brainstorm" during that time. All in all it was an amazing experience.

While psychedelic research isn‚Äôt new, it has made significant progress in the last decade. Political rhetoric has made the subject highly controversial and has hindered science for years, but the opinions of medical practitioners have also created obstacles to patient treatment. I understand the hesitancy some doctors may have regarding illicit drugs, but ‚Äúdrugs‚Äù are just medications that have been deemed hazardous and habit-forming. However, that does not preclude these chemicals from providing significant relief to patients who have failed other pharmaceutical options. I believe it is a violation of medical ethics not to keep an open mind regarding patient therapy and not to support a patient‚Äôs ‚Äúright to try‚Äù. The ethical pillars of medicine are beneficence, justice, non-maleficence, and autonomy. In my opinion, the obstacles thrown up by some medical professionals regarding alternate pharmaceutical therapies violate beneficence and autonomy. Autonomy is the patient‚Äôs right to make decisions regarding their own body and destiny. Beneficence is the obligation a medical practitioner has to make decisions that are best for the patient‚Äôs health and safety. I can understand that some doctors may consider encouraging or signing off on referrals for psychedelic therapy is a violation of beneficence, but I argue that when a patient has no more officially FDA-approved options left, it is in a patient‚Äôs best interest to explore any other options.

That's alright, everyone is different.  I've got some hardcore generalized and social anxiety and other health issues so I'm with you there.  I have a ton of practice with tripping so I can force my way through the social stuff if I need to but I prefer to go it alone, where ever-present social pressures aren't creeping in.  So maybe just stay solo?  That being said, sometimes I've found I can punch through the anxiety, I just had to really commit.    For example, I was tripping with a group and watching a movie (the very trippy 2008 Speed Racer, specifically) and my peripheral was playing tricks on me.  I kept thinking the person to my right or left was staring directly at me for no reason.  I internalized how awkward it would be if I checked and found out I was right.  What would I say?  What am I SUPPOSED to say?  I forced myself to check and of course, everyone was mesmerized by the movie and paying me no mind.  I incorporated that into other times in my life when I felt that way and it's proven to be very beneficial.

Listen.  What psychedelics do is entirely, 100% explainable through activity in our nervous system, including the brains etc.  That¬¥s what is causing the experiences, the substance is influencing that system. There is no end result or goal, god or anything like that. You need to get this through your head, otherwise you¬¥d might end up doing weird cultist shit for years, etc.  I¬¥m not against the use of. I¬¥m for understanding "the it and of" better, we need to focus more on practical things. I¬¥m not denying the benefits, the sense of presence, emotions etc. I¬¥m stating that you also need to keep your head screwed in the way that it fits. And be aware of how psychedelics affect the processes of decision making, reasoning etc.  Remember : we live in a world where people want to make money, use social power etc. One mistake can have serious outcomes years later and if you¬¥re financially well off and secure, it¬¥s a totally different scenario. Do you have any idea how many people are hustled while under the influence of something, anything? On a daily basis?  Your emotions will fool you, if you¬¥re being fooled. And your reasoning, the intuition you have about people is what, at least to some degree, guards over that. You need to stay sharp, that¬¥s what you need to do. This guy romanticized things a little too much. Psychs won't magically change you on their own. It takes a lot of legwork afterwards to maintain your enlightenment. Otherwise it will fade away, for many people.   There is no pill or substance which you can take that will grant you immediate, lasting wisdom. There may be methods to expedite the process (by varying degrees of success), but they do not exist without unique, often quite undesirable side-effects.   "Buy the ticket, take the ride"  There is no turning back.   That being said, psychs did save my life in many ways. Encouraged me to finally move out of my parents house, move to a new city and go to college. Instilled a spiritual belief in me, when I had been an agnostic atheist my entire life.  That being said, I do often wish that I had remained ignorant and afraid of death. I'm not sure that I would have shed the level of depression that I was drowning in, had I not taken psychs, but there is certainly something to be said for a healthy level of fear of death fueling your desire to really make the most of this life.   Still, knowing what I know now, I think I would still probably do psychs for the first time if given the choice again.

The most meaningful experience I've had was also the scariest. I always say, "You don't get the trip you want. You get the trip you need." Basically, I took about 3.5 grams of some of the strongest mushrooms I've ever done and I went to go to the bathroom and shut off the light to trip in the darkness, with all the patterns and colours, I couldn't find the light after. I ended up falling in the tub and just kinda laying there. I remember feeling like there was an omnipotent presence with me that was showing me the secrets of the universe. I remember wanting the shapes and patterns to stop because I could feel the anxiety building. Eventually, I realized if this is some sort of extradimensional being, I can't just say "stop" in English and hope they'll understand. So I went from saying stop in French and Spanish to just making noises, hoping that the configuration of sounds would end up as me saying "stop" in whatever language they speak. One of my most important take aways from my first lsd trip (I'd done shrooms before) was that, if this was a state of mind where I could be under the influence of this drug, it had to be accessible to me during my regular sober life, too. It specially came to me when I realized that fear and anxiety have similar effects to what psychedelics do: they make you introspective, they make you focus on yourself, and suddenly your mind is having a bunch of crazy thoughts that come out of nowhere and you imagine countless situations where the worst could happen. And it's like... that's tied to creativity in a way. Close your eyes and try to walk through a room you already know. Even if you know that room perfectly, closing your eyes will trigger fear and suddenly you imagine a bunch of stuff that isn't really there in that room. It's... creating. And I think the state induced by psychedelics, creativity and fear itself are all related through that simple fact of letting the mind go to places that "make no sense". It's a matter of the path it takes (which is also why bad trips exist, and they have similar effects to what panic and anxiety do to you but amplified).   So, I realized, if my sober mind can trigger all of that "creativity" while experiencing anxiety, I should be able to refocus that energy to trigger it in other areas of my life. Trying to make art, thinking about the big picture, understanding different perspectives, seeing new things where I was always seeing the same. I think the end goal of psychedelics used in a therapeutic or artistic way should be to reach that state without the use of the drug itself, and I think it is 100% possible, or at least that trying to get there is one of the healthiest things we could do after experiencing an eye opening possitive experience with drugs.

This is an interesting view! I had similar experiences, YEARS ago like WAY before the whole thing legally expired...  Anyway, I noticed that I couldn¬¥t get out of the loop of fear and panic but that was actually due to the circumstances. I was homeless and broke, also in a city with extremely conservative values and zero-tolerance policy, so it was not the best of places to be in. And I did notice that I¬¥d get these very, very abstract thoughts from heightened fear, and that made me find creative ways to make myself feel safe. Now, if you take things like religion and symbols, you get in to the space of fear and safety on a whole different level. This is such a huge topic.  What was interesting that the only solid way I could think of to get out of that situation was to go and study physics and engineering. Like, you literally feel a lot more safe if you know precisely how EM radiation works, how the human nervous system works etc. and I¬¥m thinking that both art and science probably have their origins in things like fear and beliefs. Only science offers something that actually works against thunderbolts and lightning. It¬¥s called a faraday cage. It¬¥s really interesting. So all things considered, fear lead to the need of safety, which lead to science, which lead to research and that lead to engineering. So next time you see someone with a tin-foil hat... seriously, it¬¥s not going to work like that. What you NEED is a tin-foil overall, like you literally have to cover your entire body and especially they eyes. The least protective part of your body in terms of radiation is where there¬¥s no skin or the skin is very thin. Such as the eyes.  So, if you happen to experience a shitload of fear and anxiety under extreme amounts of psilocybin or LSD, BE SURE to wrap yourself like a tortilla in tin foil but : YOU GOTTA PUT ON THE GOGGLES FIRST!!!!!

I had been through an intricate tunnel very similar to my dmt trips, and at the end was a womanly-buddha figure that emitted light that felt so beautiful. I felt love all over me and was mind blown as i came out of it. I boofed another 50 mg and went straight into the tunnel again to be greeted by the same entity. The combination of each allowed me to break a horrible opioid addiction, get out of an abusive relationship, and ended up with an incredible job. I still use recreational drugs but no opioids (i can't without relapsing lol). Love and respect myself now. In my youth, about 14 years old, maybe 15, I had gone on occasion with my pals in the Chilliwack area of the Fraser Valley in B. C. CA, to pick psilocybes and ingest them, too. After many such times, I had a tremendous experience. I took a large dose of fresh fruits. I think it was maybe 8 or 10. We were all together at Lee's place, high school buddy. He was a drummer and other young musicians and friends were there in his basement, getting ready to have some musical fun. Not all of us had imbibed. About 40 minutes in, I was feeling first waves and they were strong. I started getting very concerned and feeling claustrophobic in Lee's dark basement so I excused myself, went out across the road and sat down on a grassy riverbank about 40 feet from a very large weeping willow. It was a clear, sunny day, warm.   It was definite. I had taken too much. I started to panic, knowing I had a few unpredictable hours ahead of me. I started to pray to the living Creator God, who hears us. I begged Him to take this away from me. As I was going on about it, I suddenly noticed that I was clear. The psilocybe effect was completely neutralized. At that instant I realized that I was heard by the Master. Personally. Awestruck at that understanding, I started to give profuse thanks. I raised my head and a downdraft swirled through that willow tree and then I felt it touch me. My eyes turned to the sun, drawn like a moth to the fire. I found that I could look directly into it and not only did it have no pain at all, nor cause the normal squinting reflex, it was something to go into, to drink up, to desire more of. Knowing that this Supreme Being had opened me up to withstand this glory, I wondered what it meant. It was then that I heard His voice, but not audibly. It said, "This is what it is like to come into my presence. You cannot withstand it unless I prepare you. You are experiencing a small taste of Me." That little draft of His perceptible presence was a combination of those things we call "love," "joy," and "peace." He is the source of those things and it doesn't come any other way. His name is also the Truth. The Way. And The Life. As I basked in both the warm sunlight and the intense pleasure of His revelation, I did not want to leave. It was something I wanted to go more into, but the presence faded.  Stable and sober, I climbed up the grassy bank, back over to Lee's house and downstairs into the big common room. All eyes turned to me, as they stopped playing. Lee asked me what happened. I just mumbled something about needing to get out for a bit. Then he said, "You're glowing." I didn't think much of it, replying only, "Yeah, the sun and breeze are super," or something like that, just thinking they were noting a ruddy, sun-kissed complexion.  Years later, I was talking to another of those friends that was there that day. The comment about the glowing skin came up, and Blair explained it to me: "No, dude, you were truly glowing, emanating visible light from around your head." I was stunned. There is a story about an encounter with the same God as was experienced by a certain leader named Moses. God stuck Him in a fissure in the rock, face in, and just blasted by him quickly so that Moses would have minimal exposure, only to his back side. As God passed by, He declared His character as being "merciful and gracious, longsuffering, and abundant in goodness and truth." When Moses went back down the mountain to the people, they asked him to cover his head. He was too bright. He got a much bigger dose than I did. Of God, not psilocybe!  There was no ongoing effect of the psilocybe. It's effect was upon me only about 15 minutes or so and the entire experience over in maybe 30-40 minutes. But it was life altering. I know there is a real God who lives and hears.

I want to start with a disclaimer: I was MIS-diagnosed medication. I am no way advocating for you to go off your meds because of what you read below. If I'd tried to quit my meds without seeking outside help, things could have ended up a lot worse (read dirt nap, psychosis etc) than the state I'm currently in. A lot of people who also have the correct diagnosis will benefit on anti depressants whereas, because of my unique physiology, I suffer. This is my personal tale.    I'm currently withdrawing from anti depressants that were mis prescribed to me because of a lack of care in the public health system in my country. I was on these goddam things for 6 years at way too high a dosage and barely any oversight, I hadn't really been diagnosed with anything, the doctor just gave me pills to get me out of his office so he could push through to his next patient.  I didn't even go into the GP looking to get on drugs, I just wanted a mental health plan and to see if I could get someone to talk to about my problems. Being an experienced psychonaut going onto anti-depressants I thought "no problem, no drug has taken over or ruined my life, I took them before, had a bit of a giggle, had a couple days down and then went on as a productive citizen. If he's just giving me a scrip after a 10 minute chat these things must be soft." I was so wrong, the pills I was on cost me my marriage, my family, my career, my house and very close to my sanity.   The first 2 weeks of the withdrawals was 2 of the worst weeks of my life. I experienced paralyzing amounts of vertigo, nausea and tremors where I was bed bound for a week, I'm still having auditory hallucinations, shadow people in my peripheral vision, sleep depravation, extreme mood swings, paranoia, rediscovering that I have feelings, heart palpitations, loss of bowel control and a whole bunch of others. I am currently in week 3 of 6 of my withdrawals and I still have all of these withdrawal effects to lessening degrees, some even decide to come back at me full force when the sun goes down, but its's lessening over time.  While I was on the medication if I missed my regime by about 1 hour, I would get the beginning of these withdrawal effects, debilitating me until I could get one of the pills into my system.  The drug itself just cut off my ability to have emotions. It killed all my drives and cost me just about everything in my life.  Also, the medication made my eyes absolutely ache and made me tired all the time. It literally felt like my eyes had been sandpapered, some days I didn't  want to get out of bed because it meant having to open my desert dry eyes. It's one of the reasons why I decided to get off these meds, I just couldn't stand it anymore.   The side effects were understated, the withdrawal effects were barely explained and thank god I want to a competent Dr who's been guiding me on getting off these cursed things because one of the withdrawal effects is psychosis where any of the withdrawal effects can stick for life, that combined with the paranoia means you really have to have someone with a good enough bedside manner who knows what they are talking about and can reassure you in the correct way that this probably won't be the case.    I have had psychedelics before, and let me tell you, the withdrawal side effects from a big trip or a taking too much x are NOTHING compared to what I'm going through. I've heard quitting heroin is hard, the mountain comes the first few days, then you have a week of being debilitated, then it lessens where there's just a longing for the drug left. I would trade that for how I feel right now at almost into week 4 of this "experience." It's been a nightmare from physiology all the way down to introspection and it doesn't relent. The sun's gone down and the shakes are starting again.   Like, modern chemists and psyches KNOW that these side effects and withdrawal effects can be this bad. They know that this stuff absolutely has the potential to mess up lives and kill and it is handed out like candy.    On the flip side psychedelics that have been demonized for political and racist reasons, that our entire society has had it's collective mind poisoned against has side effects so mild, so well known through popular culture for thousands of years that EVEN if all they did was a placebo effect of making your life a bit more pleasant  by killing a few brain cells and make you giggle a bit, are the vastly superior option.  I'm in no way addicted to the anti depressants, the sooner this crap is out of my system the better and I never want to touch a drug that does this to me ever again. But the physiological reaction to them is insane. I've read stories of people choosing to go back on them once they tried to quit because quitting is too hard. I can understand that mentality.   It's funny looking at the footage of hippies facing off against national guard in a protest. It feels like the psychedelics are the hippies, nice, serene, chill out and enjoy life philosophy, which seems helpful and the type of help I needed when I got on the antiD's 6 years ago,  whereas these anti depressants are like the national guard, stomping on my serotonin receptors with their jack boots trying to make my brain conform until my mental processes resemble something like a normie's brain.   One of these things guides you to a better place, the other one blocks deviations with no regard for the havok that they cause to the wellbeing of those around them.   When getting off of a hit of shrooms, you feel fuzzy for 2 days and then maybe a week of not peak performance, nothing that can't be sorted with a nice cup'o'tea and taking it slow with a blanket on the couch. I imagine 6 years of microdosing would probably feel strange if you chose to quit, but not anything like I feel now.  Anti depressants has been just under 4 weeks of unrelenting come down where the muscle spasms and physical pain are competing in the pain olympics with your mental state fluctuations.

The biggest single instant of self-understanding I've ever had was when I was wandering a Western Mass town at 3-7 am, on 3-5 drops of liquid acid with a friend. We had been walking for hours already, looping around every road within a mile or so, when we came to a stretch bordering a field. This field wasn't very large, so we could see that there stood one van, alone, in the middle of the grass.   Suddenly, I hear a scream. A moment of panic. Maybe 5 seconds pass. Then I decide that I could never live with myself if I learned someone was hurt in there and I could have stopped it. I convince my friend to run over with me, and we find nothing. Hours later, I realize it had been at sunrise, next to a field in a rural area. Definitely a rooster.  Despite the ridiculousness of the story, I will always remember is that, as a stupid college kid on acid from a stranger, I cared for the health of someone I believed to be in danger above that of myself. Now that's become a standard I will hold myself up to no matter what. It's a promise to myself. I don't think I could make that promise without my experience with acid. The power of psychedelics can harm, too, but it's always important to remember that these drugs are a tool and can be used as positive influences in many people's lives.

Lack of control is a profound principle that itself teaches us about the root of our suffering: The egoic mind's identity of serving as protector of the physical vessel, through fear responses to perceived/anticipated threats.

The shrooms are decidedly IN CHARGE and they decide what is or is not dealt with, and when.  It's a constant reminder that despite what we may believe, we are not actually experts on who we are individually.  What I mean is, we think one thing in particular needs to be dealt with, but that's because we've selected the thing we'd PREFER to deal with and actively avoided another issue entirely to protect ourselves from the difficult process of dealing with it.  Psychedelics overpower us and strong-arm it in that way.  Ya just kind of have to relinquish control.  The way out is through.  Buy the ticket, take the ride, and all of that.    Your story reminds me of a similar experience.  My girlfriend and I were tripping at a commune and got separated in the woods.  She had a lifelong fear of thunderstorms, and one started while I was trying to put together a search party to find her.  It took a long time because we couldn't hear her yelling over the thunder.  By the time we finally did, hours later, she was no longer afraid of thunderstorms, ever again.  It's pretty crazy for her to be stuck, physically, facing her greatest fear alone while also tripping balls, lost and with no way up and still she come out the other side better than she went in.

I took 13g of truffles the other day and I had such profound insights.  I saw that we are all lights of consciousness swimming around in the darkness, and that lights naturally are trying to connect with other lights, and that sometimes you're not meant to connect with certain lights but you are with others, and the ones you are meant to connect with shine brighter to you than others for whatever reason.  And whilst the lights exist in a non-material realm we are bound by the physical realm which puts boundaries and constraints in place when we want to connect with other lights. Our body and the laws of physics do limit us but our profound desire to connect with other lights of consciousness is not bounded by those laws, as it comes from a different place.  So when a guy goes and talks to a girl, it's actually just a light going and talking to another light to see if there's something there. If the intention is pure and honest and curious, at least...  I saw the impurity of manipulation when it comes to trying to connect with other lights. People just want to be loved, and some in their desperate attempts to connect end up using techniques to manipulate other lights into connecting with them, but it only leads to harm, and is impure. It made me feel disgusting to think about it.  And also sadly many lights are not shining so bright because they are walking around with a digital screen in front of their face all day. They are not aware or conscious of what they, and others, are.  I saw that many lights are looking for something to hold on to - many of them are looking for another light, a strong light, something solid to hold in the darkness. A rock, a pillar.  I saw that I can be that strong light for others. I can be that pillar of strength. Instead of spending my days desperately seeking that pillar of strength outside of myself, that other light, for me to hold on to, it's better for me, and for others, to become that light they're looking for. In a wholesome way. By doing REAL WORK. And I saw that the work I had to do was not some magic pill fix. That I actually genuinely had to actively work and it would take time and effort to build the strong foundation I need to build, emotionally, financially, and in my life. There is no shortcut to construct such a foundation in the material realm, despite originating from a non-material place. The material realm provides and arena through which to enact our purpose, it provides a timeline by which to understand and utilise the past to move forward and construct our future. The mushrooms showed me what was possible and what was true. And one of those truths was that they couldn't help me do the actual work to achieve my purpose.  My purpose was to become that pillar of strength (and to realise I already am that for some people) and to breathe life back into my broken family, from a place of power, by building a solid foundation for myself to give from.

I've trip sat and guided for many different people over the years across a variety of different chemicals.  There is something very profound here that is being ignored by most of modern society.   I find it interesting that the advice that I give to people is more or less the same advice that the professionals give to people; that you need the right set and setting, and that you need to let go and let the chemical take you where it wants to go.   These chemicals shouldn't be stigmatized and they should be legal or at least decriminalized.   People can have extremely challenging and difficult experiences on them but normally it's because the person did them in a bad set or setting, they had preconceived notions about what the experience was going to be like, or they fight the drug as it tries to break their ego down.   It always blows my mind that some people consider LSD and psilocybin to be recreational drugs; maybe that makes sense at lower doses but it's just such a waste in my mind.  You have this chemical that can break open your reality and yet you use it for something so trivial which can lead to trouble.

Been in therapy and on different meds for years for my severe depression.  Had a friend convince me a while back to try LSD with them. Did a lot of reading on effects, side effects, how it functions, what it is made of, and deemed it safe enough to try.  Those 3 tabs and that 14 or so hours did more for my mental wellbeing than all the years of therapy. Felt like everything in my brain was being shaken loose and I could "see" all the surface level stuff get peeled away. It was like I was truly seeing the nature of things as they were without all the learned ideas tainting my view. I was flooded with tons of intense feelings and having to learn to experience them and let them go as all these feelings were rushing through me so that they didn't pull me into a rough trip left me with a very profound tool I can use in my day to day life and seeing things stripped of the surface level stuff, what my brain considered religion, politics, cultural ethics, national identity, etc... all that stuff we learn to think about but are really just our own constructs, has allowed me to interact with people far easier now that I approach them first as a fellow living being before addressing any of the stuff that matters far less than their inner essence.  Sure it is not for everyone, especially those with schizophrenic type disorders but for the right people approaching it with the right mindset it truly can be a life changing experience.

he means 30-40 milligrams of the pure compound which refers to the metabolite of psilocybin (4-po-4-ho-dmt) psilocin (4-ho-dmt). psilocybin cubensis the most common strain of psilocybe mushrooms consumed is roughly on average 0.65% psilocybin so a gram will have 6.5 milligrams of psilocybin so a heroic dose (5 grams) will equate to roughly 32.5 milligrams of psilocybin on average which is then converted into psilocin when it is metabolized by the liver.

I've been conducting my own scientific experiments using psilocybin and I'm very confused why you are saying that 30-40 milligrams is a heroic dose. It absolutely isn't, regardless of the patient's weight. It's not even a gram. Did you misspeak or are you misrepresenting to the public in order to prevent people from finding out on their own? Or are you worried about grant renewals not being extended based on higher doses? A heroic dose or "hero's journey" is a minimum of 1000 milligrams, and typically at least 2400 milligrams for larger/heavier individuals, up to 5 grams or 5000 milligrams (though many universities don't seem to agree with basing it on an individual's weight, but that is an oversight). Terence McKenna himself said 5 grams was the heroic dose based on his research, so this video is innacurate and it's extremely disappointing to see this coming from John Hopkins when I know they know better.

Psychedelics remove the filters that our minds use to make sense of all of the sensory input.  Our brains are bombarded with so much information that it would be difficult to function without filtering and organizing.  When you take psychedelics you probably aren't in a good position to avoid a saber tooth tiger or drive a car or do anything complex and dangerous.  On psychedelics, you can become fascinated with a flower or a painting, a song, or a rock.  Our brains dumb it all down to help us survive.  So, the thing that you learn is that the world that you know is modified and organized by your brain.  Some believe it has mystical abilities.  I don't think so.  It gives you insight into what "you" are...basically an animal with a complex brain.

A problem with ingesting foreign chemicals, even if those same chemicals may be produced within the body at smaller amounts is that one doesn't have any idea what kind of reaction one will have in a nonclinical setting. We as a species seem to 'worship' the idea of creativity but there have been many things human beings have created that have done more harm than good. So creativity isn't necessarily a 'good' thing. This presentation gives the impression that taking psychedelics is similar to gambling at their local casino with the expectation of winning and that is less likely than losing. And there's no way of knowing in advance what the reaction for a specific individual will be. I've known a number of individuals over a number of years who have regularly used mushrooms. They may experience some pleasurable moments doing so. But my observations of them over time is it changed their thinking and view of the world and not necessarily for the good.
Psychotic experience under supervision is always better than without it, if your life led you into it.

I'm 30. Started doing drugs at 9, and boy was I a connoisseur from the bat. I've done everything except weird shit from other countries (ibogaine, krokodil, w18, modern research chemicals within the last 5 years, etc.) And I've had plenty of trips where I was on like 8 or 9 substances at once. But I knew where was. I knew who was around me. I knew we were talking. After getting my life together, a friend decided to grow some penis evny mushrooms. We figured it'd be like old times, but it was like nothing I'd experienced. I truly did not exist in my own mind. There was no opening or closing my eyes, it all looked the same. I was not in reality with mountains, ducks, my parents, or anyone still reading this. I was somewhere else entirely, simply soaking in this wondrous landscape as a floating something. Like an orb or an eye or a camera or something. I've never been spiritual or religious, but I saw the universal energy that's one with us, possibly whatever string theory is trying to uncover. It was unfathomable but it appeared as some thing. We danced. It was beautiful. It was the scariest most beautiful moment of my life. I no longer party in an form, as I'm partied out for life, but I will never "party" with mushrooms again. They are something different. Something that everyone seems to come out of feeling more grounded and connected. Mushrooms are something we need to research more and educate people on because growing up as a hobbyist drug enthusiast I can tell you from experience. Nothing is that cleansing.  Synopsis - Mushrooms are not a drug, they are beautiful and they should be studied more.  Edit: Spelling

Crying for hours and hours to the extreme of feeling physical pain! I saw to some degree, a deeper nuance of evil! I must confess scary is not even close. Evil exist only and because God. Many suffering of the world ( like the Holocaust, like the natives of Africa absolutely unable and incapable of lessen the pain of their loved ones. Many people whom have died by form of torture and cruel assassination) the main question I ended up formulating was not "why?" That's the wrong question for the Main Source of Love; our Creator, God as you understand Him. Is also extremely disrespectful to question God for his decisions and ways. However the correct question is; to what end? Or what for? Or what/how are you trying to bless me via this predicament or tribulation? If you breathe, if you love, if your kids smile melts all the problems away, if you look into your significant other's eyes and find yourself IN LOVE, if you adore your mother for carrying you for 9 months and rocking you to sleep when you had a fever, if you are proud of your father whom has thought you that a spank actually scared him more than it hurt you, because he knew one day a spank was not going to be enough to keep you from the harms and twisted ways of the world, both mom and dad against their own heart HAD to let you go, out to the world and face your own mistakes but most importantly both terrified and sad that the world is the way it is, try as they might they can not change it so you can live out of harms way, now they're old man and woman, and now you being a father/mother yourself you UNDERSTAND the impotence and fear of seeing your own offspring open their wings and fly away.... Tears of the mother who ended up burying her child and not the other way around, tears of the father for the rage of having a child with terminal illness and all the money or anything he can do have absolutely no value on the realm of health. Or what about you; surrounded by people day in and day out and yet this solitude is so cold it burns your bones and the steps forward in a world of ambivalence are simply an ironic laugh of life as to remind you that almost 8 billion people right here right now in your lifetime and yet this journey is for you to walk all alone and in the darkest nights of your despair you realize that you have absolutely no one, no body in this world left for you to draw strength from and therefore some days you are BARELY hanging on by a shaky string that shows with that said empty smile you put on because you are about to snap but you try to draw strength from yourself but you're tired and all you can do is smile but you know that ANYTHING will set you off. Then the creator, and his love drag the minutes into hours next thing you know the day is over tears of solitude run down your face but you're so numb you don't even notice them anymore, confusion because a day gone means tomorrow YOU have to do it all over again.... Well wax made me realize all this, but sadly and regretfully I wanted to understand all this solitude, all this pain each and every single one of my forgotten tears, to what end? ..... What's worse; I'm still waiting for the answer, for the enlightenment, for the comprehension that all this blood fire and pain are not in vain and actually have some sort of value for which I have to go through it, because God is love, right? Because He loves me and is trying to bless me..... Only to realize that is been 3 years since this epiphanies and I know now that my answer will never come. So what is the purpose of this trip, this information this epiphanies if there's nothing I can do for/with them...... With that said, please be careful with what you put in your body. What people do not realize is that once you are able to SEE/FEEL that realm, the door is open and you simply CANNOT close it ever again....

I have found psychedelics from a 'spiritual benefit'/personal growth to be of no more value than that of having a good meditation practice. In other words, the insights/results from a good meditation are no less than psychedelics. The only thing psychedelics have on 'meditation' is that they are more entertaining, e.g. beautiful visuals, being in a completely different 'universe', like a fantastic vacation, etc. A good meditation has a better result in terms of Balance and long term results. Since you're optimizing the the most hi-tech device that there is - The human body. To me psychedelics are good for 'initiating' when one is new to the path of learning to cultivate the possibilities you have with your physical body. But if one doesn't pursue that path without the use of psychedelics, one is missing out on much benefit that psychedelics can't provide.

There's a limit to the 'heroic' dose. Meaning, for everyone there is a maximum  dose in which the experience cannot become any more intense by just taking more.  For example, aside from the potency of a mushroom that can vary from strain to strain and the growing conditions - A person may have a max hero dose of 9-12 grams. That person taking those same mushrooms of say 15-25 grams won't have a more intense experience. All that might happen is that they may feel like they have a bit of a 'hangover' /headache the next day because the body had to process more material.

¬†@chaseTheCase9¬† I did the same thing early on.  20 years ago, my second trip was a heroic dose and it was gnarly but I still had no regrets.  After 60+ trips now, I can say that it's the best way to think about it.  Even "bad" trips are good in the long run, usually.  I've found most of the difficult trips were difficult because they needed to be; ie, there was something unresolved I was hiding from, something I wasn't dealing with.

¬†@loganmott2015¬† The main purpose of having another person there is to ground you and calm you down if you start to freak out. It can still be a solo experience, but it can be difficult to get your mind back on track if your trip starts to go bad.

You are very wise to recognize the value in the therapeutic context. As someone who has had the blessing to have done so, I can say that the difficult moments are made so much more beneficial by having the trust in those around you, which allows you to focus on facing and working through the difficulty, rather than trying to avoid it. I would say that the goal of a psychedelic therapy is to hope to have those difficult moments precisely because you know that everything about you is fundamentally safe, with experts and doctors right there with you knowing what you are dealing with and verbally guiding you through the difficulty with wisdom and honed  technique.

In some ways, the effect is perhaps similar to what astronauts report when they orbit the Earth. The Overview Effect. The ego dissolves heavily, the Id is distorted, and one's shadow is layed bare before their eyes. And one's mind takes control of that process in millions or perhaps an infinity of ways. (A common conclusion of those individuals experiencing the effect feel interconnectedness with humanity and the planet, and individuality is modulated somehow.)  The potential pitfalls are that not everyone reacts to drugs in the same form, and the specificity of an experience is often incredibly consequential. (Where, when, how, etc)  I personally would not take a so called "heroic dose" of psilocin fungi or derived products. And I would never get them from questionable individuals or internet delivery.  The moderate dose and low dose mode was more than enough.  One does not simply walk into the psychedelic landscape in this modern world. Tread carefully. Stay safe. Be smart.

I never got any of those feelings while on high doses. I didn't feel universal harmony. I didn't feel like I was more in tune with nature. I didn't feel spiritual or religious. Everything that crossed my mind was squarely rooted in reality and I never felt untethered from rational thought.  However what I did feel was a powerful, childlike sense of curiosity, as if everything that crossed my mind was something I was learning about for the very first time. I felt like I was looking at my previous life experiences with fresh eyes, and that is where I made the most progress in regards to depression and anxiety. I could look into moments in my past without feeling the desire to look away, and I was able to make decisions about how I wanted to feel about the situation. I could feel differently about something without it feeling forced or sarcastic in some way. Everything felt sincere and that's something insanely difficult to achieve. It's really hard for anything to feel sincere when you have depression--even your own inner monologue. That's the real therapeutic value here.  If all we ever got from psychedelics was a vague "talk to god" moment, it wouldn't be very valuable at all. Yeah, that sounds fun, but it's not constructive. Psychedelics are so much more valuable when they're used as a tool to focus on the aspects of life that we're actually living and struggling with. Because when that happens, it can be earth-shattering from a mental health point of view.

As someone with both Chronic Depression and PTSD, I have experimented with Psilocybin. While I didn't experience the "life changing" trip as some people describe, it's absolutely impossible for me to say that it did not vastly improve my mood and my internal dialogues in ways that were profoundly helpful.
Of course, the mental health crisis is primarily due to the fact that our society and the world we've built around it is inherently broken and toxic.

I've got reservations about the idea that everyone needs to experience an "heroic dose.'"  I think a lot of people are fine without it and shouldn't think they need to.  Also, Terrance Mckenna coined that term and he was an all-out psychonaut.  Heroes often fail, and some people may not be cut out for it.  I've known people who are permanently disturbed by their psychedelic  experiences. Also, even when it is valuable, I fear that any such clinical treatments will become a privilege afforded only to the wealthy.

I grew my first mushrooms in 1980 using Matias Romero spores. I ate several large mushrooms raw, immediately after cutting them from the growth media, and had an experience that defies description. I feel the same. My brain physiology is not normative.  When I tried psychadelics in my youth I didn't have any grand revelations. As a matter of fact the experiences were quite mundane, the hallucinations were more vivid than I usually experienced in day to day life (huh, didn't realize everyone didnt get them until then), I figured out I have synthesisia because one of my tripping buddies tried to describe to me about how he could "feel" sounds.  Bass sounds were a feeling in his hands, high pitched noises were a tingling on the top of his head etc. I was like "what do you mean you can't usually feel sound? What type of sound do you usually hear when you turn to look at things quickly out of the corner of your eye? I get the sound of the ocean compressed into an instant" because my brain does that when I'm not on drugs.  I have a feeling when normies take psychedelics their brain looks something like how mine fires on a day to day basis.   When I take them I do get giggly. The closest thing I get to "consciousness expanding" and "oneness" is I get a tinge of the melting body feeling, it's like the opposite of my natural tendency towards disassociation and up tightness, it's like my brain is saying "It's OK to not put up the defenses all the time, here enjoy melting into this tree."    I can see how feeling like that in a small, controlled substance, way all the time could have great life outcomes for someone. Very calming, help you be not prone to anger etc.
