‚Äã¬†@lfgogre¬†  I can almost guarantee it's dose related. One of the recent studies actually found that low dosing doesn't produce the "brain reset" effect seen with higher doses... tho IIRC the "lower" doses in that study were closer to the "micro" range...   Anyway I do suspect a lot of people under-dose with these, tho it can be a bit tricky... because one strain can be much stronger or weaker than the last, and may even vary somewhat from batch to batch within a single strain...   Plus some people seem to respond much more strongly than others.   Anyway all that being said, the best protocol is still to work your way up from a lower dose, rather than trying to jump in at a high level when you're very inexperienced.   For average strength cubensis,   around 3 to 3.5 grams (dried weight) should be a pretty fully psychedelic dose, where you get to see most of the range of effects, but it's still not TOO crazy intense.   "3.5" used to be the standard recommendation if you wanted to see what it's all about... but a lot of people have said that 1.5 - 2.0 is a pretty enjoyable trip. Not too intense and good for dipping your feet in.   5g is pretty intense, and definitely in that "this may have long term impact" range... lol  7g is hella intense. Some may get some come up anxiety in this range lol... at 7g and up it's not uncommon for me to have some "open eyed visuals" of blatantly hallucinated colored lights... and I've also seen white light split into a prismatic rainbow, on a 7g dose. lol  (That trip was a rollercoaster, but I realized I was God, and in the end it was pretty enjoyable lol)  TBH even 7g will be too intense for some people.   Highest I did was somewhere around 9-10g, and that was kind of too much even for me... tho the circumstances were a little screwy, and those were also an unusually potent strain / batch, which I didn't realize at the time I ate them... lol  Anyway all of that info is for cubensis of average potency. However with increased legalization, some growers have developed some new strains that are easily 2x the avg potency, or more!   ... at which point 1.5g is closer to a "buckle up buttercup" dose than just dipping your feet in!   So it's a good idea to know what strain you're working with, and how strong they are.   On this note there are some dosage calculators you can find online, and there's a really good one that lists individual strains, and gives a much better idea of how they compare.   ANYWAY... I have found that the higher doses definitely give more of a reset / rebirth feeling... but even those average 3-ish gram trips can get you there...   I suspect a large part of this effect is neurochemical, however I still wouldn't discount the role of therapeutic insight...   IMHO one of the best ways to do it is to obtain or create some playlists of appropriate music, and lie in a darkened room wearing headphones, listening to music.   A- music is completely awesome on psychedelics, and maybe one of the most interesting and enjoyable things you can do.   B- Sometimes you'll focus on the music, because of how strange and awesome it sounds... but your mind will naturally start to wander...   And I find if I let it wander, I come up with various insights, and thoughts about my life. Sometimes random, but sometimes directly triggered by the music.   For this reason I think it's good to select music that is either uplifting, or reflective. Though I listen to a pretty wide range of stuff... but I have some playlists specifically intended for this purpose, that I built up over time.   (Actually usually I listen to a Beatles mix on the come up... which works for me because I'm a pretty big fan of their music, and most of it is pretty upbeat and positive... then once I'm fully immersed I usually switch over to a more eclectic mix... )  So I'll usually listen to music through most of the peak effects...   Then usually when I'm past the peak and approaching the come down phase, I'll usually smoke some weed (which kinda brings the intensity back up a bit - but forewarning, cuz THC can also make it a bit more confusing and spacy if you're still tripping) and then I'll put on a movie.   Usually something I've chosen beforehand... and using principles similar to those used for music selection. Something that may be a little trippy or visually impressive is ideal... but something that will encourage me to think or become more reflective, is usually what I'm going for...   One of my favorite trips and more memorable experiences, on the come down I watched Blueberry / Renegade... which is kind of a psychedelic western... and that one blew my mind. lol  BUT, because of the nature of psychedelics, you're more likely to become reflective no matter what you're presented with...   One time I decided to watch Donnie Brasco (which, if you haven't seen it, is the true story of an FBI agent who infiltrated the Mafia) and not only was it super fascinating and wildly entertaining... it also made me think A LOT... about the paths we take in life... morals and ethics... relative morality... identity... social groups, and how social ties impact our identity, etc etc.   And in that case it was a movie I threw on, on a complete whim - didn't plan that one beforehand. Just kinda felt like watching something, and that's what I picked...   ü§∑   (Oh and while I'm on the subject, watching the right comedy is a great way to end up with sore abs the next day! lol)  Your mileage may vary, but I've gotten quite a lot out of solo tripping, using roughly that method.   Anyway, start low and be safe...   üïâÔ∏è‚òÆÔ∏èüïâÔ∏è

‚Äã¬†@TheGoIsWin21¬† "...either trying to fight against the experience... or from being in a high stress environment..."    Yeah that's what they call "set and setting."   As in, your mind state as you're going into the experience, and the environment you use in. Ideally you want both of those things to be fairly safe and comfortable.   (And yes, if you start to freak out, you need to remember to "let go" and let the experience carry you, rather than fight it, if it starts to feel "too intense.")  Obviously tripping when you're already feeling suicidal and/or psychotic is a bad idea lol... but don't underestimate the effects of your setting. Even an experienced user who is confident, can start to feel overly anxious in the wrong environment or situation. And once that anxiety gets going, it can produce a runaway reaction, where next thing you know you're staring down the barrel of a psychedelic panic attack!   And who you trip with (if anyone) is a very common way for setting to go bad.   You don't want to be around anyone who doesn't understand psychedelics, or someone who's immature, or an a-hole, or likes to "mess with people" for fun, etc etc.   Also if the other person is tripping, their trip can go sour, and then you have to deal with that...  Actually for all those reasons (and more) I usually mostly prefer to either trip by myself, or maybe with a trusted romantic partner.   I've also had a few great trips with very close friends... but I also tend to hang out with relatively intelligent and mature people, who aren't d-bags, so there's also that... lol  Anyway, you are absolutely correct about "fighting it" though. That is another of the common ways people end up in a bad state... you start to worry... either you're tripping much harder than you expected, or you're coming up fast so you don't know yet how intense it's gonna get... maybe you start to question your dose... did I take too much? Maybe you start to question your physical safety...  If you took a very high dose, you might even start to wonder if you're dead... maybe this is the afterlife... maybe you're in hell...   Interestingly, these are not uncommon thoughts.  One time I smoked some DMT and thought I died, and I was in hell, stuck in a time loop. That was pretty terrifying.   If you're tripping hard enough it's also possible to start to worry that you broke your brain, that you're permanently insane now, or that you're going to be tripping forever...  (For this reason I find it's helpful to make a note of what time I dosed... and then a rough estimate of how long I expect the effects to last... because once you're tripping hard enough, you may have a hard time remembering what "2 AM" means, and how that relates to your current mind state... but when I can look at my note and see that I should be normal by 6AM, and it's still only 2AM, I know that it's perfectly "normal" and expected that I'm still effed out of my mind, and I've got several more hours to go lol...)  More rarely, but still possible ... is getting stuck on a certain thought or mood, and having difficulty snapping out of it. This has only happened to me a few times, but ime / IMHO this can be one of the more unpleasant ones. Even relative to "am I dead / broken" because it can be harder snap out of.   (And I think this is the one that's actually dangerous for those of us that struggle with depression etc.)  One time I somehow ended up in a state where I just felt like everything was phony and hollow, and had the hardest time snapping out of that...  Another time I made the mistake of stopping on the history channel when I was flipping through tv.. and a show about WWII quickly prompted me to start thinking about the fact that humans have been killing each other in organized brutal fashion for many THOUSANDS of years... and how many human lives ended in terror and agony on some battle field, or being graped to death by some pillaging soldier... and I just couldn't get the death and carnage back out of my brain, nor stop thinking about humans as an evil / doomed species...  So yeah, there's an element of cognitive hazard there as well, depending on how your mind works, and what cues it has to pick up on, or bounce off of...   But that's only happened to me a few times, across dozens of trips... and I'm a certified over-thinker with a pretty morbid streak!   So those are all the ways a trip can go bad... lol  But set and setting are the two big ones you have to account for...  I also feel like it helps, to start with a prayer and set an intention for the trip. Even if that's as simple as "I want to have a fun and relaxing night" But usually I'll pray that I have a safe trip, and ask for guidance and clarity of insight... and then if I have something more specific in mind, I'll mention that.   But I definitely feel like it helps to start from that more reflective, more spiritual, humble state, where I have a clear intention of where I might want to end up, and/or why I'm choosing to do this in the first place...

¬†@linamarie84¬† Well you can grow them, which isn't actually that hard if you do a little reading and preparation. These days there are even methods that work for the extra lazy beginner lol   (For example doing the "Uncle Ben's" technique and then fruiting directly from the bag.)  And spores are legal in something like all but two states in the US, so unless you're in one of those two states you can order them easily and legally.  If you didn't want to go that route... there are an increasing number of people sending dried fungi and related consumables (chocolates, gummies etc) via the net / post.  There are some sites based out of locations where laws are relaxed or legal (Canada, Washington DC, parts of Colorado and California, iirc...) that are a little more liberal in terms of where they'll send to... I've heard of and seen a handful you could easily find with a little googling...  There are also tons of people these days operating through services such as Telegram etc. However there are also tons of scammers and probably a honeypot or two as well, so I'd be extra careful if considering one of those... (both net and messenger apps. Do your research. Check trust pilot and similar resources, and see what others may have said about them. Always keep in mind however that "word of mouth" reviews can always be gamed by ambitious scammers!)  Anyway good luck out there and worry not, especially if you're in the US - more and more places are starting to decriminalize if not legalize, and it's only a matter of time on this stuff, as more people become aware and more educated on the subject...

Having taken hallucinogens of all types literally hundreds of times, I have a fundamental disagreement with this guy . In the beginning, there were basically two schools of thought as regards tripping. You had the Timothy Leary / Richard Alpert school , where you needed a "GUIDE ' to help you through the experience. To me, this was the Patriarchy writ large. Then you had the West Coast, Ken Kesey school where you dropped acid and let what was going to happen, HAPPEN. But Kesey had this caveat; If, in the middle of this amazing experience, you had to remember your Zip Code, but couldn't, you shouldn't be doing this. I have been tripping my brains out on large doses of LSD, but been forced to deal with the  "straight world" in the case of a physical emergency. And I did. THAT people, was the ACID TEST. You don't need some foo foo guide, you just need to trust yourself.

About 5 years ago I was doing quite a bit of partying. Cocain, lsd, MDA, nitrous, and drinking, pretty much everything except H, crack, or meth.  Amongst all that I started doing shrooms. I smoked cigarettes for 12 years and quit cold turkey one day. Just decided I was done. I am so glad that these substances are finally being properly investigated and brought into use. Unlike pharmacutical products, psychadelics actually CURE, not just blot out the symptoms for a few hours until your next dose.  Treating the symptoms instead of the cause makes billions of dollars for the pharmacutical companies, so they have little enthusiasm for an actual cure, particularlt one which is impossible to patent Meanwhile, you have to just live with whatever nagative side-effects happen - and some will, they always do, some worse than others. Psychadelics have either no side effects at all or at such a low level that they are insignificant. When I said "cure" I do concede that an annual "top-up" might be needed    :-)  What I would like to see is the doctors running these programs take some for themselves so that they knew what they were talking about.  How can you advise someone when you yourself cannot properly empathise with what the patient is actually experiencing? You do not need a mega dose. Just take 90mcg of LSD or 3grams of dried mushrooms and you'll have a "half-a-tab" type experience so that you at least actually understand "where they're at"  The "We are the authority, we will guide you" approach might work quite well as I assume that your patients have had no previous "trip" experience? Were I to come to you, I would have no faith in the supervision of any person who has not themselves ever tripped at all.  I would trust you to safeguard my physical health of course. When two friends trip together there is in most cases a deep bonding and empathy.  A strong shadow of that link persists long after the trip is over, possibly forever.  You two alone shared that deep experience. Having had a trip yourself, you have a much deeper and more instincive "feel" for how to handle a person who is struggling with a trip. "Vibes" are a real actual thing and can be strong when you are on a trip.  That's what I should have mentioned above when I was talking about trusting your supervision...... I think you'd give me the wrong vibes.  Not bad, hostile, whatever...... just I would KNOW that you did not know youself. Trust is essential - you can't trip with folk you do not trust.  I do realise that as a doctor, you cannot flout the law etc and if you had done you would not be able to say so  üôÇ   As your remarks above indicate, the Law, whilst ostensibly about protecting health is often driven more by political goals.

I did it about 50x during the 70's.... It "WAS" my favorite drug... I did not care for weed, depressants... I liked alcohol but never got addicted to it, it just wasn't a necessary thing.  Anyways, I did it with many people and unfortunately they were "flipping out" and getting transported to hospitals while I wasn't... I never, & they never understood why I didn't react the same way to it... I understand that no two people are exactly alike in personality, but this was peculiar to me.... Yes, I had at times bad ( scary ) thoughts on some of my experiences, but they NEVER sent me over the edge, as I had witnessed others.... The 80's came and I was nearing my 30's and nobody my age wanted to do psychedelics any more... So to me, I took that as "I had better grow up now"... But I MISSED it, and just kept my mouth shut to people about it... Up until maybe 10 years ago, there was a gigantic stigma attached to ANYONE that did it / liked it.... Now, approaching 70 I wish there was a recreational legal / safe way I could do it again....I'd still really like to know why I never "flipped out" and saw so many others who did... That still wonders me.ü§îü§îü§î  I never told anyone this, but I believe it improved me, in deep ways.. like understanding MYSELF better.... Even though my political opinions have changed in the last 3 years, lol.

What is your advice to someone fearing a bad trip?  I deeply feel that I need a mental reset. However, due to a hunting accident with my dad, I have suffered from panic attacks since I was 15 (I'm 27 Now). Haven't had a panic attack in years but I'm worried that the psychedelics will pull it out of me.

¬†@rarecandy9473¬† the psychedelics may pull it out of you, and that‚Äôs the point. The mushrooms will make you face your fears head on, and it‚Äôll be scary and maybe even downright frightening, BUT I PROMISE that when it‚Äôs done and over with, you‚Äôll feel like a totally different and new person. Mushrooms, LSD, and nn-DMT have totally changed my life.

‚Äã¬†@rarecandy9473¬† I think "bad trips" are feared and can manifest when unconscious trauma comes up if you don't know how to process it, and it can cause anxiety and panic attacks (which I've experienced a lot of). It's hard to give advice without much insight of course but I'd recommend if you can, writing down what you're scared of beforehand and trying to figure out ways you can remedy or self-soothe, even affirmations can help. I'd suggest mushrooms over acid and maybe one or two smaller doses a week or so before a bigger trip so you can consciously tap in and out of certain emotions without it being too overwhelming. I've tripped with intention and helped myself reflect and recover from certain things in my life by focusing on that thing and how I can move on from it/ forgive etc. I used to experience severe panic attacks in the beginning because I had no sort of guide or good influences around or had even been to therapy before. From my experience, it can be overwhelming for older people who haven't delved into their trauma before so it can be confronting and overwhelming because it all just suddenly surfaces after years of compartmentalising/ believing that they've gotten over it or are a different person now. That's why i think easing into doing a big trip might be good for you if you've been prone to panic attacks. But coming from someone who had panic attacks and severe anxiety and depression I've never had anything else help more than psychedelics and by experiencing severe emotions or situations on them it improves your reality by developing stronger processes and soothing techniques. Hope that was at least somewhat helpful lmk if I can be more specific .

I'm a combat veteran who has been diagnosed with fairly severe PTSD and its associated depression. Micro-dosing with psilocybin has been hugely beneficial, but it is not something to be done by the patient alone. I can't stress it enough: Just like antidepressants and all of the other meds used to treat these issues, simply ingesting certain compounds is not the answer. The patient absolutely must be actively participating in ongoing therapy as well. This includes such approaches as one-on-one counseling (think of the Freudian approach, with the patient lying on a sofa and talking through their issues while guided by a licensed therapist), CBT (Cognitive Behavioral Therapy), which teaches the patient how to reorganize and reprogram their thought processes, to other specific courses of treatment. But the ongoing input of a properly trained staff of therapists and doctors is the only way I have found to even begin unraveling the "rat's nest" of nastiness and negativity that takes up residence in the patient's solar plexus (the spot just below the center of the ribs, where even a slight impact can cause a person to "have the wind knocked out of them"). And the use of small doses of psilocybin, when combined with proper counseling, has provided me with some serious personal breakthroughs in my treatment.  One further caveat, regarding the correct dosage of psilocybin: If you can tell that you have the drug in your body, then you've taken too much. Remember, you should be trying to heal your mind and body -- and your soul, for those who subscribe to the existence of a soul. You should not be attempting to "trip" on psilocybin, as this could potentially lead to the worsening of your symptoms.

My theory based on hundreds of hours of research and self reflection is my dopamine receptors were dormant and unable to process my bodies natural dopamine. The drug over loaded my brain with dopamine to the point it had to activate and process it.  The biggest physical change I went through was digestive. I relied on medication to eat. @Yo Mama the word "guru" is misused and overly used in a wrong way. It does not mean "teacher". From a complete lack of understanding, people including fake sadhus call themselves guru. However in present day, there is a complete misunderstanding of it. They associate it with 'holy man' and other nonsense. However just because they don't understand something, doesn't give them a right to use it as a negative name.

I am a firm believer in the medical efficacy of psychedelics for PTSD, mental illness and depression because I have seen it first-hand change people's lives for the better. Now that being said the "heroic dose" is fraught with all kinds of problems and probably could be a waste or dangerous misuse of these important class of drugs. The testing of psychedelics on drug addicts and alcoholic prisoners without their knowledge both with - were given these "heroic doses" many had "permanent trips" psychological breakdowns and other long term mental problems. So that was an indicator of what can occur with the "heroic dose" but probably to get the therapeutic benefits this is not necessary or even wanted.

The key is being open to the experiences you will have. I went through a range of emotions and experiences on my first trip, and I'd do it all again. First of all test whatever you are taking to confirm that it's the real thing. Once you had that down, understand the fact that they do little to no physical harm to you. Once you understand this fact deeply, you should remember this everytime you think something is wrong. The last thing is setting and your mentality. Always do it in a comfortable setting where you don't have to interact with strangers/sober people who aren't already trip sitting you (please only let someone trip sit you if they know what they are doing. Never let someone who don't know how to act around someone who is tripping to affect your trip badly. its better to do without one or to also trip with a person or multiple people who you trust well than have an inexperienced sober trip sitter). Once the setting is all great as mentioned, remember to let go on your trip. When you trip don't resist anything that it's trying to show you because the more you resist, your mind will start thinking "this is bad" which is what most of the time causes a bad trip. When you let go even if something appears scary, explore it and let it take you wherever it wants to take you. Wishing you Happy travels!

I disagree about the concept of a "Bad Trip" I've had hundreds of mushroom trips over the course of the last 5 years. And I've learned one thing for sure. They will force you to confront all the things you've ignored, repressed, or convinced yourself aren't in your head, whether you like it or not. I've had trips where I felt physical pain from the things I was thinking about, I've had trips where I've puked and felt scared. I learned to open myself to those feelings, sickness, pain, fear. Feel them fully and deeply in my heart. And when those trips ended? I felt amazing, weightless, uplifted. The only time I had a truly bad trip where I felt terrible afterwards was one where I went in with the expectation of sex from someone who wasn't interested in me at all, and I had convinced myself that they were, I treated the mushroom trip not like medicine, but background music to the shit I wanted to do. One of my earliest trips. I never made that mistake again.  If you respect the mushrooms, and what you're doing, and go into the experience with the understanding that you cannot anticipate what will happen in your head and you absolutely have to roll with whatever occurs, you'll be fine. Better than fine.  Its not recreational. It's medicinal. Use it with no fear, an open heart, and no expectations, and I promise you. You'll be okay

Stop interweaving fear into your speaking. Your message shouldn't be, "While psychedelics are good, they need to be administered by credentialed authorities." No, they don't. Those are simply moments where you confront the traumas of your life and are reborn. Yes, there's weeping and gnashing of teeth, but that's a good trip because it leads to a very good place. Here's my breakthrough experience, 7g dried mushrooms with some tolerance from dosing a few days before hand, 2 sugar cubes of LSD of unknown Ug (who can truly know anyways). After going through a loop of laying in bed under a blanket getting too hot ripping my shirt off going to the sink chugging water attempting to vomit getting cold putting my shirt on getting in bed under the blanket rinse repeat who knows how many times I eventually couldn't get up, stared at one spot on my bed and poof, everything's black. An orb of light begins to materialize in the black slowly, and I realize I am that orb. I accept that this is death, I've somehow overdosed on psychedelics.Then a web materializes, made of what appears to be electricity. I begin to move along the lines of this web and when the orb hits an intersection I'm transported to a childhood memory so vivid I'm living it, but I have no control. This repeats for a number of cycles, then it stops being "my" memories. I start to experience moments foreign to me, as if they're my memories, of people in previous time eras. This cycle continues until finally poof, I'm back in my bed. It took quite a bit of time for me to realize, holy shit I'm alive. I calmed down with drugs a lot after that

Here is my fullest experience the first time I took mushrooms: ‚ÄúIt started with some very ‚Äútrippy visuals‚Äù. Everything looked very clear and slightly distorted. I moved my hand in front of my face and could see a trail of hands moving behind it. I went to go to bed and heard a chime. Like a bell in a town square. I heard this bell three times over the span of a few minutes. It felt like the bell was in the distance, then near me, then in my skull. I went to bed and put some music in my ears. There was a small blue dot flickering and zigzagging across my field of vision. Suddenly, it vanished. It kind of ‚Äúpopped‚Äù away, like a bubble. I was listening to music and staring at the dark wall in front of me. I was laying down. The wall started to expand forward, then come back, then go a little further, then come back. The wall expanded forwards to a point where it made a hallway. A hallway from an old mansion or old hotel or something. Hard wood floors and darkly painted walls. Sconces on either side of the hallway in pairs, all carrying a dim flicker of light emanating from a wax candle wick. I was still laying down. My bed started moving down the hallway. The flickering flames were moving past me as I moved down the hallway. After a few minutes and passing many doors and candles on the sides of the hallway, I came to a door at the end of the hallway. This door was illuminated by a bright white light behind it. It opened and I moved through. As I entered the door I saw a great white flash of light and I appeared in a garden. I was in the middle of a green garden with two very old trees on either side of me. Lots of bricks and stone patterns on the ground. And beyond the trees were these massive hedges or shrubs, they must‚Äôve been 50 feet tall. In front of me was a series of archways, with plants and vines and leaves and flowers growing around them. I walked down the stone path through 3 archways and came to a maze. The shrubbery was all around me and still about 50 feet tall. I spent what felt like 15-20 minutes trying to find my way out. There was a very small amount of golden sunlight coming through the shrubs, illuminating my path. I came to an archway at the end of the maze and walked through it. Next thing I knew, I was out on this huge terrace. One solid slab of stone, with stone guard rails all around. There was a fountain in the middle of the terrace and many stone statues but I couldn‚Äôt make out who they were statues of. I went to the edge and leaned on the rail. The sun was very bright and warm for a brief moment, and then the clouds all around started becoming dark. I felt the rumble of thunder and saw the flash of lightning. The wind picked up and I was blown over the edge. I was falling and falling for about 5 minutes. I first fell through dark blue stormy clouds with bright lightning and slashing rain all around me. The clouds eventually turned to a pale yellow. Here, I was falling from heaven, into the pale yellow which seemed to be earth. I was falling through these pale yellow clouds with objects and people whirling all around me. Earthly things. A few minutes later, the clouds started to change into a subtle orange and then a really deep and scarlet red. I saw a flash of red and was in a very rocky, hot, and fiery place. I appeared behind a small stone structure, and beyond it I could see a silhouette of a giant creature, in front of a flickering flame. The creature got closer and became easier to see. It must‚Äôve been 100 feet tall. It was a dragon, with deep green scales and huge sharp claws. It was walking on all fours. The dragon had the wings of a bat, and the head was a combination of a black lion‚Äôs head with the fangs and tongue of a serpent. I felt fear for a moment, and suddenly my fear disappeared entirely. I was no longer afraid of this creature, and in turn, no longer afraid of death. Then I was warped away. I imagine that place to have been hell. I went through a vortex of bright lights and subtle colors and next thing I know the sky in front of my cracked and broke like a mirror. Behind this were three giant hooded figures. Bigger than any skyscraper I have ever seen. They were looking over me. Almost inspecting me. I was warped away one more time and ended up back in the room and in the bed I was in. I turned my music off and went to sleep.‚Äù

I agree 100% with the complete decriminalization of all non-synthetic psychedelics and have a lot of experience with their hugely beneficial effects. That being said, I think what scared people, was that the explosion of psychedelics in the '60s & '70s, was accompanied by THOUSANDS OF ACTUAL EXPLOSIONS happening alongside the "Hippie" movement in the US.   For some reason, the general public seems to only get the two extreme "fringe" versions of our own history. On the "left" it was the peaceful educated youth protesting the Industrialized war machine & preaching the benefits of vegetarianism, cooperation & caring for our fellow man.   On the "Right" it was violent riots, bombings, fires, rampant STI's & the huge spike in overdoses & psychotic breaks occurring in the ER's,  that seemed to resonate.  To this day most, people seem to skim over the 2,500 bombs detonated in the late '60s in this Nation, and the simple fact that there was legitimate reason for middle America to become very Leary (pun intended) of the use of psychoactive drugs by their kids.

I call it the Pinnacle of Truth. He told me ancient lessons of life, the meaning of it, and reassured me of my path in life. Shortly after, I had tomes of ancient knowledge transcribed into my mind from the Golden Libraries of the Universe, these were golden scrolls of ancient text that looked like cuneiform being channeled into my brain -- the downloading of knowledge that taught me lessons of individualism, equality, love, and selflessness.  A hero dose is like a DMT trip for 4 hours -- funny thing is, psilocybin is DMT with a hydroxyl (-OH) group -- take enough of it, and you'll blast off. The way I describe it to people is this: After feeling cold, numb ,and grey inside from dealing with years of stress - it felt nice to notice how the sun felt warm on my skin. That feeling had always been there, but it had been drowned out by all the negative thoughts over the years. Feeling and acknowledging that warmth on my skin reset my view on life; I began to notice and appreciate the beauty in life and it felt like that gray cloud of stress and depression that had grown in my head slowly dispersed, revealing clear skies. Edit: I didn‚Äôt expect this to get as many responses as this did. Thank you to everyone who interacted. To clarify a few things, psilocybin was not the sole reason I was able to pull myself out of that really low point in my life. I was worn down from engineering school and failed relationships (those mainly failed due to my dedication to my schoolwork). Before engineering school I had been putting myself through the wringer for 5 years prior, all to focus on my goal to be accepted into engineering school in the first place. So about 10 years of just being stressed left me feeling emotionally numb and disconnected. Even after I graduated, started my career, and continued with therapy. I felt empty. I was able to work through most symptoms of depression and anxiety but life still felt bleak. It wasn‚Äôt until my experience with psilocybin that I finally made the breakthrough I needed to make my way towards a happy and healthier life. That was on top of the years of therapy and trying different medications. So I was on the general right path, but psilocybin just lifted that fog and reconnected me so that I can really pursue a happiness. It‚Äôs hard to find happiness if you forget what it feels like. Psilocybin reminded me of what happiness felt like.  I don‚Äôt recommend self-medicating. I‚Äôm not a doctor but everyone‚Äôs mind and body are different. But if you do, I would start with small doses and increase the dose over time until you are familiar with how your mind and body react to it. You will be confronted with heavy thoughts and emotions so it‚Äôs important to be somewhere you feel safe and comfortable beforehand. I would also recommend having someone to call in case you do feel overwhelmed and need some reassurance that you‚Äôll be okay. It‚Äôs important to read some different online sources to get an idea of what a good low dose would be for you to try . I‚Äôm about 3 years into my career now and I‚Äôm living an overall happier and healthier life. It still took work and self-reflection to reach this point but as I stated before, it‚Äôs easier to find happiness if you at least know what you‚Äôre looking for. Much love to everyone, and I wish you luck on your life journey.

Psychedelics can be incredibly transformative and life-affirming, but it really depends on the psychology of the user. People who struggle with introspection & emotional regulation can either have incredibly painful (yet necessary) experiences or full-on psychotic episodes. And then there's people who don't derive any deep insights whatsoever; to them, psychedelics are just another chemical escape from reality they'll use alongside opiates, amphetamines, booze, etc. That said, if you're someone who is capable of healthy introspection & likes to pursue self-growth, shrooms & LSD can be force-multipliers in terms of emotional & spiritual progress. Speaking personally, psychedelics have helped me totally conquer feelings of existential dread & ego rigidity.   I now KNOW for a FACT our egos are semi-persistent illusions that shouldn't be taken so seriously; that little mental avatar you imagine when you think of "you" isn't real, and to me, that's incredibly liberating to realize.

Has anyone experience with giving this to someone with dementia or cognitive decline? I was effortlessly snatched from the death grip of alcoholism by a heroic dose of psychedelics six years ago. I had tried smaller doses of both LSD and Psilocybin before my heroic dose, I had paddled my feet in the water and wanted to see how deep the water got after doing some serious research on the drugs, so one day out at my friends property in the woods I went for a hike after I ate 8 grams of mushrooms then immediately put 1200ug of LSD under my tongue when I was particularly frustrated with my desire to drink, since my previous trips had given me a short reprieve from cravings (meaning I only drank enough to stop the shakes for a few days, and not get shitfaced drunk, more like heavily buzzed) and made me feel a bit more upbeat. Little did I know the horrendously powerful experience I was in for! Never in my life have I been so tortured by my own subconscious self as I was during that trip, for the first time in my life since I started seriously drinking over a decade before that had I ever had to face the wrath of my own self conscious, looking at myself as if I was judging a different person standing in front of me, seeing all the damage I had done to myself, my body, my brain, my soul, and worst of all, those that loved me. I immediately had my family take me to a detox center where I stayed for two weeks where they drained all the alcohol vapors from my head, and ever since I had that trip and stepped out the front door of that facility I have not struggled one tiny bit with alcohol addiction, not once. These horrible, evil, destructive, illegal and downright wicked non-addictive drugs, in one fucking dose mind you, saved me from one of the worst (and legal!) addictive drugs in existence, alcohol, yet they are the bad drugs? My love for the leaders of country wanes every single goddamn day...  And just to be clear, I haven't attended a single AA meeting or any kind of support group. I took the drugs, went to detox, and now don't have a second thought about alcohol if I see it. I can even have a couple beers on special occasions but that constant urge for more is completely gone, it's like a switch was thrown in my brain and then superglued into the off position.  And aside from being my savior from addiction, psilocybin has done wonders for my mental health too, I used to be dosed to the gills with antidepressants when I was a teen, and I really wish I had the guts to try mushrooms back then because that's the only antidepressants humanity needs, the long-term boost to happiness is incredible when you think about it, it's a drug that keeps you happy for weeks instead of hours, is non-addictive, has no toxicity, and grows in nature. It doesn't get better than that.

I love psychedelics. To me they are on the same level as technology. Ultimate power, they can create a beautiful new world or destroy it all, it depends on the user. Psychedelics saved me from myself in more ways than one and has given me an unexplainable understanding for art, love, beauty, ect that I likely would've never known otherwise. However, a bad trip can have the opposite effect. One bad trip made me HATE my best friend from childhood because my tripping mind convinced me he stole $10 from me. I've seen "demons". There have been stories of bad trips leading people to kill their loved ones or jump out of windows in very extreme cases. I understand as I have felt that on some level during a bad trip. The Aztecs would consume mushrooms before ritual sacrifice. We need to integrate, with extreme caution, psychedelics into the mainstream. It would do us tremendous good

And then there's my brother, who "hero dosed" himself into irreversible brain damage.  He's lost everything; his sanity, his wife, kid, all connections to family and friends in his quest to not only connect all conspiracy theories (except flat earth, because that's to 'catch the stupid ones'), but also to prove to himself and everyone that he's a messiah who holds all the keys.  What started as something relatively focused as building a 'psychic pyramid to connect with the aliens in Saturn' has devolved into this reality not being born yet, where everyones parents are reversed, history is fiction and the mother of his child has been replaced by a demon.  He's tried to build an army of real life astral projection warriors to defeat his enemies, and decides everything through muscle tests, constantly flicking his fingers to figure out what to do next.  He has trouble controlling his emotions and is prone to violent outbursts.  And he absolutely positively can not and does not want help with any of this.  Imagine if this was your brother, or husband, or son.  How scary and exausing that would be.  There's still so so much more that we need to learn about psilocybin and psychedelics, and in this age misinformation the danger of mis-use is right up there with the potential therapy that can be had.  This is something everyone needs to remember as we move forward, instead of simply screaming "legalize this now!" There's reason why our brains have receptors for these compounds. If we as human beings wasn't supposed to experience these sacred journeys then we wouldn't have receptors in our brains. When something so small makes you raise your vibration to match the experience it's going to show you, to where it literally fills you literally full of the vibration of love to the point you love the dust on a window to the dirt on the ground, as it done for me one night when honestly set and setting was completely wrong but I knew for some reason taking the 9 grams I did would change my night. As it did.  Everyone in the house I was at was arguing and fighting. To the point I finally just lost it and I never laughed so hard. My ex showed up and she at some point started hitting me and kicking me. Guess what I did? Laughed even harder. So I had to use the restroom. Went in and did what I had to. Washed my hands. Then looked into the mirror. Anyone who's taken these journeys knows looking into a mirror typically isn't good. This time I was in aww. I loved who I saw in the mirror more than I could ever have imagined. The person in the mirror was as beautiful as anything else that I saw that night and everything that night was equally as beautiful. Then I had the thought of my ex pounding on me and from what I was told I was in the bathroom for about 45 minutes laughing my ass of hard. To me was a split second. When I come out the whole house was asking me wtf  was laughing at and why I'm so happy. Only thing I could say was they needed mushrooms like me. Or of the funnest journeys I've took with mushrooms themselves. Nothing that nigg could change my vibe or happiness. Honestly nothing hit me as being negative for about a month and a half after either. I noticed what would typically scratch me or hit me as being negative in any way didn't for a while after that. Set and setting are everything when taking these sacred teachers. For me myself that night it was needed. I'm a firm believer that when one knows how these sacred plants work and how the journey is going at it alone even with a room full taking the same thing, what most would call a bad trip was truly what the individual themselves needed to experience. The bring so much positivity because how they seem to make the individual themselves face the things they never released by storying them in the closet. Until the individual themselves truly faces these things and accepts and takes full responsibility for what ever it is they can never truly release these things in a way they don't become attachments. I want to start this by saying that I am still struggling daily with psychological issues and self-hate. Psychedelics are not a cure all and shouldn't be seen as that. Having said that, I've definitely had life-changing experiences on psy's, particularly LSD.   One particular trip I will never forget was me physically walking in circles, while mentally walking around a truth that I had to see eye to eye. I was ~30 years old at the time and had accomplished nothing of substance that would be viewed as successes in today's society. I kind of knew what it was that I was evading. But at some point I broke through and had the guts to face it; I had the constant nagging belief that my life wasn't worth anything and that probably, I just wanted to die. I was literally circling around a decision point; Life or Death. It felt so real and HUGE and so, so scary. Once I reached the center of the spiral I finally realized, truly realized,  that I did not want to die. That I wanted to keep on fighting.   An immense strange mix of relief, hope, but also grief and intense sadness, for all the missed chances I already had in life, filled me up. I can never overstate how intense and overwhelming all these emotions were. I had always been a person with a fairly flat affect; emotions were very fleeting and most of the time the only real feeling I knew was just emptiness, probably just chronic depression. This was the most emotion I had ever felt and it was so freeing, but so uncomfortable at the same time.  After this realization, probably 4-5 hours into the trip, I just started crying uncontrollably. I've always had problems crying. I can probably count the number of cries in all my adult life up to then on one hand. I must've stood in my bathroom, looking myself in the eye in the mirror, crying, for at least 30 minutes (maybe an hour even), profusely apologizing to everyone I knew, and especially to myself, for treating myself so badly over the years with self-hate and self-criticism after setting myself unobtainable goals and requirements. All out loud I was apologizing to myself and starting to forgive myself for everything.   After this trip, nothing has been the same. I've developed an, although subtle, empathy for myself and others. I have learned to be more truthful to people about my competences and my shortcomings. And about the real reasons behind my actions. And through that I've learned that people are much more empathetic when you're just honest about all these things.  The hard part is the integration, which for me, a couple of trips and 7 years later, is still ongoing. I still have difficulties trusting people, and trusting myself. I still find it hard to get up in the morning to actually do stuff and fight through the lack of motivation. But, I started a job that might give me good opportunities the coming years to develop myself and live up to my potential. I feel a little bit less shame for who I am and actively observe my shame and realize that it's unfounded.   So, to conclude, the trip was an AMAZING experience and has had effects that I feel no other experience could've triggered. The lingering results are subtle, but noticable. It maybe saved my life. It was the catalyst for quite rapid growth over the years. Once in a while I still do an LSD trip for evaluation and I doubt I will ever stop doing this.  EDIT: I feel it's responsible to add that psychedelics are no child's play. Please don't take psychedelics thinking you're gonna cure your mental issues. Educate yourself, also read about the bad experiences (there are tons of them), take precautions, prepare. Heck, go talk to your MD if you're set on doing it.

When I was 19, I was really into psychedelics.  One summer night, I made a pb&j sando with 7.5 grams.  Off I went.  I sang a lot that night.  Performed my songs on my acoustic in a room full of ‚Äòlike-minded‚Äô friends who loved listening to me play. Very warm atmosphere. We all drifted off into our own worlds eventually.  Then more music on the comedown.  And then, around 6am, as the sun was rising, buddy arrived with a 10 strip of gelcaps (LSD) and we all ate one. We were at a lake house that had a deck boat and two JetSki‚Äôs. I hopped on a JetSki and went tearing ass all over this lake, which was calm as glass. For anyone who has never been on a JetSki in calm water, it‚Äôs like being on a motorcycle only you can crash and it‚Äôs just more fun. Now imagine that experience while you are frying away lol. After a while, I wiped out. As I lay in the water, staring at clouds waltzing together above me, in the sky, a friend of mine swam up to the JetSki, climbed on it and sped off. Left me alone in the middle of this lake, floating on my back. I probably lay there floating for a good half hour with the sun rising on my face, listening to the sounds of life waking up. After a while they came back and picked me up on the boat. It was just an absolutely beautiful night and beautiful morning. I am probably lucky to be alive. I was a very reckless young man, to say the least lol. But I sure had a lot of fun and I had a lot of amazing experiences. And I‚Äôm pretty sure my adolescence would have been far more painful, I‚Äôve had it not been for nights like that.

I'm proof that it works for depression. I've been chronically ill and in chronic pain since I was about 10 years old and assumed I would never not be chronically depressed... because I will never not be in chronic pain and illness. I was able to face all the trauma I experienced losing my mom to cancer and cried harder than I think I ever will again in my life... and the next day I felt a million times better, lighter.. I had such a better perspective and understanding of what I'd been through, and what my dad went through losing her, and since then have repaired my relationship with him that was previously so bad we could not even speak for about 3 years after her death. This has been a miracle for me. It did the thing nothing and nobody else could do. I had completely treatment-resistant depression and NO reason for it to ever go away.. because you're usually pretty depressed if you're in chronic pain and it's a lifelong condition for me with EDS! I'm just hoping and praying that this research and work gets done as quickly as possible so that people can start having access to this absolutely miraculous and life-saving medicine. I had my 1st heroic does (plant medicine) exp a number of years ago when I was in my late 30's. I felt like I was one with the Universe and the creator. A good Shaman/Guide will never try to influence your exp. Thats your own direct exp. A true Guru will only guide and empower you. However, I was told a story by someone I knew who had gone to different countries in South America to work with Ayahuasca.   He had worked with this plant 100s of times with different tribes in the deep Amazon jungle. These are places where you will not see any tourist as you can only go with the tribe's permission, which is very difficult.  He shared his experience of working with these tribal elders one time.    They give you the brew and put you in a hut by yourself. You are all by yourself for the whole exp. Then the next day he sat with the elders of the tribe and as he was talking to them through a translator he was stunned when the elder, a shaman of the tribe was able to describe his experience in great details and as to what and why he saw in his trip. This just blew his mind, and it blew mine too, to hear this story. Some things are very difficult to explain. I can only say that it sounds like real Shaman, medicine men (who has worked with the medicine for many years, generations) who are very rare to find these days have serious psychic powers as they are able to get into your dreams, thoughts and experiences while you are on the medicine. ¬†@travisumbel6877¬†  Yes, you are correct, to me there is no difference between a good and a bad trip, it's just tripping, but what worries me is individual tolerance. I've done 5g of shrooms and even then just 1g can still hit me like a ton of bricks and don't get me started on acid which can completely melt your sense of reality on higher doses. When I first did psychedelics and it eliminated my depression I also thought "why doesn't everyone do this", but after more experiences and seeing how crazy it can really get I realized that someone who does a low dose might still get a very intense trip and they might not have the mental fortitude to not reject it and freak out. This stuff isn't candy or like smoking weed, it can be extremely pleasurable or just straight up agony for several hours. I think these things shouldn't be done unless you feel it deep inside that you are really ready for it, when your head is clear so nothing would pollute your mind and that you are ready to let go of your normal understanding of reality, because no words or youtube videos can really prepare you for the experience, it really feels like straight up magic. But for first timers always trip when you're in a good mood, always trip in a place where you feel safe and know nothing can go wrong and always trip only when your body says yes, if you have any doubts or if you second guess , then your experience might be vastly different to the one you are hoping for. Once you already have experience and know what you're dealing with the "bad trips" might not be so disturbing or have any negative consequences, but a bad trip on your first time can leave a sour taste in your mouth forever.

¬†@kohakugawazy¬† That's now how it works, in terms of "achievement".  We are dealing with differences in perspective, really: Seeing things differently. The easiest analogy is that having experience in psychedelics is like having read a book someone else didn't: You have a perspective and knowledge they do not, for not having read the same things. What you do with that knowledge or how that knowledge manifests in your own life will vary by individual.   Two different people with two different lives take the same dose...both experience an intense connection with their surroundings, the people in their life, and see themselves without any doubt or fear as they truly believe themselves to be, at their core...the next day, one person realizes "I need to do more with my life!" and the other says "I need to slow down and work less and spend more time on the little things"...and neither is wrong. It's all relative and there are no magic answers for everyone (other than "Be kind and love yourself"). The "knowledge" or information you gain from psychedelics is personal and intimate and not applicable outside of you and won't result in a single measurable change...you just gain a new perspective, and that perspective may help other things in your life make more sense, or become less of a worry.

¬†@ryandavids1129¬† What if, as a hypothetical example, your "bad trip" was the only type you could experience, at that time, because of an abundance of fear and doubt in your mind and an inability to surrender control over your surroundings and thoughts...whether you were cognizant of those issues going into the trip, or not? That can be just as telling as someone walking outside and feeling connected to the grass beneath their feet or the birds moving through the sky.  I think when people say it would "benefit anyone" it is a sincere belief...there is just an asterisk* that needs to be stated: What benefit you derive may not be enjoyable to experience and may surprise you and you may be unprepared.  Whether someone can benefit from what they experience doesn't undermine the nature of the experience or the value it can offer...not unlike how you can lead a horse to water but cannot make them drink. If it wasn't a good time and you learned nothing from it that can be your take away...but that doesn't speak to the molecule or the experience itself, just how you reacted to it during, and after. Whether you choose to think about or learn from what you experienced, and why, is up to you and if you can derive a benefit from that is up to you.

When I look at the world of today, arguably largely a product of the 70s and 80s, and in turn, of psychedelics and a surge in drug-use (legal and non legal), I have to wonder if we're treating a problem within ourselves, or whether we're diluting a healthy response to an unhealthy society. I can't see any correlation between  prosperity, personal or communal, and the use of psychedlics, and whilst a lot of great music and art came from the 70s / 80s, when you pry for information, it seems it was also a time in which some of the darkest and most sinister human acts in all our history occurred.  Following an abnormally hopeless childhood, I'm an abnormally resilient person when it comes to my mind. I've tackled my problems one by one, sober, and the key element has been the care and support of the people around me. I'm evolving and prospering as a result. When I look at everyone else, absolutely everyone I see, they treat their problems with drugs, and all I see is people being disarmed and blinded. Many find happiness, but it is not enduring. It requires constant use of the drugs, and many other conditions of comfort and stability. I haven't seen this work for unlucky people.  They're apathetic, disarmed, and disconnected from each other. This leads to ideological isolation, and worse, fear. This seems to cause almost all problems the people I see are dealing with. In the moment there's empathy, 'woke'ness, seeing things that others don't see, but they're also missing blatant truths about our nature and what we are. Social creatures. We designed to be collaborators.   I still know so little about human nature, but I will continue to observe and hopefully learn more.

I was 19 in the Marine Corps, 2 years at a duty station, feeling stuck in my position and depressed with alcoholism lingering on the horizon. I tried mushrooms on leave one time and realized how incredible it was on my life. A year later, still in the Marines, I took 10 grams of dried mushrooms, a ‚Äúheroic dose‚Äù, and had the veil lifted on my reality. I grew up extremely conservative and narrow minded with racist, misogynist indoctrinations as a child and teenager. But after that trip, I began the process of transitioning out of the military and focused my life on becoming more centered and peaceful. It increased my self awareness as well as my ability to gain perspective for and from others. It single-handedly was the most prophetic moment of my life and I owe my creative career as a chef and now mushroom farmer to that heroic dose. It wasn‚Äôt the prettiest experience, honestly it made me psychotic for a brief period. But when the realities of the universe are plainly laid before you on the table, it‚Äôs difficult to grasp and understand them at the time. Psychedelics hold an integral part in mine and so many others lives, I‚Äôm amazed that they aren‚Äôt legalized yet, at the very least for their medicinal value.

The heroic dose for me personally was in 1999, it was a few years after I had gotten the PF TEK Psilocybin Cubensis grow book and spore syringe in the mail for $10.  I quickly bought the supplies for around $100 and within a few months was growing about an ounce a month.   Before long my apartment was filled with aquarium diy terrariums for fruiting the mushroom cakes.  Eventually I got into mass growing using mini fridges and ultrasonic humidifiers and stepped it up to about a half pound of dessication dried mixed genetics psilocybin cubensis mushrooms of 4 types of spores I'd acquired from a JLF catalog and elsewhere.    The heroic dose came in one night when a friend and my current wife and I decided to go to the Pink Floyd laser light show.  We were having beers and smoking my fine homegrown cannabis beforehand when I accidentally ingested all three of our doses (and I had ridiculously low tolerance to begin with)  As we were waiting in line I started almost stroking out and falling down... and subsequently had a bad time for a few days.   It was about 3 days later when I went completely religious, this lasted about 6 months and subsequently I've been blessed with a positive outlook, a nearly photographic memory, and an innate ability for creativity, ideas, and inventions.  Not sure if it's related but I've always attributed some of it to that experience.  That is all, thank you for joining me for a little while.

This is the story about my experience with magic mushrooms ((S.I. TRIGGER WARNING)):  I first wanted to try magic mushrooms when I heard these kinds of potential benefits that psychedelics could have in treating depression. There were lots of promising stories online of people allegedly curing their depression and finding newfound hope and a love for life. It sounded too good to be true, especially for me. I had no luck with anything to improve my mental illness in the past, and was on the verge of using my way out. So, I was in need of a miracle.  I tried magic mushrooms as soon as I could, on the edge of my depression and s.i.. Someone I knew got me about 1.5 grams and they stayed with me when I took it. When I experienced nothing, no trip, no improvement to my mood (which supposedly last for weeks), I fell even deeper into my depression. I'd been trying to get my hands on magic mushrooms for months since I'd heard of its potential and when it didn't work I didn't know if or when I would just give up and take my own life.  Before that dose, I had already committed to growing my own mushrooms, believing they'd help as everyone would have had me believe. A number of weeks later, my mushrooms were ready and I could try a higher dose. I thought my first dose just wasn't high enough. So, again I tried and I didn't feel anything. The next day I doubled the dose and still felt nothing. The third day I increased it again (I think to maybe 6-7 grams). I still didn't feel anything. I crossed my fingers and decided to try to give myself several days before I tried again. Long story short, that worked. I felt the affects. First it made me really sad, then it made me really happy. This was the only time it made me feel happy. I didn't have lasting positive effects to my mood. From then on, they would only make me feel worse.  Microdoses made me anxious, and trips pushed my depression and SI to its limits. Finding that out, I planned to use it as a way to push myself to go through with my "plan". Only, that didn't work either.  My latest trip, a couple of weeks ago, I took more than a heroic dose and I broke my mind. My visual processing was extremely delayed and slushy, as was my sense of space/touch. I couldn't walk or talk properly. Everything I've learned about reality seemed useless, and I was so anxious that I thought I permanently damaged my brain or ended up in hell before I even followed through with my plan. Everything looked and felt wrong. It lasted for hours. On the comedown, I realized it was only a trip, but my visual processing was still completely off and I wasn't sure if my sight would fully restore. I had to sleep with that uncertainty. Thankfully it did restore, else I wouldn't be able to type this out, let alone unlock my phone..  Magic mushrooms have done nothing but cause me more pain as if to mock me. I wanted to write this so others would know it's NOT a "magic" fix-all wonder drug (for everyone). Hey, if it works for you, congrats, but it didn't for me. This was just my experience, and people in similar situations to me should know there's that risk.  If you're struggling, you're not alone, and I hope we all find our peace ‚úåÔ∏è

As a very experienced magic mushroom explorer, for 20 years, having done them dozens of times I give you this advice: don't do a heroic dose. Not without starting out with 1 dry gram for first time, wait a month or two, then do a 2g dose, wait again, then 3g, and so forth. If you really think you need to do a "heroic" dose of 7 dry grams, you BETTER have experience under your belt and do it properly, planning carefully for it, covering all your bases carefully like set and setting and who your with. Mushrooms and other psychedelics are dangerous, they're not always just medicine, and they're not always healthy for your mind or your body. I've had friends permanently lose their f*cking minds, I've personally known people that became drug addicts and destroyed their family and business and everything, from doing mushrooms like an idiot and confusing themselves about reality. Mushrooms and psychedelics are NOT AUTOMATICALLY GOOD FOR YOU.

¬†@senorpepper3405¬† A very big deal. You can't be trapped inside one room, for one thing. Your brain is going to be going 110% and so being in any enclosed space feels really claustrophobic. Same goes for places with anything loud and busy going on, like a nightclub or crowded bar would be torture. No bright lights shining in your eyes. You want a very relaxed outdoor setting with nobody around, except you and your friends. A nice warm, sunny day in a park. And your mind will be in a very vulnerable place so your friends can't be trying to fuck with you or make you think the cops are going to bust you or anything like that. And don't drive. Have plenty of cold water to drink. Have food in case you get hungry. Have toilet paper. Get rid of any knives or weapons. Don't do them when you're upset or angry or heartbroken, or in physical pain like on crutches.

Not discounting your experiences, but there are some mistakes in your recommendations.   The Hopkins study was a full-on heroic dose on people with no prior experience with Psilocybin. It was also in an enclosed space, with a blindfold, and while listening to music. No practice run, no friends, no nature, no food. This is the clinical environment that has shown promise for treatment, everything else is anecdotal (but not automatically incorrect).  Definitely good points in preparation and making it a meaningful experience. For anyone trying it, read the depression study abstract. It sets out the parameters for how one would plan to recreate it.

¬†@r0ckworthy¬† The Best trips I've had are in my room alone in complete darkness after 11pm. Ive never felt claustrophobic because when I open my eyes the room no longer exists and the distance between me and my hands are in them moments no closer to me than the edge of the universe is. My advice to people is for the first time sure, do a small amount with a friend in the day. But if you want to get past that level 1 recreational stuff. Dont do it with people in the middle of the day in bright lights being studied and watched in an unfamiliar location. After 10pm at night, lights out, alone, in a safe familiar decluttered space where you would be free to leave your physical body while you left it to go explore another realm, is the set for high doses. If you begin your trip around the time you usually go to sleep, and you actively try to sleep when you start tripping, you can enter a state of dreaming while awake, it is akin to entering a deep meditative state, in this state you are completely unresisting to the trip and fall Deep into the rabbit hole.  I have not yet had a "bad trip", only 2 trips that had very difficult moments in them, which have actually been 2 of the most positively impacting. When the trip becomes difficult is when you are reaching a climax of your heroes journey and breaking through that difficult moment is a part of that experience.

Studies are showing the rate of psychosis occurring for users of psychedelics is no different than the general population. Furthermore, there is no mechanism in psychedelics that would cause addiction and resulting destructive lifestyle.  I suspect that anyone you knew that had such an experience, was likely due to other factors, other drugs, laced product, traumatic experiences etc... and psychosis was likely already an event that was going to occur... correlation not causation.  While I believe people should be as safe as possible... I think it is possible that the dangers are often overstated, and are deterring people that could be helped. If you have a good set and setting, you have mentally prepared yourself, you are open, and don't resist the experience... and especially if you already have a spiritual/religious framework... you may not need to be as cautious as you suggest. Though it is a good recommendation... it certainly is a reasonable approach, and it would absolutely help, or even be necessary for helping people having anxiety about taking the leap...  Ultimately I trust in the individual's ability to judge for themselves the level of risk they are willing to take... they have a sense of trauma they may face, the strength of their faith based framework, their emotional stability, their level of being prone to anxiety etc. etc. etc.. If more caution is necessary then I think people can gauge that. They need to do their research and decide what they are comfortable with. Some people will never be prepared to try it, and that is ok... some may need to take it really slow, and that is great too... others may be able to handle a more aggressive leap...  Using my experience as a counter example... After years of meditating on the possibility of taking a heroic dose of psychedelics... one year ago I was presented with the opportunity to purchase some shrooms, the next day I took a heroic dose, without a trip-sitter, alone, on my first psychedelic experience. I didn't reach ego death, but I was very close. It was challenging but positive. It went without any negative incident. 3 weeks later I took double the first dose... again, I was alone, no trip-sitter, same setting. My ego dissolved away... I was gone... I didn't exist... But I did.. or something... faced the immensity... the infinite possibilities, overwhelming... then filled with the realization of my infinite capacity to face those possibilities within my self, and being connected to all of life that works in concert... and I was born again... my ego re-materialized... I was new... and had powerful insights as I integrated the experience and the world and myself with new perspectives and understanding.  I've taken probably another half dozen heroic doses but no ego death... some were transformative, others weren't as much, though usually insight is still enhanced. I tend to aim for a level 3 trip, as I find it still produces powerful experiences without the need for full ego death.

@Jason Smith I hear what you‚Äôre saying man, but I‚Äôm afraid it‚Äôs a bit more complex. While psychedelics have changed the lives of many people forever, we mustn‚Äôt forget that they are a trip, and when it‚Äôs over, you once again exist in the reality in which you existed prior to taking the psychedelics, even if your notions, beliefs, and feelings have changed. You discuss the idea of achieving full potential, but that in itself is a highly complex philosophical idea that is inherently subjective in nature. What does it mean to achieve your full potential? To assume that one‚Äôs potential cannot be reached without the aid of psychedelics is a rather pessimistic view of our existence. You also cannot make generalizations or sweeping statements using a word like ‚Äúwe‚Äù to collectively describe humankind, because, regrettably, not everybody‚Äôs experience with psychedelics is pleasant. Many people become quite sick to the stomach from taking psychedelics, and have reportedly seen quite disturbing things such as ghosts or demons or creatures. Many of these individuals might have come out of the experience having learned nothing but that they were scared shitless and won‚Äôt ever try psychedelics again. So, while I agree with you that uses of psychedelics in science and medicine is encouraging, and that these substances can be beneficial, I do not necessarily agree that they are this miracle substance. I believe that reaching one‚Äôs potential in the way you intended, is primarily reliant upon dedication, practice, sight, and willpower throughout one‚Äôs life. The bettering of oneself, in any way, occurs over time.

¬†@shoeman6966¬† absolutely agree with you, it‚Äôs way more complicated than just eating some mushrooms and having things figured out upon sobering up, and I shouldn‚Äôt have distilled it down the way I did. My main point was from personal experience for the most part. I was in my early 40s before I tried any psychedelics of any kind, I was afraid of ‚Äúthem‚Äù because I‚Äôd heard over and over all the terrible things they do to you. Finally conditions were favorable and I tried mushrooms, and it really was life changing stuff. I feel like there was me before, and me after. Cliche maybe but it‚Äôs true.  I was locked into a way of thinking that was very selfish and narrow minded basically, me me me me. Literally the next day I feel like I started a journey that I‚Äôm still on today. I don‚Äôt feel the same. My perspective shifted from focusing on work, money, and other physical shit to buy or try to buy, to more of a general open minded view that I‚Äôm a cog in the big machine, and finally recognizing that life is indeed so short and my time here is very precious so I have to spend it wisely. My focus shifted in a lot of ways, I feel like I‚Äôm a better father, husband, human for that matter. I used the words ‚Äúfull potential‚Äù because I feel like even though I haven‚Äôt taken any in months, they‚Äôre still helping me find and properly appreciate what really matters in my life. I get that people take psychedelics for fun and to party (which is bananas to me) thus they retain their status of dangerous illegal drugs, and it‚Äôs so unfortunate for us because they‚Äôre a tool and should be respected and used as such. That being said, they‚Äôre definitely not for everyone, but if everyone could somehow experience what I experienced and apply that subtle change to their lives, I know for a fact the world would be a more compassionate, open minded generally better place with people‚Äôs priorities firmly in the right place. After my first experience, my basic existential anxiety sort of dissolved, I dgaf about politics, news, or propaganda from either side of the aisle anymore and that was a real problem for me before. I bought into the big lie the Uniparty is telling, and mushrooms helped me walk away and stop playing the game. I just wish more people could experience it. That‚Äôs really what I meant by full potential, not that 1 or even 1000 mushroom trips would just fix anyone, but the tools to fix yourself are there if we can look for them.

It is surely a more interconnected and actualized state of consciousness. The default state of the human mind is riddled with instinctual illusions, societal programming and defense mechanisms. They blind us.  But its also true that the mushroom state lacks a certain kind of critical thinking, and logic. This can be equally as blinding.  Thats why its important to reflect on the experience during a sober state to make sure you aren't falling into a delusional pattern.  Mushrooms have helped me more than i ever imagined anything could... but i neglected to maintain my scepticism... and i ran astray from reality for a few years, joyously entertaining my delusions. ( i never should have watched Joe Rogan on acid, it absolutely destroyed my epistemology.)  Luckily the delusions i had were harmless and silly... but that is not the case for everyone.  I took the time to understand what true skepticism is and i am now able to think clearly and logically, while still maintaining the gifts that the mushrooms imparted onto me.  Everything has its pros and cons.

If only I thought something like this could actually help me. Don't get me wrong, I genuinely think it's amazing that it helps so many people. But when your life is actively putting you down and preventing you from even being yourself without people wanting to bring you harm for things that aren't even their business and don't hurt anyone... Honestly, I am 100% convinced all, or at least almost all of my depression is caused by external sources that I currently have no control over. Some might say "Well just suck it up and deal with it if you can't change it, change your goals, your dreams, be content with what you have" etc. What I have is nothing, what my goals and dreams are, is simply to be myself without people trying to stop me or harm me for it. I have autism and ADHD, I'm trans, I have PTSD, and I'm disabled. I can't get a job because my ADHD, but I can't get medication for it because nobody wants to diagnose or prescribe for ADHD in adults. I also have my autism and disability to deal with, but I also can't get disability benefits because I'm "not disabled enough" because my daily life at the moment (IE staying around the house and doing frickall) isn't affected by it, even though my ability to function in regular society and be productive is effectively zero. I also can't transition, because I can't drive (disabled), and my only source of transportation is a transphobic family member. And even if I could drive, the state I live in is anti-trans making it harder to transition, and it's expensive as heck. And since I can't get a job or disability income, well...  I think anyone who reads this all the way through will see my point. It's why I don't want medication, and why I don't think any of this would work for me. My depression, all of my mental issues with the exception of my PTSD, are secondary symptoms to things that I cannot change and which will not get better just by "trippin' balls" for six hours. Trust me, I wish they would get better. If it were that easy to get rid of my depression, my PTSD, my situation, if all I had to do was take some gigantic frickoff dose of magic mushrooms, I'd at least try it once. But I just cannot see any way in which my life will be improved. All I could see happening would be witnessing some profound hallucination or something, then coming down, realizing I'm still in the same situation which I can't change, and just getting even more depressed after feeling and witnessing what true freedom could feel like, only to go back to feeling like a slave to a society that hates me, a body I didn't choose and can't change in a productive way, a family which thinks I'm a burden but does nothing to help me stand on my own two feet, and a reality which only seems to promote selfishness and greed above all else, but actively punishes it from anyone not already at the top.  TL;DR: If your depression is caused by external factors and not internal perceptions and the like, I personally can't see how this could ever help.
