Key takeaways:  Psychedelics, including psilocybin and LSD, have been used for centuries in various cultures and have been shown to have potential therapeutic benefits, particularly in the treatment of mental health conditions.   However, their use was heavily stigmatized and restricted in the mid-20th century due to their association with counterculture and incidents of unethical research.   In recent years, there has been a resurgence of interest in the use of psychedelics for therapeutic purposes, with research focusing on their safety and effectiveness in treating conditions such as depression, anxiety, and addiction.   Psychedelics are known for producing intense and potentially transformative experiences, but they also carry risks, including the potential for "bad trips" and the need for careful preparation and support during the experience.

I'm not an emotionally expressive person, but my last heroic dose of psilocybin saw me break down and absolutely weep. All this agony I'd buried over decades of living with depression had a light shined on it; but the light didn't judge, or mock, or burn it away. It just bore witness to it.  It saw it, and acknowledged that the pain I had suffered was real, and terrible. And it told me, wordlessly, that no matter how horribly broken I thought I was, that it still loved me. That I was worthy of that love. And that even though I would go back into that dark place it would be with me always, even if I couldn't feel it.  It stayed with me as I wept; as I poured out all this pain and suffering I had just learned to live with, accepting it as a normal part of everyday life. It stayed with me as I wept, wishing it would be present to me always, but knowing that the experience would end, and that I would eventually lose sight of its presence. And when it did leave, it left me with a fragmentary sentence that has haunted me since:  "... always with you."  I was raised as an atheist, but psilocybin has shown me that the love of God is very, very real.

Honestly, I think videos like this are kind of na√Øve at best, at worst attributing something to drugs that doesn't actually happen. I tripped on acid, shrooms, DMT many times when I was in my early 20's and severely depressed. None of it 'fixed' me. Some of it probably made me worse. I did have some cool experiences but it did not 'change the direction of' my life. I know tons of people who would tell you it profoundly altered the course of their life, but from the external view they still live exactly as they did beforehand.. It's a popular thing to claim, is what i'm saying.  I'm not saying it can't help. I know there is some scientific proof of it being a good tool when used in conjunction with therapy, even going as far as minimizing PTSD symptoms and helping prevent relapse in addiction. The key word there is "therapy". Normal people unexperienced with psychedelics should not be running out to try 'heroic' doses of shrooms in an attempt to fix depression or PTSD. Guaranteed some of you are going to have a very bad time if you do this.  You need a pleasant setting, you need sober helpers/friends nearby who are experienced with what you're about to go through, and even then, you may still have a horrible time. It depends entirely on the person. And if you do have a horrible time, a bad trip if you will, it can exacerbate the very same issues videos like this claim it will fix.   I kind of hate that people talk about these drugs as a spiritual experience that can only do good. It can absolutely make you worse and you may be unlucky and find that out first hand if you don't respect it. I would literally never suggest this shit would work for everyone, nor would I suggest everyone should try it. Some people aren't cut out for the experience. It can be uncomfortable, scary, leave you feeling worse than before and for a long while too, after the fact. It's not a cure-all and if you're hoping for mental health improvement, do it in conjunction with therapy. Probably going to get some shit for saying this from the "hallucinogens are the best!" crowd but I have roughly 20 years of experience with this shit and the pop-culture effect has worn off on me. These drugs are too strong and have effects that are so different from person to person that you should never suggest everyone try them. One person may have a swell time and the next may jump out of a 3rd story window terrified for their life because they're seeing something that isn't there and have forgotten they're under the influence of a substance, (something I have actually seen happen).  I'm not saying don't do it. I'm just saying the "it'll fix everything!" crowd have their head up their asses. There is some medical legitimacy to these drugs helping but the same could be said for antidepressants, and those definitely don't work for everyone. The same is true here. Be safe if you want to test this out for yourself, and the 'therapy' component is more important than the drug in these situations. The drug can potentiate those sessions and help you achieve maximum benefit. On it's own, it's just an altered state of mind. Be safe.

Okay first let me say, everything I say should be taken with a grain of salt, be aude perhaps the subject hits a bit close to home because I've tried a couple different psychadelics under the watch of a couple doctors now, and just feel that there's a lot of misinterpreting that goes on and not enough explananing.  So I'll just start by ask how many people only psychadelics once. Rather I'd like to poll how many people used it "once" so it changed them and now they are just doing psychadelic cycles regularly? Cause I feel like that number is abnormally high. And I've found a number of doctors that are into psychadelics science are usually avid users as well (and quite a few of them are poly substance users it seems). So I usually try to understand that they will have a positivity bias. (Which like reminds me of like the early 1800's. Here drink this super alcohol slurry so you won't feel as bad. Then you start drinking alcohol cause a doctor told you, you won't feel as bad...) But I don't think as many people are getting help as they think. I'm not saying there aren't cases where people aren't getting helped immensely, because there clearly are. However I am saying from my experience,  most of the licensed psychadelics psychologist/ therapists that I've talked to, that are psychonauts,really seem to really push clientele and potential clientele to try "take the medicine", to the point where the therapy seems second to the "medicine." Now this portion could only be me but, I feel it creates this cloud disillusion where, you want to believe a lot of the story's you here about people getting better, but then they just sound like the fake euphoria and eureka moments you hear about frequently when people take psychadelics. ( Like let's remember people abuse drugs including psychadelics because they make you feel good) So I see it like this, if you are going to get therapy so you can change your life forever with one experience, why do so many I know seem to go back so many times? Like if your life changing experience is every few weeks, is your life really changing or are you just in the mind space and thought pattern that you think it is, and you feel better because you under the influence? Or have you been conned into feeling like you have a strong connection to thoughts, people and objects because you were extra vulnerable to stimuli, and told you should feel and think different after taking the medicine. For reference Mother is psychadelic psychiatrist, and  between her the psychadelics doctors, hercolleagues and herself, (I've met a few other psychadelic psychiatrists and therapist that she doesn't know or associate with but the bulk that I have met have been through ber) only 1 out of about 25 aren't frequent users of some kind. Which range from THC, psilocybin, MDMA and ketamine all the way to peyote, ayahuasca and buffo alvarius. And of that group again, only  3 people took less than 2 psychadelic substances in about a 3 month time frame. So again, everything I said with a grain of salt, but I felt I should share my perspective because it's not stays quo.

Awesome. Finally! Mr. Johnson sees this correctly. I grew up in a university town in CA. My dad was a professor considered at the top of his field in research. The first time I tripped was my sophomore year (1977). I have taken acid and mushrooms dozens of times over the years. I went on to college, earned a masters in education administration and leadership, became a county commissioner, ran federal and state education programs, built my own house in the 1980s and am starting again to build another by myself in my 60s. I run heavy equipment and mill my own lumber. I've always been what I call a big picture person. I can get down into the smaller picture, but I'm very cognizant that I go there at the expense of the big picture. It has always felt like the lens of a camera to me. If I dial in the lens to bring things up close into focus, the bigger picture goes blurry. I think I like the big picture, because hate, fear, sadness lose their strength in the big picture. One can see their effects there, but they become more abstract. But love, compassion, empathy really come into focus in the big picture. Psychedelics can transport a person into the big picture in a way they have never experienced before. Once you have taken that journey a few times with psychedelics, you learn to do it on your own.

My experience with 11g of mushrooms;. It was not the typical geometric colors and shapes I was used to. The come up came strong and fast and with it  came extreme agony.  I had taken on all the pain I had ever caused anyone all at the same time. I wept while hypervtilating. I couldnt see because the amount of tears. I couldnt speak for lack of breath.I curled up in a ball and was completely taken over by the experience. My mind unlocked memories going back to childhood. It was like (life flashing before my eyes) but only the pain. I then blacked out (I truly believe I died bit it cont be proven) and went to Hell. It was complete darkness. I had never imagined black could be so dark. I experienced the worst emotional torture you could possibly imagine. Worse that the memories and pain before. I knew the pain  was from being completly seperated from God. I cried out for him endlessly with nothing  but silence and darkness to comfort me. The moment befor Jesus let out his last breath he said "father why have you forsaken me." It was at this moment Jesus felt the worst pain of his crucifixion. Worse than all his wounds. The pain wasnt physical but spiritual. God could no longer connect to him because he had taken on all the sin of mankind. This is what I felt weeping and gnashing of teeth but no fire or physical torture. It was something worse. After suffering frlor what seemed like forever I was saved. I was suddenly in a space filled with pure white light and knew I was in the presence of Jesus. This was the most beautiful and amazing feeling. Unlike any drug or experience could provide on earth. It was pure joy, not tarnished by subconcious guilt or shame. Not adultered by the underlying doubts or insecurities that are present even in the happiest times in your physical body.  A euphoria washed over my being with pure extacy. Ive done every drug known to man and nothing compares to this, it can not be described with words. I spent some time there and dont remember much about what was said but i know we where talking. I remember when it was time to go and i remember begging him not to send me back because I was suicidal and extremely depressed at the time. He said my time on earth wasnt done and then I woke up. I ended up going to rehab the next week and remained sober fir the first time in my life. I now have a normal life. I married my best friend and we had 2 beautiful daughters. Im thankful for the experience and Im thankful that God blessed me with another chance so I could meet my little girls.

I once took a very large dose of mushrooms, about 10 grams. I put my headphones on and laid down. About an hour in I completely left my body, all I saw and experienced was a void. Then, in the void I saw a sphere covered in fire. I soon realized I was actually looking at the dark side of the Earth, and each spot of fire were cities, smouldering and billowing smoke into the atmosphere and killing the trees and grass.  Then I started flying extremely fast, and I rotated around the planet. When I came to the light side of the planet I saw massive forests and mountains consuming the burning cities, blanketing them in their green and burying them beneath the mountains as the smoke slowly stopped pouring into the atmosphere. Then, I heard a loud blast of wind, and my body shot back into my body way down on Earth at a thousand miles an hour, I even recognized Chicago (where I stayed at that time) as I was sent down.   During all of this, I felt terror and confusion as I saw the black sphere of fire floating in a void, sadness and guilt at the realization that it was humanity my own people hurting Earth setting it ablaze, and relief and happiness when I understood what I was experiencing, the Earth rebounding from an infection. It was marvelous and terrifying all at the same time.  I took this as a lesson that we can never kill our Earth, it will eventually bury us and our mistakes, just like our distant ancestors who they are still digging up to this day. Life will always find a way and continue with or without humans, and that was an incredibly comforting thought for me.

Have fun with a music visualizer, it's why they were made to begin with, you should be at home feeling safe and cozy.  After your journey you'll need to spend time reflecting, a lifetime in fact. 4:50 "Compared to other drug classes, psychedelics are really robustly safe at the physiological level", accompanied by a picture of mushrooms. Careful with that! While it may be true that a person will not suffer permanent physical harm from a massive dose of LSD, you certainly can eat enough psilocybin mushrooms to make you violently ill or even kill you. And let's not even get started on Datura (the infamous Jimson Weed that Carlos Casteneda's novels popularized). I understand you're dealing with clinical doses that you know are safe, but a lot of people will take a statement like that, given by an authoritative expert on the subject, like you, and just run with it on their own - hit the street, buy some pills or a bag of mushrooms from "a friend of a friend" and potentially put themselves into a very serious situation requiring a 911 call. I very much appreciate the work you and others are doing to use psychedelics to help people, but please be really careful about making blanket proclamations like that.

30-40 milligrams is an extremely SMALL dose, much less than the typical 0.2g microdose.  A heroic dose is 4-5+ grams.  I'm confused why he says 30-40mg is a heroic dose.......is that a mistake?  Terrance McKenna took +5g, which is definitely not 30-40mg.  I have taken 3-3.5g on multiple occasions.  The first time was debilitating (I was safe) and I could barely walk from my chair to the bathroom.  But the experience was not life-changing.  I took 3.5g a few weeks ago and it was underwhelming.  I didn't even have a comeup, it didn't even make me emotional, and it didn't "show me" anything.  I was disappointed.  I have committed to tripping monthly on the full moon for 12 months, slowly increasing my dose when I feel ready.  I am still waiting for a profound or "most meaningful experience of my life" sort of experience.  Maybe I will reach that at a true heroic dose of 5g.  But so far, I am underwhelmed by psilocybin.  I am also disappointed that the trip lasts about 2 hours.  I wish it lasted longer.   Disclaimer:  I do not take any pills or medications other than herbal supplements and minerals, and 0.2g microdose of psilocybin every 4 days.  I also use THC regularly.

Do you do internal work on yourself while in a decent or strong experience? Because I'm learning more and more that the key with real change and healing coming from a mushroom trip is the conscious therapy part. To be strongly introspective and analyse yourself and your problems. By conscious I mean being vocal about it in your mind or even speaking aloud rather than just letting yourself heal. Facing the negative and traumatic thoughts in your head, and talk through them like you are at a psychiatrist but by yourself. In my opinion, during an experience on mushrooms is the only time you will actually be ready to face some negative parts of your mind that need addressing. I used to be under the impression that just having the trip will be healing your mind, which it does, but I'm convinced now that the most important part is having the therapy with yourself at the time and addressing the problematic thoughts, and of course the good thoughts as well. This is coming from a sufferer of sever depression for the last 3 years. Some people (not saying you) tend to paint psychedelics as a magic medicine when in reality I think it's the ability it gives you to work on yourself, and use yourself to your full potential, which is the magic part.

I wish people would focus on why micro dosing works instead of just saying it works without explanation. Microdosing merely throws us off our game just slightly so we focus more on the present moment rather than repeatedly dwelling on pasts or predicting negative futures. This allows the brain the opportunity to create new, healthy habits of thought and the ability to conciously change our habits of thought. And that is the key. Steering the ship so to speak instead of being a passenger. We choose our habits of thought and emotion when we decide that we have that ability. We can do the same by merely rearanging our routine every day, step on cracks, in puddles and take the inconvenient long way in simple situations. Just do things that put the breaks on habitual reflexive reactions and decide first before reacting. Merry Christmas everyone and constantly make the decision to steer your ship. You don't need drugs to do it but microdosing absolutely helps keep you in the present moment, adds euphoria, hightens senses and opens you up to believing you have the ability to choose your state of mind.üéÑüçªüòÅ

As someone who started psychedelics while young, and continued use until two years ago. It was what changed my life for the better. It's so hard to explain what it's like living as someone who isn't yourself, only to come back into your own body and judge every habit, every word said, every person wronged. It made me feel so awful that from that day on, I cleaned myself up day by day. I quite nicotine, smoking weed, drinking alcohol, and even stopped caffeine and large portions of sugar intake. I live in a place where most people are completely uneducated on psychedelics and cannabis. But they do have alcohol. The people here often ask about weed. I tell them, alcohol makes you stupid, marijuana makes you crazy, and neither of those two are of particular profound value. Yet there are things called magic mushrooms that allow you to sit down with and talk to god. I tell them about the amazing phantasmagorical visions, the heightened perceptions, but the real value is the inward journey where your soul is stripped naked to your consciousness of its clothing that somehow it had been wearing forever and for no particular reason. It can be beautiful and it can be ugly. It will likely be both. In any event, upon reflection it will be ineffable and invaluable. And exactly what they need in this corner of the world.

I am a disabled veteran with Bipolar 1 and combat related PTSD. I am greatly improved because of psychedelics. Specifically: Pharmahuasca, vaporized DMT, mushrooms, and ketamine. When the depression hits so hard you stop eating, sleeping all day, barely drink water, and do absolutely zero selfcare, the coping techniques don‚Äôt work. I have an 8mg per squirt nasal spray of ketamine. Two rounds up each nostril (32mg total @220lbs) and about 15 minutes, the crushing weight of the darkness is simply disbursed.   I was once experiencing an intense PTSD spiral and was able to dose ~5mg of vaporized DMT to find relief. There was no psychedelic experience. I simply felt the "afterglow" of peace and contentment with all existence. In 30 seconds, I went from a hyper-emotion state of spiraling grief to being at peace because of a small dose of vaporized DMT. This was an application I had hypothesized and knew the opportunity would genuinely present itself. Vaporized DMT is a rescue med in this application. I was on the verge of being possibly hospitalized, and definitely sedated, from a core trauma trigger that sent me spiraling (shaking, crying, and suffering incredible emotional pain), and a subthreshold dose of DMT saved me. Within a minute, I had rebalanced emotionally and thought, "Holy shit. I'm ok." And truly, I was.  60mg (@220lbs) of Pharmahuasca had me fall in love, and then become love on my first dose. I had tripped about 30-40 times before this on mushrooms and some limited exposure to LSD. This trip was transformative. It changed how I saw the world. Instead of a lens of suffering and emptiness, I saw love in all things, the beauty that exists all around us, and love that it took to create this wonderful existence for us to experience.  Early on, I was so empty and depressed for so long, I forgot what happiness was. I took a 3.5g of baseline cubensis and, for 4 hours, I was happy and free from the depression. After I realized I had a 4-hour window of relief, I started dosing every 7 days, so I would just not be in one stage of crying or another for a few hours during the day. This is not recommended use and was an extreme situation where I was overmedicated and was so empty, I would just sit and cry because I had to endure another day of a miserable existence of suffering and pain. We adjusted my meds and my use went down to once every few months pretty quickly. Please forgive my overuse, but this is what I had to do to make it through that period.  * I would rather someone tolerance-trip on psychedelics based on this anecdotal account than to hurt themselves because of their pain.  My hand to the sky, I swear this my true experience.  Be safe. Use responsibly. Stay blessed. <3

Hero doses are transformative when done right. Years of chronic pain, depression and minor childhood traumas had twisted me. I wanted to be dead but didn't want to die. I wouldn't admit my shame and I didn't really know it was there. Then I was offered shrooms so I dug up the studies to calculate the "correct dose" (~4.5-5g with Cubensis).  The first few trips were euphoric. Years of muted emotions caused their return to feel intense. The feeling exceeded the euphoria of cocaine in almost every way. But no one else I know has experienced euphoria.   Just like in the video, I was in bed with a blindfold and music. But I was cuddling my wife skin-to-skin. Whenever she left for a minute, I felt an intense decline in my euphoria. The same happened when the music would stop. I would not have voluntarily left that state for almost any reason.   But there was no desire whatsoever to re-enter the euphoria once it faded. When it was over, I wanted to explore my new state of consciousness unimpeded by the effects of the mushrooms. I felt clear-headed and emotionally neutral from a state of relative negativity.   I did 6-8 hour fasts followed by hero doses every few weeks for about a month (not sure if fasting changed things). On my 3rd trip, I felt my diaphragm release and I started breathing more deeply. I had (apparently) developed a subconscious pattern of tension that constricted my breathing. I have been mindful to keep it relaxed since then.   Slowly the euphoria faded away though. I no longer feel the same way when I do a hero dose. I think that there may be a special window at the beginning of therapy when your doses are re-wiring your brain most effectively. Having the right setting on the first few trips may be extremely important. I recommend skin-to-skin with an intimate partner or family member. Music and a comfortable place to rest are a must.   On a later trip, I actually perceived tension in my muscles that I could not perceive normally. I spent several hours on one trip stretching my arms and fingers intensely (I looked crazy for sure). I later learned that I had a muscular deformity in my shoulder (long story), which may explain some of those perceptions. It has not happened again on any trip since. Maybe 3 hours of contorting fixed it.   But one of the most important trips ever was when I realized that I carried much shame. Shrooms allowed me to recognize it objectively. The feeling came up and I was acutely aware of what it was. I was relatively aware of why I felt shame, but it also took some thought to fully understand. Luckily, thinking is largely unimpeded even when you are very high. (It is mostly what you care about that changes, so your thoughts focus on those things to the exclusion of most else). By recognizing the shame and its causes, I was able to challenge it, come to terms with it and alter my thinking. I had to accept guilt for some of the shame (another long story), which may not be healthy, but I no longer suffer it: I co-exist with it relatively unbothered with how others perceive me. In a way, I came to understand and accept what I cannot control. The shrooms allowed me to recognize and label an emotion more effectively. There was just no hiding from it actually, nor was it painful to confront.    Overall, mushrooms healed me a great deal. I am by no means fixed entirely, but I no longer want to be dead. Unfortunately, I am still twisted from my childhood. Years of social anxiety (possibly social phobia) caused by childhood traumas has changed my personality (IMHO). I gravitate to solitude because I have learned enjoy it despite its effects on my mental health. Shrooms helped me to recognize that trauma and resulting shame were how I got this way though.   A trained therapist during my trips may have helped to reshape my thinking. I could have gone in a dramatically healthier direction despite the amazing effects. A lengthy course of therapy before shrooms could help unearth issues that could then be explored while high. Then you could really work out the kinks on your trip. It helped that I had been challenging my own thinking since taking psychology courses years earlier (where I learned of mushroom therapy). It could likely work in reverse too: shrooms first then lengthy courses of therapy.   I was thinking of doing another hero dose this Christmas. But I have no skin to cuddle (out of town) and there will be no euphoria to speak of. My relationships are in need of repair (longest story) and that won't happen (in my case) while I am high. But they were not damaged because I was high. If anything, they are much better because I transformed in the presence of my loved one and she got to understand me better. There is work to do, but I am in a better place to do that work.

Talk about a meta trip. That was the positive aspect. It included feelings of extreme nausea (about to vomit), then a few seconds later, perfect physical peace and even feelings of bliss... then back to retching when I saw how I felt guilt, then back to peace when I kind of saw how unnecessary it was. It was intensely physical as well as mental.  On the negative side, I experienced reality melting down. I think if people start assuming after watching this video that psychedelics is that one stop solution to all mental health problems, and its been kept from the masses with some mal- intent, a lot of the truth that Dr Mathew tried to share gets lost.  Therefore am highlighting the very things he mentions to reaffirm the half that we tend to miss in such videos-  1.For starters if we listened closely to just this video all by itself- he brings out how set and setting is crucial, how sensitively guided the process should be. The ethics of the practice. what I 'm trying to draw attention here is to discard a rudimentary dichotomous way of having looked at psychedelics throughout history as 'good' versus 'bad'. Instead, the a more nuanced higher order wholistic view of its place in ones journey, and how it should be then used and not abused.   2. case in point the issues of abuse- of boundaries - "the guru complex" for example  When one enters this altered state safety is of the highest importance and am referring to psychic safety as well.  3. Also to highlight and I quote-   '''I kind of think of all of these disorders as different forms of addiction. So whether it's to a substance like tobacco or alcohol, cocaine, or a way of thinking about yourself, it's this narrowed mental and behavioral repertoire: reality used to be like this, and now your reality is like this. "   Here  he himself is referring how a NARROWING of REALITY is at the heart of mental illness and suffering,  and ironically if we start having a narrow view of psychedelics instead of a wholistic view , something beautiful and transformative can get twisted and we might find ourselves swinging the opposite end of healing and end up with a new cycle of addiction.   With that,  best wishes to everyone reading this for health and well being, grounded in wholism. Peace.

This scientist‚Äôs comment on The Beatles reveals an oversimplified perspective.   The Beatles didn‚Äôt have one ‚Äúbig shift‚Äù like a light toggle turned on. It was more like a light fader gradually brightening. Beatles for Sale revealed a shift in lyrical themes influenced by Dylan, and Help was when cannabis had an influence.. also inspiring ‚ÄúGot to Get You into My Life‚Äù which was developed & recorded later  By the time Revolver came, they also reduced touring and had absorbed song forms and music in general for many years by then (incubated creative influences), and refined their independent writing informed by their unique and fertile partnered writing.   Eventually they stopped touring altogether when they created SGT Pepper‚Äôs.. Having all that free time to indulge songwriting and studio production was the main catalyst of change, coupled with George Martin‚Äôs expertise at scoring classical arrangements. To say this period of creativity was merely due to LSD is ludicrous.. if that was the case, many more bands and artists would‚Äôve had similar creative breakthroughs, and that‚Äôs just not the case.   Conversely, other artists, such as Dylan had his creative zenith prior to that proliferation of LSD .. or as many see it, his creative output was fairly steady throughout, from Blowin‚Äô In The Wind to Blood on The Tracks.    Then there‚Äôs LSD casualties such as Syd Barrett, who‚Äôs creativity fell off completely after his exposure to it.  Would The Beatles have produced those late albums without LSD?  Perhaps not, but it was only one influence among many in a complex evolution. Similarly, I would argue (as a person has partaken and has had transformative experiences) that LSD works with other influences or environmental inputs.. Perhaps similar in a sense to epi-genetics and gene expression

Thing is, since the 60's, it just hasn't had the impact one would think such a profound experience would. It did not lead to a world of peace and love, and most of those folks wouldn't even touch the stuff these days, they have had plenty.. And as part of that plenty, some trips are fun, some seem profound, some are awful. Point being as much as it seems like your speaking with the gods, the truth is your simply tripping.  That's all. Do it again in a few days and instead of speaking with the gods you'll be talking to a turtle.  This is the same way for the last few years we've heard crazy shit like pot cures migraines, or weed cures cancer.. If ya wanna trip, trip. If you wanna spend your days studying each trip and looking deeply into it, then go for it. But be intellectually honest about it and recognize the truth of it is that its no more important that what you might experience in a dream, and then forget just as soon as you wake. In fact that's exactly what it is, and all it is. Its just a fuck'n trip. It's not a message from god. It's not the answer to every psychological sickness, in fact it can agitate some illnesses and even cause other psychological issues to surface. And it's not some sorta profound contact with an ancient alien race.  I'm happy to smoke weed, but i sure as hell know its not gonna cure my hemorrhoids. And maybe tomorrow night I might toss down 4 grams of the mushroom's I have. And while it will be pretty fun, I certainly don't expect my entire life to be profoundly effected the next day. Because it never has been. Not once. And I'm 52, I got plenty of skin in the game. At best you might carry a consist good mood for a day or two after, assuming that you had a good trip.

Thank you. This was brilliant and profound. It seems to me that this perfectly dovetails with all of the recent work on the effects of childhood trauma and neglect.  People like Dr. Besel Van der Kolk and Dr. Gabor Mate have really changed the way we think about and treat trauma. They both have personal, first-hand experience with childhood trauma, which I think makes their work all the more meaningful and powerful. Having both gone down the traditional Freudian "talk therapy" road and gotten nowhere themselves, they both explored and pioneered alternative forms of treatment.  For personal and professional reasons, I have read all of the standard psychological "heavy hitters," like Freud, Jung, Klein, Kristeva, Winicott and others, and I have also personally benefitted greatly from "talk therapy."  I have, however, also been reeling for a couple of years since my current therapist recommended Besel Van der Kolk's book, The Body Keeps the Score. The idea that the body carries a "record" of our every experience at the "cellular level" often unbeknownst to the mind, that "voice in our head," is astounding.  In order to survive certain events in our primary circumstances, we may deny, repress, suppress, sublimate, etc. the traumatic memories, but our bodies remember.  Both of these doctors recommend therapies that target the body specifically, and these therapies must necessarily involve approaches that are "beyond words."  I can see how psychedelics could be similarly helpful at untying what Joseph Campbell refers to as "psychological knot points."  I have believed for some time that humanity is in the midst of a paradigm shift on every level.  To express this in broad strokes, it seems to me that we are moving away from a time in which our leaders in public positions and in the home rule by fear, domination, cruelty, neglect, exploitation, etc. to a time in which leaders in public and private recognize and appreciate difference, diversity, inclusion, kindness, warmth, generosity, compassion, empathy, and, dare I say it, love. The latter are infinitely better ways to lead and to live for everyone concerned.   The former Orange American president's current circumstances are serving as a kind of symbolic measuring stick of this paradigm shift. No, the fifties was not a better time when anything could happen behind closed doors, and no authority would intervene. The "nuclear family" itself is a very modern invention that has never reflected reality for most Americans, let alone the rest of the world. A former teacher of mine, Stephanie Koontz, wrote a book in the nineties called The Way It Never Was in response to the "Family Values" BS that Dan Quayle and other politicians were lauding at the time.   I allude to the fifties because people like Timothy Leary and Terence McKenna were marginalized in their time for questioning public and private power structures.   There were many others like them, of course, but while these folks were trying to change the world for the better, others were watching Lawrence Welk while the Vietnam War was happening.  Good grief.  Obviously, psychedelics are scary to dominators because an "expanded" mind is much harder to control. Finally, I think that one "silver lining" to the whole COVID epidemic is that it brought the mental health crisis to the forefront. My  therapist says that our society has been structured to support insanity rather than sanity for a long, long time. I agree, but maybe this is changing.  A girl can dream. : )   Thank you for this excellent presentation.   I really appreciated it and will share it with others. : )

He called it ‚ÄúThe Shaman‚Äôs Dose.‚Äù The ‚ÄúHero‚Äôs Dose‚Äù was 40 mls. The other eleven people in tonight‚Äôs ceremony choked down only 15 mls. We each were given a pillow, a foam mat, and a little white plastic bucket. We laid in a circle, feet pointing to the center.  	As the nausea drudged in through a swamp of putrid odors, I inhaled as much air as possible and let the exhale out under its own weight - making sure I slipped down below the nausea with each. In this way I avoided puking and was able to fall asleep as the others were filling their buckets.  	Twister appeared. What a gift to assuage my regret. As usual, I mounted bareback and gripped his mane and ribs. He leaped through the threshold. Already at full gallup, down down swerving down the tunnel to a chamber. In total opaque silent dark, I dismounted and fell asleep on the floor.  	My wrist watch burst into flame then melted like one of Dali‚Äôs clocks. An eye the size of a basketball blinked at me. In the flash of light an enormous dragon crouched. Black green, a stag buck with a full rack. 	As usual, I mounted then reached around his scaly neck with arms and legs.  Wood creaking way back and to the left end of the chamber, the dragon moved toward the sound. A portal opened. We slipped through and flew down the steam tunnel. Swerve diving he was breathing hard, but not steam: flames. The flames reached around his head. What‚Äôs burning?  	We landed in a dank stone chamber. I fell asleep again. In the total darkness, a creaking wood sound woke us up and directed the dragon to another portal. I jumped on. Gripped his neck with arms and legs. We leapt through. Spiraling down, flames from his nostrils lighting our way and burning off more of my flesh. Until a pure calcium skeleton was all that was left on the floor of the chamber. We were on the bottom of the bottom. 	The Ayahuascero and his wife were standing over me. With a look on both their faces like they had just been asked a spelling bee question without a clue as to how to spell the word, and worse yet, couldn‚Äôt even guess. (The word must have started with silent letters.) They seemed relieved when I asked to go to the bathroom. I felt relieved I remembered how to use my mouth to speak. 	While peeing I could feel the texture of molecules as they traveled down  and out then fell into the toilet. People said Ayahuasca creates an out of body experience, the truth is: it was the most connected to my body I have ever felt. Returning to the ceremony room, I took my place on the floor pad among the other journeyers, purged into my little plastic pail, closed my eyes, got small and crawled into a liver nephron to learn how to expedite detoxing the caffeine and nicotine molecules waiting in their respective queues.  	Eleven of the twelve of us sat in a circle drinking tea. We were supposed to ‚Äúdebrief‚Äù by sharing our ‚Äúda-vine‚Äù journey experiences. Nick said he remembered trying to make love to the Ayahuascero‚Äôs hot wife, then paused to watch us all gasp, before he went on to explain the only problem was: she happened to be a plant at the time.  	When the talking stick made its way to me, I felt putting the astounding ineffable experience into words would obviously fall short. I could‚Äôve told them about Twister turning into a dragon and burning off all my flesh but that still wouldn‚Äôt measure up to all that was learned. ‚ÄúLook, you know I cant explain what actually happened last night.‚Äù They all nodded. ‚ÄúMaybe it would be better if I just show you by using a ritual the Goddess taught me somewhere along the way.‚Äù That offer lit up the Ayahuascero‚Äôs hot wife. ‚ÄúPlease do,‚Äù she cooed.  	I dont really know when during the night I learned it. It just seemed natural and felt comfortable to perform. (Sure was weird that something so strange, that I had never done anything like before, would now feel entirely comfortable, as if I had performed it hundreds of times.)  	I asked the journeyer sitting next to me for her left hand. She willingly offered it. Cradling her left hand palm up, in mine, and holding it open with the tips of our fingers, I ever so gently exhaled 4 lung breaths into the center of her palm. Turning my head to the side to deeply inhale then over the center to gently exhale. Not shaping the breath with my lips, not blowing: I relaxed and opened my throat so the breaths would come only from releasing my diaphragm. I forced the inhale, but let the exhale flow into her hand of its own accord. Four ‚Äúlung breaths.‚Äù Then I took her palm and delicately planted four sweet kisses on the same place the breaths went in. (Like you would kiss the cheek of your own infant) Then I folded her fingers closed into a fist. Then gently, in slow motion, placed the fist on top of her sternum. Ever so slowly, gradually withdrawing my fingers with a delicate caress of her knuckles.  	I asked her how she felt. She said, ‚ÄúGood, warm, self-love.‚Äù    *   *   *    	A month later, at a child‚Äôs guitar lesson, a warm up to the ritual was added so both people are comfortably in the ‚Äúalternate state‚Äù when the lung breathes are delivered. This is done by looking into each others eyes until each person sees two eyes turn into four eyes. This may take from 15 seconds to four minutes. Also, both people should be grounded - standing on dirt or grass without shoes.  	Later I performed the Lung Breath-Palm Kiss Ritual on two people with cancer, one with spastic bowel syndrome, four children (guitar students) with ADHD (and taught their mothers how to perform it), my wife, my father, along with about 30 members of the Jarawa Tribe living in the Andaman Islands of India.  	Self-love: the healer sublime.

I've had quite a few trips over the years.  Maybe 15 or 20 of those were heroic doses of mushrooms of 5 grams or above and of one trip of 8.5 grams.  Speaking from my own expirence, I feel like the risk of bad trips and the idea of a trip suddenly turning from good to bad to be a bit over stated. Generally, it doesn't play out that way. If one knows what he or she is getting into and has done a bit of mental preparation beforehand, the risk is almost nill. The problem arises when a person begins to fight the expirence either out of fear or because he or she has encountered negative emotions during the trip and does not understand that they will pass naturally if not focused upon.   For those that are worried though, there are strategies for coping with a difficult journey. First,  If you find yourself on an uncomfortable ride, change your setting. Turn the lights off or on, switch the song or go get some fresh air. The mood of your physical place can affect your mental state.  Also, try to drink a soda or some juice. Sometimes a cold way too sweet refreshment hits your already over hyped senses hard enough to snap you out of a negative thought loop.  Next, say yes to the expirence. That sounds like woowoo self-help nonsense but things might get weird during your psychedelic journey and fighting it is always the wrong answer.  Let the trip wash over you without resistance and it will pass easily.  Finally, and this is likely controversial and definitely counterintuitive, but bigger doses (of mushrooms and the other classic psychedelics) are easier to cope with than smaller ones. If the trip overwhelms you, you won't have the time or inclination to to worry about cares, insecurities, personal and et cetera because of the profoundly altered state you will find yourself in which will allow you to truly enjoy the expirence.

These people have a completely wrong sense of how trips scale. The ‚Äúheroic dose‚Äù is said to be 5 dried grams taken in silent darkness. That‚Äôs more than most people think they can handle, but it‚Äôs actually a relatively tiny dose. Anything below 3 grams should be called a micro dose. Lots of people think they‚Äôve had an ego death, when in reality they have no idea what that means, because you can‚Äôt know unless you‚Äôve actually had one. And you cannot experience an ego death below ~15-20 grams. If you want to learn about the nature of yourself and reality, you need to macro-dose. Take 10, then 15, then 20, see how high you can go. I promise that there is a world of difference in every aspect of the trip for every 5 grams you add. What people must remember is that it's not what happens during the trip, but what happens after. It's possible that without support and a positive environment surrounding us, we can slip back in old patterns of thought and rigid states of consciousness. I have experienced trauma directly after a trip that I felt had healed me, and I slipped straight back into the deep dark hole I had been stuck in prior. The trip is just the beginning. We owe it to our minds and bodies to dive deeper and develop habits that ultimately decide our journey. Breathwork, meditation, journaling. The relationship you have with your mind must be nurtured always. Psychedelics don't heal - they simply show you how. When you are lost, they will show you the way. When you are lonely, they will connect you. They will show you love and often that is enough to guide a person in the right direction.

¬†@christavanw7476¬† Big question. First I think it should be noted that adding extra chemicals into the equation can cause negative effects e.g. alcohol is probably the worst thing you can mix it with in my opinion. Alcohol lowers consciousness while the mushrooms elevate. I've smoked weed on a trip before - some people love it, others hate it. I prefer not to smoke as I often need the mental stability after a big trip. I also find that weed can create a lot of inner chatter, other times it helps me meditate on the nature of my thoughts and my relation to them, rather than my thoughts narrating for me. It's obvious that having a controlled environment (setting) is so important for guiding the trajectory of the trip. Music plays a big part for me personally. Being in nature is great in the summer, but being able to fully let go is most important, which I find easier to do on my sofa than in public. Feeling safe is priority, only then can you be open and let go. When you resist the waves of energy that move through you during a trip, that is when you will start to feel particularly uncomfortable. When you let go, deep emotions will come to the surface and release. I often experience a lot of laughter and crying at some point during the trip, followed by inner calm. It's all subjective of course, but we should distinguish between a bad trip and a hard trip. Sometimes we will let go and be faced with some really difficult truths about us, others or the world around us. That can be a difficult experience, but it doesn't mean it's bad. Where a bad trip might mean feelings of anxiety, paranoia... a hard trip may entail feeling pain - BUT - it's important that we feel this pain in order to release it from the surface of our bodies. This is essentially how we go about healing deep traumas that have been stored in our cells.

As a coach in the psychedelics space, as well as a veteran of 30 years of using them, I take slight issue with this video and videos of it's kind. I realize that this video is intended as a kind of puff piece aimed at a general audience, with the assumption that people are generally clear headed, neurotypical, and going to take this message with a modicum of caution but optimism. The problem is that the message of this video misinforms people either by implication, or by omission, and then when people come to work with someone like me, their expectations are completely misaligned with the reality of psychedelic experiences.   They'll come to me after following the 'advice' of a video like this, taking WAY too high of a dose for a beginner and wonder why they're having difficult and unproductive experiences. Or they'll come hoping that, even though they've never done any therapy or personal development work in their life and  have a lifetime of stuff to process, somehow they can get it all done in one trip and "rewire their brain". Then, when that fails to happen, they fall into discouragement or despair, or self judgment, or anger that psychedelics aren't getting them the instant result that is implied in videos like this. For many, psychedelics represent a last hope after every other form of medication and therapy has failed them. As a coach & hypnotherapist in the psychedelics space, I'm CONSTANTLY being approached by people who really aren't doing well-- whose brains aren't functioning optimally, who have been coping through mental and emotional distress for far too long on medications-- who take these types of videos out of context, make sweeping assumptions on the information being presented here, and then rush headlong into psychedelics without proper preparation and support. And to some degree, this mismatch between the reality of the firsthand experience of psychedelics and what is being presented in media like this video adds to the problems that these masses of desperate people end up having.   There's other information that is also missing in these videos, like all the failures behind closed doors in sessions in these studies, the teething pains of developing a clear understanding of psychedelic therapy inside the psychedelic therapy community, and the truth that many of the results touted from these studies don't show a permanent change in symptoms for the participants, but rather a reduction for a period of time, which still implies a sort of consumerist, take this medication to fix it approach to therapy, that ultimately doesn't resolve the underlying issue, but is just a better form of kicking the can down the road. Permanent healing is possible, but these studies don't address that. And the people come away with this confused sense that psychedelics are the new SSRIs or meds, rather than a paradigm that can eliminate the need for meds altogether.  My hope is that as the push for legalization continues, there is a refining of the messaging so that people more accurately know what to expect. Not just the extreme end of the potentials in the positive sense, but the reality of what working with psychedelics for mental and emotional transformation and well being actually looks like for your average person. To not represent this clearly does a disservice to the audience and society as a whole.  Don't get me wrong though; I'm a HUGE believer in psychedelics, and very excited both by the research and legalization!!! It's just that at the very least, we should be accurately representing the reality of using psychedelics to people in order to minimize their suffering. Anything less is unkind at the very least, and I'd argue, unethical.  So here's to hoping that Big Think, Hopkins, Matthew Johnson, MAPS, and all the other visible, vocal mouthpieces in the psychedelic science and psychedelic therapy space start to sharpen their message to be more accurate, because this dumbed down version of the truth is a bit dangerous.

The real hopeless victims of mental illness are to be found among those who appear to be most normal. Many of them are normal because they are so well adjusted to our mode of existence, because their human voice has been silenced so early in their lives that they do not even struggle or suffer or develop symptoms as the neurotic does. They are normal not in what may be called the absolute sense of the word; they are normal only in relation to a profoundly abnormal society.  		 		   Aldous Huxley   I imagine one of the reasons people cling to their hates so stubbornly is because they sense, once hate is gone, they will be forced to deal with pain.  James Baldwin, The Fire Next Time   The cult of self dominates our cultural landscape. This cult has within it the classic traits of psychopaths: superficial charm, grandiosity, and self-importance; a need for constant stimulation, a penchant for lying, deception, and manipulation, and the inability to feel remorse or guilt. This is, of course, the ethic promoted by corporations. It is the ethic of unfettered capitalism. It is the misguided belief that personal style and personal advancement, mistaken for individualism, are the same as democratic equality. In fact, personal style, defined by the commodities we buy or consume, has become a compensation for our loss of democratic equality. We have a right, in the cult of the self, to get whatever we desire. We can do anything, even belittle and destroy those around us, including our friends, to make money, to be happy, and to become famous. Once fame and wealth are achieved, they become their own justification, their own morality. How one gets there is irrelevant. Once you get there, those questions are no longer asked.  Chris Hedges, Empire of Illusion: The End of Literacy and the Triumph of Spectacle   The commercial media ‚Ä¶ help citizens feel as if they are successful and have met these aspirations, even if they have not. They tend to neglect reality (they don't run stories about how life is hard, fame and fortune elusive, hopes disappointed) and instead celebrate idealized identities ‚Äì those that, in a commodity culture, revolve around the acquisition of status, money, fame and power, or at least the illusion of these things. The media, in other words, assist the commercial culture in ‚Äúneed creation‚Äù, prompting consumers to want things they don't need or have never really considered wanting. And catering to these needs, largely implanted by advertisers and the corporate culture, is a very profitable business. A major part of the commercial media revolves around selling consumers images and techniques to ‚Äúactualize‚Äù themselves, or offering seductive forms of escape through entertainment and spectacle. News is filtered into the mix, but actual news is not the predominant concern of the commercial media.  Chris Hedges, The Death of the Liberal Class

The added temporary interneuronal synapse connections thanks to cannabis and especially the psychedelics are literal wiring upgrades to our brains that can be made permanent through normal neuroplasticity learning.  These new connections give parts of our brains new access to both our current sensory perceptions, heightening them and making us more appreciative of everything we experience, while also giving parts of our brains new access to memories making even our memories heightened with literally new mental perspectives on them (explaining ‚Äòflashbacks‚Äô).  It‚Äôs like a physical empathy, giving our brains the ability to have new and more diverse perspectives on everything, past and present.    These substances widely have the reputation as creativity-enhancers but I think actually they‚Äôre empathy-enhancers creating new perspectives, giving artists greater ability to imagine how a wider audience will perceive their work while it‚Äôs in progress, making it more creative as a result.  Legalize, release, expunge and give industry advantages to the minorities most harmed.

As a psychiatric nurse of 28 years, I can tell you that psychedelics won't cause you to "go crazy." Or, in professional terms, have a psychotic episode or break. However, if you ARE mentally ill, your symptoms will exacerbate. Now, there have been cases where a person was pre-psychotic, meaning that they were going to have a psychotic break at some point, and the drugs kind of kicked it off, so to speak. So it would seem that the continued mental illness was CAUSED by the drugs, when in fact the psychedelics were simply a catalyst.

¬†@pigcatapult¬† I say not. I took LSD 57 times in my youth and that was in 1970-1977 - when you got a dose back then it was strong!  Three times I took more than one tab, the strongest being two tabs of "Clear Light" also known as "Window Pane". I also took mushrooms a couple of hundred times once I lost my bottle for takin acid.  From all that I never had anything that amounted to a flashback. There were some lasting effects although I would not consider them negatives.  For the following ten years or so, the headlights of oncoming cars had a colour to them as did any really bright light. - if that sounds like a problem remember that there are a great many people who are colour-blind in some way.  Seeing pretty colours in bright lights is no handicap or hardship. Cannabis in large doses is slightly hallucinatory on it's own. The closest I got to any sort of flashback was to feel that if I got really stoned it was more hallucinogenic than it was before I first tripped.  I knew a lot of people who took trips - I never met anyone who had dramatic flashbacks of the type you described nor even heard any second-hand stories of people who did. In the case of a pre-existing serious psychological issue then perhaps such a flashback is possible, but for people in general, I say no.    :-) Nor did I ever see a single person "totally lose their mind" on a trip.   I had a couple of bad trips and saw a handful happen to other people.  In all cases, a couple of minutes of calm reassurance and bonding was all it took to fix the problem and allow the rest of the experience to be joyful. Do not forget that the majority of these rumours about negatives were started by the Govt in order to discourage use.  Just look for a film called "Reefer Madness" and you'll see what I mean - the pure nonsense they spouted about cannabis is utterly farcical.

Every mystical tradition, whether good or bad, has utilized practices that alter consciousness, whether through praying, meditation, self flagellation, fasting, chanting, dancing, sleep deprivation, the list goes on and on. Therein lies the problem of epistemology, what is a valid justification for knowledge. The only recourse I can see is to look at much larger scales of evidence, which includes the anthropological history of these substances throughout time. What we find is that the Industrial Revolution and the cultural changes that occurred during that time have much more to do with the negative affect (not effect) of these experiences. ¬†@Eljose06¬† well I think people conflate Nihilism with existentialism. Nihilists take the cold and meanless universe and anthromorphize it as though it's making a deliberate statement at you, to affirm the futility of your own life's meaning. But if the universe really is meaning devoid, then there isn't anything that judges meaning but you.  In that the universe is devoid of any intrinsic meaning, it is equally devoid of any ability or reason to invalidate those meanings which emerge from the informational systems it hosts. Ones that reach sentience (or further) are the only environment in which an evaluation of meaning can exist, because they are the only phenomenon capable of defining such things into being. Your own private experince of reality is the only universe your current identity is a part of. The makes you literally the "meaning" of the universe (your universe), just like perceivable color is a meaning of wavelengths. The question just becomes one of whether or not your meaning is sustainable to others that might exist.

I see that over 100 ppl already agree with this sentiment, but it‚Äôs actually very subjective. The idea of us being ‚Äòsmall‚Äô or ‚Äòirrelevant‚Äô is true in some senses and not true at all in others.   Indeed, if anything the big idea here is recognizing this relativity or subjectivity and our power to choose this perspective for ourselves. That is, we can see the bright side or the dark side and it‚Äôs totally up to us.   Naturally then we can begin to recognize all the biases we previously applied to different aspects of our lives, and re-balance those views by looking at them from new angles.   Even this outlook that I‚Äôm outlining is not the only way to interpret the psychedelic lesson, but at least I can admit that, for not doing so means you‚Äôve missed the point, or haven‚Äôt gone far enough to see your biases.

¬†@codemiesterbeats¬† One thing to keep in mind when musing over the concepts of duality and equilibrium is that these motifs are more indicative of the way our brains work as opposed to nature herself. For one, we are inherently bivalent -- meaning we are prone to black n white thinking, due simply to evolutionary efficacy (the panther is either in the bush or it isn't). Naturally this bivalence bleeds over to more nuanced topics, e.g., philosophy or politics, where a more fuzzy logic approach would probably be best, yet we still can't help but truncate concepts as this or that, due primarily to the virility of yes-no memes as well as basic intellectual laziness. For two, whereas equilibrium is obviously essential to biochemical processes, it's also essential for logical linearity, and indeed we could not formulate consistent models of reality (such as those very same biochemical processes) without the logical reversible consistency implied by equilibrium of thought. The boolean space of algebra for example, which covers all simple transformations over the real numbers is completely linear, reversible, and based on the idea of equilibria, and we could not count, or reason (cycle of induction and deduction), without at least approximating these kinds of basic logical functions. All-in-all we perpetually mistake the map for the territory, meaning what we convince ourselves are patterns in nature are actually patterns in our thinking.

¬†@SahilP2648¬† Your fear triggered cortisol, adrenalin and etc. Whatever you pay attention to is amplified, so don't focus on fear, focus on something good. Your perception of the normal biological responses to whatever you feel or what you focus your attention on gets amplified. You say thinking about some things helped, that's why. Mindset and setting are important up front. And don't trip if you have serious health issues, like for example liver disease, without medical supervision. And remember, it's a temporary altered state, it wears off, so you will get through it. Cheers!
And everyone gets an initial kick in the gut as they start to take effect, it's normal, it's temporary and it's nothing to fear.

¬†@FractalZero¬† ingredients: Naphtha, Lye, water, and mimosa hostilis root bark. Grind (50 grams) the root bark in a blender to a VERY VERY FINE powder. 2.) Take 50 grams of Lye and dissolve (in a thick glass such as a Crown Royal bottle) in approximately 400ml. of water. 3) Put root bark into a mason jar and then slowly pour the lye water on top. 4) Mix VERY THOROUGHLY. 5) Add approximately 25-30ml. of Naphtha into mason jar. 6) Take a big pot of hot water and fill it up until it reaches the top of the mixture in your mason jar. 7) Put a sandwich baggie secured by a rubber band on top of mason jar and swirl in a clockwise motion until the naphtha is mixed into the root bark solution, and then place the jar into the pot of warm water. 8) Empty the water out of the pan and replace it with warm water every 3-4 hours for at least 24 hours, and every time you go that you swirl and mix your solution (repeat step 7) 9) Extract top layer of Naphtha from your solution and place into a beaker and put into freezer for at least 24 hours. 10) After 24 hours your beaker will be coated on the bottom with white (or yellow) DMT crystals, empty the Naphtha and put in front of a fan to dry for at least an hour. 11) vaporize your freshly made product and prepare to witness another dimension.
